post_text:

error: error while loading CharSequence, class file '/Library/Java/JavaVirtualMachines/jdk1.8.0_20.jdk/Contents/Home/jre/lib/rt.jar(java/lang/CharSequence.class)' is broken  
(bad constant pool tag 18 at byte 10)

title: sbt and Java 8 (on OSX)
post_text:
you can pass try the next command 
sbt  -java-home {JDK install path }

or you can edit the sbt.sh file and update it to accept your JDK path

to check about the used JDK in sbt try the next command 

show java-home

title: sbt and Java 8 (on OSX)
post_text:
You will have to change the environment variable as explained in the video for Working on assignments.

But keeps this in mind: if you copy the bin directory to PATH variable as in the video and still have problems running JDK7 in windows shell, copy the bin directory to the beginning, that helps.
I had a problem with this for a few days before I figured it out.
In windows shell write "java -version", it should give you the version shell is using.

title: Earn a Verified Certificate.
post_text:
Signature track confirms your identity and links the work you do on the course (and successful completion thereof) to your "real world" self. As proof that you completed the course, you get a signed certificate officially recognized by the authority that sponsors the course (in this case, the École Polytechnique Fédérale de Lausanne). 

The idea is that an officially endorsed document with proof of your identity behind it will be easier to accept as a credential when seeking jobs or for other forms of career advancement.

title: Error in example project
post_text:
It's quite easy:

  1. Download scalatest_2.11-2.2.1.jar (or the latest one you find for scala 2.11)
  2. Put this file in your eclipse workspace, e.g. in a 'lib' folder, not inside a particular project
  3. In Eclipse, right-click the project you want to modify and open 'Properties' (or Alt+Enter)
  4. In the left pane, click on 'Java Build Path'
  5. In the right, click on 'Libraries'
  6. Remove the current scalatest_2.10-1.9.1.jar
  7. Click 'Add External JARs' button on the right and select scalatest_2.11-2.2.1.jar

Repeat the process for each project you have the same problem. I've seen it in, at least, 'example.zip' and in the first assignment, 'recfun.zip'. 

Another solution is to edit the file 'build.sbt' and replace scalatest version '1.9.1' with '2.2.1'. This will automatically download the compatible version. If you do this first, you'll find scalatest_2.11-2.2.1 in the directory 'lib_managed/jars/org.scalatest/scalatest_2.11/' Then follow the steps above to change the Eclipse jar starting at step 3.

Hope this helps.

title: Cannot use SBT with example project: error while loading CharSequence
post_text:
I had the same issue (Windows 8 and already JDK version 8 installed due to other projects).

I installed JDK 7, changed the path in the Environments Variables and changed the Java-Home location with the link posted earlier by Egor: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/2619584/how-to-set-java-home-on-windows-7

A quick reboot afterwards and now everything seems to compile well.

title: Cannot use SBT with example project: error while loading CharSequence
post_text:
I also had this problem to fix I had to set JAVA_HOME to java 1.7 

View which versions of java you have installed enter the following in the command line: 
   
 /usr/libexec/java_home -V
Check java 1.7 is present if not you will need to install it from the oracle website

In your .bash_profile add JAVA_HOME and set to point at 1.7 for me this was:
    
export JAVA_HOME=/Library/Java/JavaVirtualMachines/jdk1.7.0_67.jdk/Contents/Home

Reload your .bash_profile using:
 
 source .bash_profile

title: is it a must to use an IDE?
post_text: Yes, you can use a text editor if you want to.  You use sbt which is a command line program to submit your programs.

title: Which exact versions of Java, Scala, sbt work with this course
post_text:
I accidentally downloaded the latest version (2.11) of the IDE.
OTOH, scala as installed on Ubuntu 14.04 results in a 2.9 version.

I was able to use both, and the sbt version as provided.

I had to change a preference in the IDE however, under Scala / Compiler / Build manager, uncheck "withVersionClasspathValidator". It works so far, but I'm not sure if this version difference might lead to issues later. In that case I'll downgrade to 2.10.x.

title: Cannot use SBT with example project: error while loading CharSequence
post_text:
On OSX, I did the following:

- Installed JDK 7u67 from http://www.oracle.com/technetwork/java/javase/downloads/jdk7-downloads-1880260.html
- Edited ~/.profile and added this line:
   export JAVA_HOME="`/usr/libexec/java_home -v '1.7*'`"
  
- opened a new terminal window and typed:
      java -version


This showed me I was now running 1.7 and sbt test worked for me on the example project

Is this a known bug with no solution?
Thank you,
Alex

title: reloading a function?
post_text:
I am following along with the "Working on Programming Assignments" tutorial and I am trying to figure out how to reload a function when you have made changes to it.

For example, I set the result of the sum and max functions to 0 (as in the tutorial), then went to the REPL, imported the functions (with "import example.Lists._) and tested them.  As expected the result of sum(List(1,2,3)) was 0.

Then, back in Eclipse I changed the functions' outputs to 1 and saved the Lists.scala file.  Back in the REPL I imported Lists again (as above), checked the result of sum(Lists(1,2,3)) and got 0 again.  I had to quit the console, restart it and reimport Lists to get the "correct" output of 1.  Is there a way to do this without leaving Scala?

Thanks,
Kevin

title: reloading a function?
post_text:
Good, I have the same question.  :-)

title: Lecture 1.2: Call by name, and pure function
post_text:
Hi, I have 2 or 3 Questions.

Q1

Consider;

def Mult(x: Int, y: Int) = x * y
Mult(2, 3 * 3)

If called by name would it be evaluated like;

Mult(2, 3 * 3)  
2 * 3 * 3  
6 * 3  
18

or; 

Mult(2, 3 * 3)
2 * 3 * 3  
18

?

Q2

On related subject, what does the "pure function" mean? Does this mean that a function is a operator that takes only 2 operands like *, -, /, or + ?

title: error: illegal character
post_text: People seem to be having problems with Java 1.8  try 1.7.

title: Lecture 1.2: Call by name, and pure function
post_text:
Called by name would be:
Mult(2, 3*3)
(2) * (3*3)
6*3
18

The function gets applied before the parameters are evaluated.

Ed

title: reloading a function?
post_text: Exit out of the Scala REPL with ctl-D, type "reload" at the sbt prompt, then back into the Scala REPL, re-import, and try your function again.

title: reloading a function?
post_text:
if you don't want to exit and enter REPL mode again, maybe could use :reset to have a clean environment.

Here is the :help message
:reset                     reset the repl to its initial state, forgetting all session entries

title: "scala.NotImplementedError: an implementation is missing"
post_text:

title: "scala.NotImplementedError: an implementation is missing"
post_text:
This is on purpose. Both max and sum are set to ??? which is scala's way of saying a method is not implemented.  You will have to implement the two functions to get the tests to pass.

Correction: As pointed out below the ??? are a project specific typedef. See Fred's answer: https://class.coursera.org/progfun-005/forum/thread?thread_id=38#post-175.

title: should sum of an empty list be 0 or an exception?
post_text: I chose 0. Like, let's say we have special subtype of List ­– TwoList which is a list that contains only 2-s: (2, 2, 2, 2), (2), and so on. So now we can think about sum of these lists to be a multiplication of 2 by list's length: 2*4, 2*1. Now let's say we have an empty TwoList: (). Because it's a valid TwoList (it contains only 2, but 0 of them) we shouldn't get any error/exception about that and by applying reasoning we used before, we can expect its sum to be 2*0 = 0, so "get sum" makes sense for this list.

title: Lecture 1.2: Call by name, and pure function
post_text: Q2: "pure function" means that the function works only on its arguments and nothing else. Especially this means that a pure function always returns the same result when you pass the same arguments. A pure function does not have any side effects (i.e. it only "reads" its arguments, works with them and returns a value).

title: Style - curly braces
post_text:
Hi,

Scala allows us to write:
if cond
    action1
else
    action2
action3

or 

if cond {
    action1
}
else {
    action2
}
action3

Personally I prefer the latter as it more clearly conveys intent - i.e. you mean the else to be action2 only, not that you intended it to be action2 and action3 but you forgot the curly braces.

IRL I use languages like C# and javascript which also allow both styles and it has happened often enough, particularly in modifying someone else's code, that it is unclear whether the developer indented action3 to always happen, or it should only happen as part of the else.  Insisting on curly braces all the time uses a couple of extra lines, but the intent is clearer.

So two questions:
1. Will using this style affect assignment grades (i.e. will the style checker "punish" me for what seems unnecessary braces)?
2. What do other people think - does this make intent clearer to you?

title: Style - curly braces
post_text:
I don't think that style checker is going to penalize you for this. But whenever in doubt, you can actually run it against your code before submitting the assignment(check https://class.coursera.org/progfun-005/wiki/SbtTutorial).

In terms of brackets, there is one major detail here. Any block in scala can return value and "if" is no exception. So, in more "idiomatic" approach you will try to avoid any mutators / "actions". Instead, you will start using if for computing things. Thus, having something like this:
val x = if (cond) fun1(a, b, c) else fun2(a, b, c)
In such cases, not having {} is a blessing. And even in the example you provided, it would be pretty much clear that action3 was not meant to be a part of else block, if your if had something to return(primarily because action3 would most likely have a totally different type).

Overall, I agree that sometimes {} are needed, so that the code is easier to read(e.g. your action1/action2 can be if on its own). But the exact boundary between using/not using will always be up to you as a developer.

title: Style - curly braces
post_text:
Hi,

Thanks for the feedback.
I'm not sure that it IS clear in my example that action 3 is not meant to be part of the else.

Let's go with a worked example (this is the sort of thing I have seen IRL)
Developer starts with:

if cond
    action1
else
    action2

Later changes to

if cond
    action1
else
    println("some text")
    action2

Now....was this accidental that action2 is NOT part of the else?  It is indented, so it looks at first glance like it is part of the else but obviously is not.

Compare with:
if cond {
    action1
}
else {
    println("some text")
    action2
}

and

if cond {
    action1
}
else {
    println("some text")
}
action2

In both of these cases, the intent is clear.  

IME, unless you have 100% test coverage on conditional branches, you won't catch subtle bugs that may be introduced because of a simple error like this.  Yes it would be great to have 100% coverage, but that can be very hard to achieve, for a variety of reasons, so clarity of intent can be very helpful here.

title: Do tests form part of the assessment?
post_text:
Hi Tony,

short answer: they are for your benefit only.
longer answer: the tests we provide as part of the assignment are intended to give you some intuition for approaching the problem. You are encouraged to write your own tests, refactor the tests as you see fit locally, if that helps you solve the exercises better. The automated assessment will run its own set of tests on the program code that you write, and does not interfere with tests that you may have written yourself.

Cheers,
Manohar

title: Read entire file in Scala
post_text:
I find it hard to believe that Scala is lacking a one line solution to the problem of reading an entire file into a string(I know it is not recommended but, say, I've got a spec/test where I just need to get it done etc.).

Here is the related discussion on StackOverFlow:
http://stackoverflow.com/questions/1284423/read-entire-file-in-scala

So the only safe way to do it with pure Scala is this:

      val source = Source.fromFile(filename)
      try {
        source.mkString
      } finally {
        source.close()
      }

Otherwise an underlying file descriptor will not be released to the system. Does anyone know any workarounds which don't imply leaking resources?

P.S. I would be really happy if Scala had something like try-with-resources that Java 7 introduced...

title: Lecture 1.4: using call-by-name
post_text:
It's been used in lecture 1.4 the following example:

def and(x : Boolean, y: => Boolean) : Boolean =
    if (x) y else false

Professor states that if we assign "loop" to y, using call-by-value, it will not evaluate because it will enter a infinite loop.
So, we should use the "=>" and adopt call-by-name.

So, with that in mind, I have two questions:
a) Should the programmer know before implementation that call-by-name will be necessary? Is this a software requirement, or something that the programmer should do based on his own knowledge?
b) Why wasn't CBN used on both arguments? Is it because, if x caused a infinite loop, the whole expression would never evaluate? While if y causes a infinite loop, the expression evaluates in some cases?

title: Can't understand "isGoodEnough" function in Lecture 1.5
post_text:
Example for small numbers put '0' as a guess. and 

abs(0*0 - x) < 0.0001 ==> x < 0.0001
So 0 would be accepted as a square root of any number smaller than your arbitrarily set-up precision!

the first formula means: "squaring my guess, how far am I from X? I want this 'distance' to small 'in absolute'"
the second formula means: "squaring my guess, how far am I from X? I want this 'distance' to be small compared to X."

abs(guess * guess - x) / x < 0.0001

title: Is it ok to share assignment solution after deadline between a few students?
post_text:
This is the second time I am taking this course.

During the first time, I always felt like: oh, I wanna know if this is the best solution, or oh, I wonder how the others would have done it better.

So this time, I want to get a few more students to study together.

I created a gitlab repository, it's like github, but the repo is private. Only people who are explicitly added to it can access.

So I want to ask your opinion, would it be ok to review and learn from each other's solutions after the deadline?

And if that is ok, please join me. Tell me your gitlab account name, and I will assign read/write access to you, and then we can learn together.

title: Can't understand "isGoodEnough" function in Lecture 1.5
post_text:
This is not a matter of Newton's method but of the numeric precision of floating point numbers, so you might want to google on that.

Simply put: for very large numbers, the distance between two numbers can be much greater than 0.0001. For example:
scala> val n = 1e22 // 10^22
n: Double = 1.0E22

scala> val o = n + 1e5 // 10^22 + 100.000
o: Double = 1.0E22

The distance between 10^22 and its upper neighbour is so big that 10^22+100.000 gets rounded back to 10^22.

So if you operate on two of such large numbers, it is very much possible that the distance between them never gets < 0.0001

However, if you divide that distance by one of those two numbers (in our case: x), you get it back down to a value that can be compared to 0.0001 (you might want to google on "relative error" vs "absolute error" too).

title: How can I translate recursion into tail-recursion?
post_text:
I'm not sure it helps, but I'll give it a try:

It is not always possible. Mutually recursive function for instance do not call themselves but one another. I beleive if such a general algorithm existed it would make @tailrec obsolete as Scala always try to optimize recursion away into a loop.

For a 'normal' recursion, I usually do:
  1. Write the algorithm with a loop and no recursion
  2. Then make a helper function from your loop, where each of the variable mutating in the loop are parameters of the function
  3. Given (2) you can obviously make your new helper function tail recursive you can just call it with initial loop parameters

title: Lecture 1.4: using call-by-name
post_text: Call by name causes that parameter is evaluated when it is needed and call by value is evaluated immediately. Call by value is evaluated once and call by name is evaluated every time when it is called. In this example x has to be evaluated everytime so call by value is more efficient. When x is false then there is no need to evaluate y so there is reason to use call by name.

title: Can't understand "isGoodEnough" function in Lecture 1.5
post_text:
I think it is misleading to say that the issue is floating point precision, it's simpler than that.

Suppose you are trying to guess the size of 20cm pencil.
Let's say your tolerance is 1cm, so you'd accept anything between 19cm and 21cm.

Well, now, let's say you're guessing the thickness of a paper, which is 0.1mm thick.
If you keep the 1cm tolerance and guess that your paper is 10mm thick, you'd have:
abs(10mm - 0.1mm) = 9.9mm < 1cm.
Despite being a really wrong guess, it is within the threshold.

So, the thing is that it doesn't make sense to have a comparison that depends on the order of magnitude of the objects you measure.
Instead, you should normalize your comparison in relation to a known value and use a ratio threshold, for example, 0.05.

abs(19cm - 20cm) / 20cm = 1 / 20 = 0.05 <= 0.05
Not too precise, but within the range.

abs(10mm - 0.1mm) / 0.1mm = 9.9 / 0.1 = 99 >>>>>>>> 0.05
No way this could be right!

title: Lecture 1.7 - Why is it NOT worth making the factorial function tail recursive?
post_text: Tail recursive version is implemented at 12:02 in the video. It is less readable then previous version. Tail recursive is used to prevent stack overflow error, but in this case value of factorial would exceed the range of integer sooner than stack overflow would occur. So in this particular case, you should stick with more readable version.

title: Lecture 1.7 - Why is it NOT worth making the factorial function tail recursive?
post_text:
In this exercise, it's just an example to show the conversion from recursive function to tail recursive function. In practice, it is not worth doing so, because factorial will exceed the range very soon. For small number, tail recursion and normal recursion may cost roughly equally (time & memory) in this example.

Hope this helps.

title: Lecture 1.7 - Why is it NOT worth making the factorial function tail recursive?
post_text: The Int type in Scala has a minimum value of $$-2^{31}$$ and a maximum of $$2^{31}-1$$(inclusive)  (docs), so the maximum value the Int type can represent is smaller than $$factorial(14) \approx 2^{36.34}$$. That means that for any valid number we can get by calling the factorial function, the function is called less than 14 times.

title: for statement in Scala
post_text:
Hi Dmitry,
First, I'd advise you to take the chance and learn to program in functional style: try to use recursion in place of a loop. In fact, for-expressions work quite differently in Scala than in most imperative languages you might be familiar with (they are not really loops!), so they are not introduced until later in the course.
As for your question, the compiler issues a type error because it expected an expression of type Int in this position. The for-expression, however, has type Unit (the equivalent of void in Java).

title: Week 1 FAQ
post_text:
This is a FAQ from previous versions of the class. Some information could be out-of-date.

Is there a limit on a number of submissions?

Yes. We're only allowed five submissions before the grades stop counting towards the effective score for the assignment.

https://class.coursera.org/progfun-004/wiki/view?page=GradingPolicy

How do I compute the elements of Pascal's triangle?

There's a nifty animation on Wikipedia's page for Pascal's triangle, right next to the table of contents:

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pascal%27s_triangle

Note that you should not compute the elements of the triangle using other formulae for binomial coefficients. Grader may rely on certain behavior specific to this particular way to implement this function.

What should I do in pascal() if c > r?

Grader will not complain if you return zero in that case.

What exactly does it mean for a string to be balanced?

A string with no parentheses in it is balanced. Any given opening parenthesis is balanced if and only if there's a closing parenthesis to the right of it such that the expression between them is also balanced. Any given closing parenthesis is balanced if and only if there's an opening parenthesis to the left of it such that the expression between them is also balanced. An expression is balanced if and only if all of the parentheses in it are balanced.

Note that this does not give you an immediate solution for the problem - you should think about it a little.

What does CHF stand for?

It's the currency symbol for Swiss franc.

How many ways are there to change 0 CHF?

One way - using no coins at all. No, you cannot give no coins if asked for 14 CHF - sum of an empty sequence of numbers is 0, not 14.

What do all those isEmpty, head and tail methods actually do?

Give them a shot in sbt console or Scala worksheet.

Should my solution be runnable?

Yes. run in sbt should produce a simple representation of Pascal's triangle.

Should I use just what we learned in the class so far?

Generally speaking, yes. Graders are known to check the code for using certain features in at least some cases. Besides, it's a good idea anyway.

Should I handle edge/corner cases?

Generally speaking, the assignment instructions tend to tell us whenever we need to do something specific about "weird" inputs. In all other cases you may assume the inputs are valid.

Should I make my solutions tail-recursive?

No. The grader will be perfectly happy with solutions that do not use tail recursion.

Can I make my solutions tail-recursive?

Yes, you can make pretty much anything tail-recursive. Simple tail-recursion takes the form of:

def f(current_state: StateType): StateType =
  if (exit_condition(current_state))
    current_state
  else
    f(make_new_state(current_state))
f(initial_state)

and is equivalent to the following imperative approach (in pseudo-code):

current_state := initial_state
while not exit_condition(current_state) do
    mutate_state(current_state)
end

Anything that can be computed one of these two ways can also be computed the other way (in fact, the transformation from one to the other is purely mechanical). You may convice yourself that anything computable can be computed iteratively by considering the Universal Turing Machine - which is certainly an iterative process.

But the question you should be asking yourself is whether making your solution tail-recursive gave you any benefit. If making a function tail-recursive requires passing a lot of state as a parameter, you're trading off stack space for heap space, which may or may not be useful, depending on the situation. For example, writing tree traversal in tail-recursive form is no rocket science, but it's usually an exercise in pointlessness, unless your stack space is extremely constrained, while heap space is abundant.

Why am I not supposed to use var? I need mutable state.

You can have mutable state without mutable variables. See the example in the previous question - it has "mutable" state, but all functions remain referentially transparent (i.e., they always produce the same result given the same inputs).

My solution passes all of provided unit tests, but the grader complains about it.

Unit tests provided with the assignment do not cover all of the cases. In fact, writing your own test cases is part of the assignment. And with the limit on a number of submissions it's a crucial part of it.

I don't get if .. else - it doesn't quite do what I expected.

if .. else is not equivalent to if .. else statements in imperative programming languages. It's an expression, which means it has a type and always evaluates to a value, so it closer to ternary operator (?:) in C-like languages or foo if bar else baz in Python.

The type of any if expression is the least common ancestor of the types of its branches (we'll learn more about Scala's type system later in the class). While we're using proper if .. else expressions, where the types of expressions in both branches are the same, that reduces to "if expression has the same type as its branches". if without an explicit else clause still has it, implicitly, but its type is AnyVal, and so is the type of the entire if expression in this case.

What's wrong with using return?

A ton of things, perhaps the scariest being the fact that it doesn't respect the boundaries of anonymous functions.

But perhaps more importantly, if you're thinking in terms of return, you're doing something wrong. Most if not all of your function definitions should consist of a single expression (perhaps with some auxiliary definitions). This expression may be quite involved, but it will always evaluate to something - and that something will be "returned" by your function.

What's the best way to enforce preconditions in my functions?

It depends, but require is great.

title: Description of the Counting Change Algorithm
post_text:
Essentially this is a graph search problem, but with a different twist.  The easiest way to do it is by implementing a BFS that adds up the number of unique combinations to your goal.

It is also tricky because 1+1+2 is the same as 1+2+1 (but is only count once).  So lets say you are passed a list (1,2,3). Any time you add a value that is not on the head of the list you can never add the current head again.  That way you will get 1+1+1+1, then 1+1+2 and 2+2 and 1+3 but not 2+1+1 or 3+1(when change == 4).  So one you add the 2 the only working set left in your list is (2,3).

I don't want to explain the whole algorithm but this should help!

edit: adding some description

title: sbt and Java 8 (on OSX)
post_text:
I've had the same problem. And as already pointed out here, setting JAVA_HOME to point to another JRE solves the problem. To find out all available java installations on your system, issue the following command:

/usr/libexec/java_home -V

In my case, it returns:

Matching Java Virtual Machines (3):
    1.8.0_11, x86_64: "Java SE 8" /Library/Java/JavaVirtualMachines/jdk1.8.0_11.jdk/Contents/Home
    1.6.0_65-b14-462, x86_64: "Java SE 6" /System/Library/Java/JavaVirtualMachines/1.6.0.jdk/Contents/Home
    1.6.0_65-b14-462, i386: "Java SE 6" /System/Library/Java/JavaVirtualMachines/1.6.0.jdk/Contents/Home

The given path is is the one you should select for JAVA_HOME. I've picked the second entry (JDK 1.6.0) and without any changes to the configuration, the following command (all on one line) starts the console just fine:

JAVA_HOME=/System/Library/Java/JavaVirtualMachines/1.6.0.jdk/Contents/Home sbt console

It has the effect, that the modified value of JAVA_HOME here will be applied just for the subsequent command 'sbt console', but won't be changed at all in your system. So, I've simply set an alias in .bash_profile like that:

alias sbtconsole="JAVA_HOME=/System/Library/Java/JavaVirtualMachines/1.6.0.jdk/Contents/Home sbt console"

title: sbt -h gives errors: "No such file or directory" and "command not found" on OS X 10.9.4
post_text:
When installing sbt and creating .bash_profile, starting sbt -h gives the following error:

line 23: /Users/Eric/Applications/sbt-launch-lib.bash: No such file or directory

line 104: run: command not found

This is caused by the use of special characters in the path, that needs to be escaped (space needs to be escaped in following path: /Users/Username/Downloaded\ Applications/sbt/bin). By looking into SBT FAQ, this error is acknowledged for Linux, but not for OS X. The easiest way to fix this error, is by using pathnames without special characters (spaces, quotes, etc.).

title: sbt and Java 8 (on OSX)
post_text:
It is even easier, since there is in the /usr/libexec a java_home program to get the location for installed JDKs. So in order to start sbt with version 1.7. You can simply say

sbt -java-home `/usr/libexec/java_home -v 1.7`

(mind the back quotes). So you do not have to know where it is exactly installed and it will not break if you install an update for 1.7.

title: OpenJDK couldn't start due to not enough space for object heap
post_text:
Problem solved.

The problem is I'm using a 32-bit machine, but the memory settings is too large (such as 1536M). I tried to edit the sbt startup script to turn down the memory usage. Now it works all fine. See this link: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/4401396/could-not-reserve-enough-space-for-object-heap

Doing the same thing on the file directly produced the "No JUnit tests found" message.

So right-click on the package rather than the test file.

Java version 1.7.0_17

$ brew install sbt

[info] 'compiler-interface' not yet compiled for Scala 2.10.2. Compiling...

java.lang.OutOfMemoryError: PermGen space

title: Can't understand "isGoodEnough" function in Lecture 1.5
post_text:
For too small numbers the computation prematurely stops. You can see that using this code

def isGoodEnough(guess: Double, x: Double) = {
    val myGuess = guess * guess
    val difference = abs(myGuess - x)
    println("dif:" + difference + " myGuess:" + myGuess)
    difference < 0.001
}
and testing with $$x = 10^{-20}$$ the guess will try to go down but will stop as soon as the difference hits the $$0.001$$ threshold as shown below 

> dif:1.0 myGuess:1.0
//| dif:0.25 myGuess:0.25
//| dif:0.0625 myGuess:0.0625
//| dif:0.015625 myGuess:0.015625
//| dif:0.00390625 myGuess:0.00390625
//| dif:9.765625E-4 myGuess:9.765625E-4
//| res0: Double = 0.03125
You may wonder why is the difference the same as myGuess? That is because x is just too small compared to myGuess to make any noticeable change. However if you run the code with $$x = 9$$ you will see these too variables in fact have different values

> dif:8.0 myGuess:1.0
//| dif:16.0 myGuess:25.0
//| dif:2.5599999999999987 myGuess:11.559999999999999
//| dif:0.1417301038062284 myGuess:9.141730103806228
//| dif:5.493331704400362E-4 myGuess:9.00054933317044
//| res0: Double = 3.00009155413138
For big numbers the reasoning is the same but the difference of $$0.001$$ between any too numbers is just too small and unreachable. In that case you are risking to make an infinite loop. This problem is a matter of resolution and absolute vs. relative difference (error).

title: Is python also a functional programming language?
post_text:
Straight from wiki:

In computer science, functional programming is a programming paradigm, a style of building the structure and elements of computer programs, that treats computation as the evaluation of mathematical functions and avoids changing state and mutable data.

You can even do functional programming in c++ : http://meetingcpp.com/tl_files/mcpp/slides/12/FunctionalProgrammingInC++11.pdf !

The Real questions are more :

  1. How easily a given language does support functional programming paradigm ?
  2. How much does it forces you into it ?

python and c++ are very open. OOP if you want, functional if you want, crappy spaghetti if you want ...
scala has more built in support for FP than python. Haskell does not give you any other choice.

The above stack overflow is a very good answer to question 1 for python. (and therefore upvoted)

title: Is it usual to not release all the lectures & assignments at the start?

Hi Randall,

I have taken other courses that didn't have the materials available before the lectures for the corresponding week had already finished (like Learn to Program, the Fundamentals, for example). A different example is Introduction to Databases, which has everything ready for download and is a self-study course.

As you can see, there's diversity. So I guess we'll have to be patient!

title: Functional Style question
post_text:
def foo2(theList: List[Int]):Int = {
     if (theList.isEmpty)
        1
     else
        theList.head * foo2(theList.tail)
  }
  
  def foo3(theList: List[Int]): Int = {
    if (theList.isEmpty)
       return 1
    theList.head * foo3(theList.tail)
  }

Why is foo2 more desirable, from a functional programming style perspective, than foo3?  IMHO, the tail recursion is more obvious in foo3.

title: Functional Style question
post_text:
Also, since "if" is an expression, shouldn't one be be able to do:

x + if (a > b) c else d

instead of:

x + {if (a > b) c else d}

title: Passing all the tests (Week 1)
post_text:
As stated in this handy FAQ https://class.coursera.org/progfun-005/forum/thread?thread_id=71 it seems that:

Note that you should not compute the elements of the triangle 
using other formulae for binomial coefficients. Grader may rely on 
certain behavior specific to this particular way to implement this 
function.

In fact with my first submission, using a similar approach as yours, I got the same error.
Rewriting the function using the animated wikipedia's gif about the Pascal's Triangle as a guideline [ http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pascal%27s_triangle ] solved it.

title: Functional Style question
post_text:
I would probably write the latter as 

"x + (if (a > b) c else d)"

but yeah it is a bit weird. Essentially it seems you just need to spell out the order of evaluation for Scala in this instance.

As to your first question, the main point in functional programming is that everything is an expression and an expression needs to return a value, of the same type for all its branches. From this point of view, it doesn't make much sense to have an "if" without an else. "foo3" is very imperative in nature, it has a series of steps that you must perform one after the other. Functional programing is more declarative. "foo2" says that its value is either "1" or "theList.head * foo3(theList.tail)", depending on the result of the comparison. It does not say "try this, and if it works return, if it does not do all these extra steps". It says "my value is either this or that".

Takes some getting used to.

title: Lazy Evalutation with Memoization vs Call-by-value and Call-by-name
post_text:
After watching the comparison of call-by-name and call-by-value in Lecture 1.3, I am wondering why lazy evaluation (or call-by-need) using memoization isn't mentioned.  By using memoization, lazy evaluation should be able to evaluate an argument only if it is used (like call-by-name), but store the result for later reuse.  This strategy evaluates only what must be evaluated, and evaluates each argument at most one time.

I'm interested to hear the tradeoffs of this approach.

title: Description of the Counting Change Algorithm
post_text:
At each step of the recursion you should keep moneyLeftToBeExchanged and the list of availableCoins.
If the moneyLeftToBeExchanged == 0 it means you have found a way to change the initial amount (you will select 0 from each remaining coins) 
if moneyLeftToBeExchanged < 0 this change thus far is a failure
if moneyLeftToBeExchanged > 0 there is still hope we can change it legally. 
In the last case you should Recur for each number of legal number of coins of the first coin in the list of availableCoins   Think what should be the moneyLeftToBeExchanged and the list of availableCoins.

By this method it is guaranteed that you will count only legal and distinct change.

title: Pascal's Triangle
post_text:
@Randall, 

"Optimal" is kind of subjective, depends on the context right? If the use case is only ever going to be for a small data set, then I'd say readability trumps an "optimized" solution in the sense of performance, because for small data sets it doesn't matter. Other people being able to read your code and understand it is actually optimal in this case. We've all heard that premature optimization is the root of all evil.

That said, if using tail recursion you end up with a solution that is (probably) more readable than an imperative solution, and also more performant (correct me if I'm wrong) because of immutability.

title: Lazy Evalutation with Memoization vs Call-by-value and Call-by-name
post_text:
AFAIK this is realized like this:
  def f(expensiveValue: => Int): Int = {
    lazy val x: Int = expensiveValue
    if (...) x*x*x*x else ...
  }

This way expensiveValue is evaluated at most once, and only when needed (because of the lazy keyword for the alias x)

title: Lazy Evalutation with Memoization vs Call-by-value and Call-by-name
post_text:
Call-by-name is in my view to be avoided, though I'd be happy to be shown examples to prove me wrong, i.e. examples where you want something like call-by-name but can't get by with call-by-need/lazy evaluation.

  1. The main tradeoff between call-by-value and call-by-need, though as I would prefer to call them direct evaluation vs lazy evaluation, is that the language needs to set some things in place to make lazy evaluation work. Intuitively what a language in lazy evaluation mode would need to do is create a "box" that would eventually hold the value of the computation, and when that value is asked to know what computation it needs to do to fill in the box. Or to put it simply, the language needs to replace an access to a variable with a "look at a cache. If value is there use it, else compute it, cache it and return it".
    So the main tradeoff is that lazy evaluation makes accessing the values a bit slower when you do end up needing the values. How much of an issue it is depends on how expensive the computation is, how "thick" the lazyness layers are, and how likely you are to need the value. One of the problems in my view is that, unless this is built into the language so that it's all over the place by default like Haskell, it's often hard for the "user" of the expensive computation to know that it is in fact an expensive computation. In Stefan's example above, somehow f is meant to know not just that it will be passed integer values, but furthermore that those values are meant to be expensive computations. It kind of requires that f "know" something about its surroundings. Depending on the program structure, this may not be easy.

  2. A drawback of lazy evaluation is that, depending on how many computations you have delayed, you may end up at some point calling for all of them at once. This may or may not matter depending on the situation.

  3. The main drawback of lazy evaluation is that it really does not play well in languages with side-effects (or I guess from my point of view this is a drawback of languages with side-effects, that they don't lend themselves well to lazy evaluation). If your "expensiveValue" produces a side-effect, then you do not know if that side-effect will occur, or even when it will occur in relation to other side-effects that may be taking place in the function f. Being uncertain about the order of execution of your program is not a good situation to be in.

Consider the following code example, which is not valid Scala but would illustrate the problems with having side-effects plus laziness:

val y = 1;
def f(exp1: => Int) {
    lazy val x = exp1;
    y * x * y
}
def g() = { y = 3; 4 }
f(g())

Here when the computation of exp1 is forced, the value of y would change (that's the side-effect, and Scala wouldn't allow that). But when does that happen in relation to the expression yxy? Would the first y and the third y end up with different values? Would they both have the value 1? Will they both have the value 3? It's best to avoid that kind of question.

title: Lazy Evalutation with Memoization vs Call-by-value and Call-by-name
post_text:
Is *this* the reason why you recommend against using CBN? Just because you could do really weird things with it?

There are some more useful things that you can do with lazy evaluation, e.g. working on infinite lists: Imagine a function fibs:List[Int] returning the list of all Fibonacci numbers. Of course when calling println(fibs) you will not get any result, because it will take forever to calculate the complete list of these numbers.

What about println(fibs.take(10))? Without lazy evaluation you will run into the same trouble. With lazy evaluation it is possible to calculate only as many Fibonacci numbers as are required by .take(10)...

title: which test suite launch the grading assigments?
post_text:
Writing your own tests is part of assignment. If you would know grading tests before hand, you'll miss all the fun when submitting.
With only few tests provided, you are forced to always think about your solution and question if it is sufficient.

One pitfall/characteristic in test driven development is that you write only as minimal code (and logic) as possible to pass the tests. So your implementation could be faked or wrong (on purpose or without knowing)

Example: If only this test case provided
test("sum of 3 and 4"){
  assert(sum(3,4) === 7)
}
Implementation that pass test could look
def sum(x:Int, y:Int) = 7

Example is made up, but you'll get a point

title: Java 8
post_text:
If you have java 8 and java 7 installed at the same time in windows, you can make sbt work with java 7 editing C:\Program Files (x86)\sbt\sbt.bat, adding at the beginning of the file these 2 lines:

SET JAVA_HOME=C:\Program Files\Java\jdk1.7.0_67
SET PATH=%JAVA_HOME%;C:\Windows\system32;C:\Windows;<rest of the path>

Another option is to open the windows command prompt as an administrator and switch between the two JDKs with:

SETX -M JAVA_HOME "C:\Program Files\Java\jdk1.7.0_67"
and
SETX -M JAVA_HOME "C:\Program Files\Java\jdk1.8.0_20"

being the System path: %JAVA_HOME%;C:\Windows\system32;...

Mind the difference between SET and SETX -M, the first command only changes the environment variables for a session, whereas the second one changes the system environment variables (for all users). Finally, if you only write SETX without options, you change the user variables, but it doesn't work because the "%JAVA_HOME% in the system path doesn't expand.

However the grading system just gave me 8.67 out of 10 points. This is due to an automated test that does not meet the description in the comment.

Although this "Getting Started"-Assignment is optional and not relevant for the overall score I this could be improved, either by adapting the comments or the automated test, since for most people it's the first assignment and therefore crucial for future motivation.

Other than that I am very happy with the lesson structure and quality of the videos (except: 4! is not 120 but 24) and assignments and the (coursera) system!

/**
   * In order to test the exceptional behavior of a methods, ScalaTest offers
   * the `intercept` operation.
   *
   * In the following example, we test the fact that the method `intNotZero`
   * throws an `IllegalArgumentException` if its argument is `0`.
   */
  test("intNotZero throws an exception if its argument is 0") {
    intercept[IllegalArgumentException] {
      intNotZero(0)
    }
  }
From the example assignment test code "ListsSuite.scala". It's used as a small ScalaTest tutorial and it's highly recommended to read it.

title: Missing return statement
post_text:
Hello,

My first approach to the max function was following:

  def max(xs: List[Int]): Int = {

    def inner(xs: List[Int], maxValue: Int): Int = {

      if (xs.isEmpty) maxValue

      if (maxValue < xs.head) inner(xs.tail, xs.head)

      else inner(xs.tail, maxValue)

    }

    if (xs.isEmpty) throw new NoSuchElementException()

    inner(xs.tail, xs.head)

  }

However, it was throwing java.util.NoSuchElementException: head of empty list exception.

After adding return statement as follows:
  if (xs.isEmpty) return  maxValue
it started working correctly. I thought that it isn't necessary to write return keyword to exit the function with the given value. Was I wrong? Why return statement is so crucial in this example?

title: Missing return statement
post_text: use "else" with your if

title: Missing return statement
post_text: Right, but why is it so important? I thought that if you return maxValue (event without using return keyword) the rest of the code should not be executed.

title: Missing return statement
post_text:
I think posting the source of a working solution is against the Coursera's Honor Code, you should probably modify it to be a generalized example of the same problem.

Anyway an if statement is treated like a function that returns a value. Your code, simplified, is the same as:
def f(): Any {
  value
  value
}
So the first value is simply lost and only the second one is returned, always, because it's the last one of the method f(). You should do something like that:
def f(): Any {
  if(cond)
    value
  else
    if(cond2) value else value
}
So at the end of the method life only one branch of the outer if is returned.

I hope this was more helpful than confusing.

title: Missing return statement
post_text: The return isn't implicit, just the value of the function being the value of the last statement executed is implicit.  It's considered bad functional style to use explicit returns.

title: Missing return statement
post_text:
Yes, it makes sense.
And you probably right that I missed the point with posting the possible solution here. At least this task is from the 'getting started' section, so I hope it does not make much harm.

title: Missing return statement
post_text: Remember that if is an expression not a statement: without "else" evaluation continues at the next if statement regardless of the result of the isEmpty test.

title: How to run tests from sbt console?
post_text:
You need to run "test" from the sbt top-level rather than within the sbt console.  You can also run "compile" from the top level but its not necessary as "test" will compile for you.

You will also need to be at the top level to run the submit command once you are done.

title: Is it usual to not release all the lectures & assignments at the start?
post_text:
Keeping the class in sync by releasing materials on a week by week basis is one of the common features among many Coursera courses [ yes, there are exceptions ].

The pedagogical rationale is that the social benefits of following a more traditional academic model outweigh the costs in individual cases. The preference for keeping an academic style schedule differentiates Coursera from the vast numbers of self-paced resources available on the web and in print - e.g. a person can purchase a tutorial book on Scala and work through at their own pace.

For me, having a clear start and end to the course is useful because

  • There's always an end in site at the point where working through the material becomes a death march

  • Missing an assignment because I'm busy is simplified down to a 'grade management' exercise and I can stay moving forward with the class rather than fretting that I have to go back.

  • The idea of taking a course again is more coherent when courses move forward on a schedule from beginning to end.

title: Best way to keep track of recursion progress
post_text:
I am not sure if I understand your question clearly, but I'll give it a try.

I understand that you want to save your computation at each recurse, So, what you can do is add it to a List as you were planning. Each new computation you do will be added to the head of the list. And at the end, you can reverse you list to get proper order of results.

i.e.

val listChar = List[Char]()              //> listChar  : List[Char] = List()
 
val addingOne = '1' :: listChar          //> addingOne  : List[Char] = List(1)
val addingTwo = '2' :: addingOne         //> addingTwo  : List[Char] = List(2, 1)
val addingThree = '3' :: addingTwo       //> addingThree  : List[Char] = List(3, 2, 1)
val addingFour = '4' :: addingThree      //> addingFour  : List[Char] = List(4, 3, 2, 1)
 
addingFour.reverse                       //> res0: List[Char] = List(1, 2, 3, 4)

title: Best way to keep track of recursion progress
post_text:
btw, adding an Element at the head is O(1) operation - instant! 

reversing it is O(n) operation which you will do only once.

title: How to use Scala 2.11.1 and latest Eclipse on Mac OS X
post_text:
Since various people have been asking... you can get things working with all the latest and greatest SBT/ScalaIDE/Mac OS X by editing the build.sbt as follows:

--- a/build.sbt
+++ b/build.sbt
@@ -2,11 +2,11 @@ name <<= submitProjectName(pname => "progfun-"+ pname)

 version := "1.0.0"

-scalaVersion := "2.10.4"
+scalaVersion := "2.11.1"

 scalacOptions ++= Seq("-deprecation", "-feature")

-libraryDependencies += "org.scalatest" %% "scalatest" % "1.9.1" % "test"
+libraryDependencies += "org.scalatest" %% "scalatest" % "2.1.7" % "test"

 libraryDependencies += "junit" % "junit" % "4.10" % "test"

@@ -24,22 +24,22 @@ libraryDependencies <++= (currentProject) { c =>
 libraryDependencies <++= (currentProject) { c =>
   if (c.isEmpty || c == "nodescala" || c == "suggestions") Seq(
     "com.netflix.rxjava" % "rxjava-scala" % "0.15.0",
-    "org.json4s" % "json4s-native_2.10" % "3.2.5",
-    "org.scala-lang" % "scala-swing" % "2.10.3",
-    "net.databinder.dispatch" % "dispatch-core_2.10" % "0.11.0",
-    "org.scala-lang" % "scala-reflect" % "2.10.3",
+    "org.json4s" % "json4s-native_2.11" % "3.2.10",
+    "org.scala-lang" % "scala-swing" % "2.11.0-M7",
+    "net.databinder.dispatch" % "dispatch-core_2.11" % "0.11.0",
+    "org.scala-lang" % "scala-reflect" % "2.11.1",
     "org.slf4j" % "slf4j-api" % "1.7.5",
     "org.slf4j" % "slf4j-simple" % "1.7.5",
     "com.squareup.retrofit" % "retrofit" % "1.0.0",
-    "org.scala-lang.modules" %% "scala-async" % "0.9.0-M2"
+    "org.scala-lang.modules" % "scala-async_2.11.0-M6" % "0.9.0-M2"
      )
   else Seq.empty
 }

 libraryDependencies <++= (currentProject) { c =>
   if (c.isEmpty || c == "actorbintree" || c == "kvstore") Seq(
-    "com.typesafe.akka" %% "akka-actor" % "2.2.3",
-    "com.typesafe.akka" %% "akka-testkit" % "2.2.3"
+//    "com.typesafe.akka" %% "akka-actor" % "2.2.3",
+//    "com.typesafe.akka" %% "akka-testkit" % "2.2.3"
     )
   else Seq.empty
 }


With this change to  build.sbt you can then run
sbt eclipse
Then you can import your project into Eclipse. After this, I recommend backing out the change so you don't confuse Coursera when submitting. Only do this for generating Eclipse project files

Caveats!
  • This upgrades various Scala libraries to later versions, which may bring in new features that the older libraries don't support. Do not use those new features
  • Make sure you run/test everything in sbt using the original build.sbt before submission so you know it works with the old libs
  • This may require you have the sbt-eclipse plug-in installed. I have addSbtPlugin("com.typesafe.sbteclipse" % "sbteclipse-plugin" % "2.2.0") in my sbt plugins directory
For a regular scala developer, the above is fairly standard stuff so hopefully okay to follow. It assumes you know that SBT compilation and Eclipse compilation are totally independent.

If you are relatively new, the above will be hard. In that case you are much better off following the Coursera instructions exactly and install their recommended versions and not try to be clever.

YMMV and these instructions are only for experienced people who already have the latest and greatest installed. I take no responsibility for anyone who screws up their submissions for reasons including trying to submit coursework with upgraded libraries or failing to test their work on the original build.sbt.

title: VDO 2-4 - Lecture 1-4: Why doesn't the loop expression work like it does in the video lecture?
post_text:
Hello !

Here it says that the "loop" value was not found, it means "loop" doesn't exist in the REPL's context (yet).

You need to define loop before using it. So in your REPL you would actually type :

def loop: Boolean = loop

def and(x: Boolean, y: =>Boolean) = if(x) y else false

and(false, loop)

Hope this helps !

title: IntelliJ 13.1 not recognize Scala classes
post_text:
You need to import the assignment in Intellij.
In the startup menu in IntelliJ, you need to click on import project.
Then you navigate to the folder where the assignement is located and search for build.sbt.
Select build.sbt and click on import button, that should work.

changeCount(any value, List()) = 0 (not possible to return a value>0 without coins)

title: Description of the Counting Change Algorithm
post_text:
When I submitted the assignment, I had 4 conditional branches, but immediately after, I realized I could reduce to 3.

1 branch return 0
1 branch with 1 recursive call
1 branch with 2 recursive calls

I had another branch with a recursive call to handle coins that are larger than money, but a slight modification to the first branch allows the last branch to resolve it.

title: Missing return statement
post_text:
In general the "mode of operation" to get used to when writing in functional programming would most typically be:

def f(...) = {
    aDeclaration   (inner def, val etc)
    anotherDeclaration
    aThirdDeclaration
    anExpressionThatUsesTheAboveToComputeReturnStatement
}

In other words there is always only one expression, which may be a big set of nested if-else blocks perhaps. The only reason for the multiple statements is so that you can declare some helper methods or intermediate values, but once you are done declaring those the rest should really be one expression, that computes the result value using the other declared quantities along the way.

It is imperative to stop thinking in an imperative way, saying something along the lines of "do this; then do this; then do that". Instead think declaratively: "My answer is the result of this expression, in which this symbol means that value, and this inner function is defined this way, and ..". Do not read if-else as saying "if this is true, then do that thing, else do the other thing". Read it as saying "My result is this expression if the logical test is true, otherwise it's this other expression".

I'll add to that a specific comment for this problem. Instead of trying to raise an expression yourself, you can rely on xs.head to throw it for you.

title: Brute force argument exception handling  (or a better way?)
post_text:
I am thinking that Scala may have a better technique than I am aware of,  for function argument exception processing.

The brute force method is to set a flag outside the function to discern between the initial vs, recursive calls to the function, where a condition is, and is not, an error.

This would seem to be a common situation in functional programming and I would be a bit surprised if function argument exception processing was not a first class implementation in Scala during initial function evaluation.

Is the brute force method the way to go,  or is there a better way?

title: How much Java one need to (survive/ get good/ be very happy) with Scala?
post_text: I've been developing Scala professional for a few years now. Before that, I was developing in Java, so I considered myself fluent in Java. Looking, back, I'd say that not knowing any Java is actually a benefit when learning Scala, since you won't be tempted to do things "The Java Way." Scala does allow you to write code that looks just like java, but most benefits from Scala come from when you move beyond how you did things in Java and fully embrace functional programming and the ridiculously powerful type system that Scala has.

title: Is python also a functional programming language?
post_text:
Functional programming is more than just having function literals. For example, python does not support immutable values to my knowledge. A strong type system also helps, since a function is basically a mapping from one domain (your arguments) to another (your return value). Type systems specify these domains.

As alluded to in that stackoverflow article, the other issue is the ecosystem of the language. In Scala, the community has bought into the functional programming paradigm. Most libraries do not use mutable state, and tend to consist of a few functions to be composed with the rest of your application.

title: Ex 3. What if changeCount(0, List(any combination of coins)) and changeCount(any value, List())?
post_text:
Ger is right, I think there was a comment somewhere in the contents about that....

This point follows the "normal" intuition:
  • if you have to give 0 change there is only one option: not give any coin. Any other option would imply to give more money than you should (there are no negative coins)
  • if you need to give x > 0 in change but you have no coins to chose from there is no way to give it. There are 0 ways to give that change, doesn't matter the value of x.
Once I got those cases covered the solution was much easier. Hope it helps.-

title: Brute force argument exception handling  (or a better way?)
post_text:
Can you clarify what you mean by "argument exception handling?" If possible with a code example?

Setting a flag outside of the function is generally frowned upon for two reasons. First, the flag would have to be mutable, and second, the inner function would have to set the flag, which would be a side effect, making the function impure.

In Scala, errors are usually handled through the type system. If a function needs to indicate that it might not be able to return a value, it specifies a return type of Option[ReturnType]. If it wants to return an error indicating why it couldn't, then there is an Either[ErrorType, ReturnType] type to use. There are other types for handling asynchronous functions that never return, and other error cases.

I am intentionally being not very specific, as I am sure these will be covered soon in the lectures. Odersky briefly touched on Option already.

title: 'console' command fails to give a scala prompt
post_text:
SBT runs from the root of the project. If you downloaded the zip file and extracted it to a directory called "recfun," then you only run SBT from the "recfun" directory.

More specifically, SBT needs to be able to find a project definition in the directory you run it in. In this case the project definition is the "build.sbt" file.

title: Brute force argument exception handling  (or a better way?)
post_text:
Please clarify "argument exception handling". As I interpret your post, what you want is to handle "special cases" of the arguments, so I answear with that in mind. Also, what you call brute force is not brute force.

We should not use mutables if they are not really necesary (not sure if they are ever really needed, that's why I'm in the course...) They are not needed for week 1 at least.

To know whether it's the "first call" or not you can use one function inside other. The external exposes the signature you want (or the one you are required) while the internal handles the recursive calls (and it has extra parameters) I solved the balance problem this way. There is a Hint in the example project: "You might need to define an auxiliary method"

Hope it helps.-

There is an error condition, for which an exception must be thrown, of an input parameter to a recursive function.  If the parameter error condition does not exist (and exception is not thrown),  the same condition is used for terminating the tail recursion in the function variable assigned by said parameter.  In other words, what is initially a parameter error condition is later the recursion termination condition.  I need to be able to either throw an exception on the parameter BEFORE the function is evaluated, OR, throw an exception on the function variable assigned by the parameter BEFORE any recursive calls to the function.   

Does this make sense?

title: Small hint on IntelliJ IDEA for runnig unit tests
post_text:
Use ScalaTest for running your unit tests to see the test output. The Scala plugin will create the ScalaTest configuration by default when you run a test suite for the first time. But occasionally it will create a JUnit configuration instead.

To get rid of this behavior remove the @RunWith(classOf[JUnitRunner]) from the test suites. Then remove the JUnit configurations from your project. You can access the "Edit Configurations..." from the drop down list in the upper right corner or in the "Run" menu. On the next run a new ScalaTest configuration will be created.

title: Ex 3. What if changeCount(0, List(any combination of coins)) and changeCount(any value, List())?
post_text:
The assignment says "counts how many different ways you can make change for an amount".
Therefore, in my interpretation:

changeCount(0, List(any combination of coins)) = 0 (there is absolutely no way to combine the coins to give you a 0 change)
changeCount(any value, List()) = 0 (there is no way to combine an empty list of coins to give a change.)

title: Brute force argument exception handling  (or a better way?)
post_text:
Hi John,

I am not sure I fully understand your question, but let me try to rephrase. Are you asking what the best way to handle base cases in recursive functions is?

If so, I would recommend not using exceptions in general. Indeed, for most recursive functions, the base case usually has some meaning. This meaning is captured either by some specific value (say 0 in the case of the fibonacci recursion) or some base value. As others have mentioned above, this meaning can be captured either by an empty list or by the `None` variant of an `Optiion` (if you do not yet know what this is, be patient for a few more weeks :-)).

Hope this clarifies!

Cheers,
Manojo

title: Ex 3. What if changeCount(0, List(any combination of coins)) and changeCount(any value, List())?
post_text:
I was struggling with the same philosophical question on 0 change.  :-)
But the meaning of 0 as an answer in this problem is that it is impossible to give a change.
On the other hand the meaning of 1 as an answer is that it is allowed to give 0 coins as change when the amount = 0.
It's like shopping in the supermarket. If your change is 0 you will get 0 coins and this is the only one possible solution. But if your change > 0 and there are 0 coins left then we have a problem.

title: Is python also a functional programming language?
post_text:
Ordersky in Lecture 1.1.

> In the more general sense, functional
> programming means focusing on the
> functions in the program.
> So, in a sense, it gives you new
> capabilities to work with these functions.
> In particular, functions can be values
> that are produced, consumed and composed.
> All this can be done in any programming
> language.

But of course everyone wants to call languages 'functional' because it's good marketing.

> in the wider sense the functual programming
> language is one with that enables the
> construction of elegant programs that
> focus on the functions.
> In particular functions in a functual
> programming language or first class
> citizens.

That said, Common Lisp is often called a 'functional language'. But the degree to which it facilitates mutation would be considered scandalous by any purist - there are mutable versions of almost every major function. They are there for speed.

Functional programming is a style or paradigm, and the more relevant question both in terms of this course and in general is "Am I a functional programmer?"

title: Eclipse Error
post_text:
You can run two things: a main method or tests. For the tests: right click on a test -> run as -> JUnit test. To run a main method right click on a class with a main method -> run as -> scala app

A class with a main method is any class with a method with the signature:
def main(args: Array[String]) { ... }
and that's where the execution starts.

You probably have a main method but it does not compile (the first message you wrote says that), so you don't really have a main method (it's wroken) and scala doesn't have where to start the execution.

Compile it in sbt or see errors in window -> show view -> problems and tell us what are the build problems you have.

title: On Windows 7 I get a "Connection timed out" error when running sbt
post_text:
This is either happening
1) because you're behind a corporate firewall or
2) JVM is using IPv6 by default to connect online.
1) can be solved by defining correct proxy settings.
2) can be solved by giving -Djava.net.preferIPv4Stack=true in your JAVA_OPTS/SBT_OPTS environment variable.

title: sbt offline mode?
post_text: If you need to access the Internet through a proxy, you should set the JAVA_OPTS environment variable. See: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/13803459/how-to-use-sbt-from-behind-proxy

title: Test Case: Var value is stored across cases
post_text:
Hello,

I do agree with both Bret and Sebastian, try not to use var. However, you can use val, which provides a handy shortcut for long expressions, as it has been demonstrated in the lessons.

From what you are describing, I think you are trying to think of a way to store intermediate results. This is not exactly the correct approach, but quite close : those intermediate results need to be passed through the recursion, somehow. To design a nice max function, I would recommend getting inspiration from the tail-recursive version of factorial which is described in lecture 1.7 .

Hope this helps :)

title: Why does @tailrec fail when calling a different function?
post_text:
A slide in the tail recursion video states: "In general, if the last action of a function consists of calling a function (which may be the same), one stack frame would be sufficient for both functions. Such calls are called tail calls."

Why "in general" would it not? If the function called "may NOT be the same", or if the function is a higher order function? I'm thinking Scala doesn't currently support tail calls when calling a different function. I ask for the following reason...

For one of the assignments I have a function which called itself twice, adding the results of both calls

mylocalunc(somearg) + mylocalfunc(otherarg)

I wanted to make it tail recursive, so I did this in an else statement which is the final statement in the local function.

mycombiningfunc(mylocalfunc, somearg, otherarg)

def mycombiningfunc(passedfunc: (argtype) => myreturntype,
                    somearg: argtype, otherarg: argtype): returntype = {
  passedfunc(somearg) + passedfunc(otherarg) 
}

It all compiles and passes all tests; however, when I annotate the calling function with @tailrec I get an error "could not optimize @tailrec annotated method mylocalfunc: it contains a recursive call not in tail position."

Perhaps the error message is misleading. It's in tail position, but it's not really a recursive call; at least, not directly. mylocalfunc does call itself, but only after one layer of indirection.

So, I'm thinking if there's nothing to be gained by the refactoring I should roll it back to the original direct double-call (which of course also fails @tailrec because the addition is the last expression evaluated.) Otherwise I'm thinking I may lose points on style.

Does it make sense for the compiler to detect the recursion in mycombiningfunc and try to optimize it? If so, is there any idea of when that might make it in?

I apologize if this is a naive question. I'm just a CRUD programmer; not a strong background in math or computer science.

title: A minor style question
post_text:
Is it preferred Scala style to do this

if (mylist.head == X) A
else if (mylist.head == Y) B

or this

val myval = mylist.head
if (myval == X) A
else if (myval == Y) B

I would think head is not expensive since it's used so often in pattern matching, so it wouldn't be worth creating the temporary variable in this case. Then again, something in me rebels at calling a method multiple times for the same value...

title: A minor style question
post_text: I would go with you first example, it seems to me to be clearer. The second example, I would wonder why the value was created, maybe used farther down in the function. Also I wouldn't worry two much about the efficiency of the head function, I would guess that it's a constant time dereferance.

title: Why does @tailrec fail when calling a different function?
post_text:
There is no way to transform a doubly recursive function (a function that calls itself twice with different parameters) into a tail recursive function. No amount of refactoring can change that.

Essentially, tail recursion optimisation transforms recursion into a loop, so you can evaluate the function in constant stack space. But with doubly recursive function, you need to go down at least one branch (it would still be possible to loop on the other branch).

It is sometimes possible to change the algorithm to avoid the double recursion entirely. For instance, Fibonacci numbers can be computed with a loop. I guess in your case you are computing Pascal triangle numbers; I did it without recursion. But a compiler optimizer is usually not able to come up with such "creative" rewriting.

title: sbt & console seem to re-install
post_text:
sbt usually doesn't download things twice, if they are already in your local repository, ie they have already been downloaded for another project.

it does, however, re-resolve all dependencies for the new project, checks for the used scala version, compiles the compiler interface if necessary etc.
this is all completely normal.

title: A minor style question
post_text:
It depends on the number of conditions. In this example, you introduce a third line of code for only 2 lines of code. The 2 lines form appears lighter to me.
As the number of conditions grows, the additional line has less impact and avoid more duplications than it introduces new code. I would then choose $$h$$ as the name of the variable.

title: A minor style question
post_text:
As quoted in the lectures: "Premature optimization is the source of all evil" - Donald Knuth

I would go with the first option, clarity wins. I have the same reaction anyway, just learnt to control it :P A general comment: don't try to be smarter than the compiler/runtime you are using, they take care of ALL basic and intermediate optimizations (some really advanced sometimes too)

title: example not working
post_text:
Okay so the first couple of lines of that file looks like this. I honestly do not know where you mean by the second line and where it could be.  

#!/usr/bin/env bash

realpath () {
(
  TARGET_FILE=$1

  cd $(dirname $TARGET_FILE)
  TARGET_FILE=$(basename $TARGET_FILE)

  COUNT=0
  while [ -L "$TARGET_FILE" -a $COUNT -lt 100 ]
  do
      TARGET_FILE=$(readlink $TARGET_FILE)
      cd $(dirname $TARGET_FILE)
      TARGET_FILE=$(basename $TARGET_FILE)
      COUNT=$(($COUNT + 1))
  done

  echo $(pwd -P)/$TARGET_FILE
)
}

By my intuition I added the JAVA_HOME = ... on this line.  I have change the text a of that line so that you can see where my put my change clearly:


#!/usr/bin/env bash

realpath () {
(
  TARGET_FILE=$1
  JAVA_HOME=$(/usr/libexec/java_home -v 1.7)

  cd $(dirname $TARGET_FILE)
  TARGET_FILE=$(basename $TARGET_FILE)

  COUNT=0
  while [ -L "$TARGET_FILE" -a $COUNT -lt 100 ]
  do
      TARGET_FILE=$(readlink $TARGET_FILE)
      cd $(dirname $TARGET_FILE)
      TARGET_FILE=$(basename $TARGET_FILE)
      COUNT=$(($COUNT + 1))
  done

  echo $(pwd -P)/$TARGET_FILE
)
}

Is that where the second line is?

title: sbt console error due to AnnotatedElement.class is broken, can someone help?

Hi Lee,

Your screen capture shows that you are using JDK 8, but there is a problem.

Please use JDK 6 or 7 to proceed with this course. Because most recent version of sbt still has not supported JDK 8, you need to use JDK 6 or 7 for sbt.

Of course, you have to install JDK 6 or JDK 7. Please run those commands in your Terminal. 

$ /usr/libexec/java_home -v 1.6
/System/Library/Java/JavaVirtualMachines/1.6.0.jdk/Contents/Home
**$ /usr/libexec/java_home -v 1.7**
/Library/Java/JavaVirtualMachines/jdk1.7.0_67.jdk/Contents/Home

If you get results like above, it is just okay. If your result is like below, JDK 6 or JDK 7 is not installed.

$ /usr/libexec/java_home -v 1.6
Unable to find any JVMs matching version "1.6".
/Library/Java/JavaVirtualMachines/jdk1.8.0_20.jdk/Contents/Home
$ /usr/libexec/java_home -v 1.7
Unable to find any JVMs matching version "1.7".
/Library/Java/JavaVirtualMachines/jdk1.8.0_20.jdk/Contents/Home

Then you have to install JDK 6 or 7. I recommend JDK 7. Please visit this link and get and install JDK 1.7 on your OS X.

BUT there are few steps to do something more. Please refer to this link. Brobbey had same problem on OS X. Posts in this thread are for sbt installed by Homebrew or manually by unpacking sbt*.tar.gz. If you installed sbt using MacPorts, you need to edit /opt/local/bin/sbt script, quite easy even though if you don't know bash script well.

title: Example project not compatable with jdk 8 and scala 2.11
post_text: The problem is that sbt itself does not support JDK 8 yet. Its development team has been testing for 8 but not finished yet. So right now there is no way using JDK 8 with sbt.

title: SortCoins
post_text: Yeah, you really don't need to do a sort, I think, unless the grader tries to pass in a collection of coin denominations that has dups in it.  Even then, you don't need a sorter - just a deduper.  There's a fairly simple and straightforward solution to the basic change maker function with no sorting.

title: How to disable cross-compile error btw 2.11 and 2.10?
post_text:
You should go to Window->Preferences, then choose from the left menu Scala->Compiler. Go to Build Manager tab and uncheck withVersionClasspathValidator property.
Also you should check with the sbt if the project compiles successfully. If so, you can safely uncheck the compatability check.

title: Lecture 1.4 quiz gives incorrect "incorrect" when my answer is correct
post_text: You need to the write function signature also.. Notice second parameter should be pass by name to make this function work as a short circuit evaluator in the case of or(true, loop), where loop is non terminating.

title: Lecture 1.7 alternative tail recursive rewrite of factorial function
Best way to keep track of recursion progress
Lecture 1.7 alternative tail recursive rewrite of factorial function
post_text:
This works for the first call, but fails if you use the function again.
Having var m =1 outside of the function means you are having a side effect in a function which is something functional programming frowns upon.

See http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Functional_programming
 Eliminating side effects, i.e. changes in state that do not depend on the function inputs, can make it much easier to understand and predict the behavior of a program, which is one of the key motivations for the development of functional programming.

So it  works, but is very bad design as it gives no advantages, but has the disadvantage of making the function not threadsafe and more complex to use - if you want to reuse it.

title: Does Scala leverge mutliple CPU's for parallelism
post_text:
I'll give it a try. There are two questions in your question:

  1. Are thread spawned automatically by scala when possible ?
  2. How many CPUs are used to run my program ?

 1 ] As for the number of CPU used, The allocation of CPU's is up to the operating system.
http://stackoverflow.com/questions/10392800/how-does-pthread-implemented-in-linux-kernel-3-2

When a process creates a new thread, It just performs a system call to notify the system " Well dude I have created a child process of [this] process, and they happen to share heap, you can run them independently". And then it might use other system calls ( hidden in mutexes and semaphores ) to keep shared data synchronized.

The operating system, on his side, may have many other processes running with many level of priority.

Note: The process running, as far as the operating system is concerned, is the java virtual machine, not your program. Which may aslo impact the number of thread actually spawned to the system. But I do not know at all the JVM internals.

2] Scala spawning

val numbers = List(1,2,3)
numbers.map((i: Int) => i * 2)

Here the computation for each number can be done independently. The question is will Scala automatically spawn thread for that ? Or maybe for a longer list ? Well I have no idea. But it would be possible as those computation are "obviously independent". In the present case, you may have to explicitely use parrallel collections:

http://docs.scala-lang.org/overviews/parallel-collections/concrete-parallel-collections.html

In fact even the cpu itself is likely to try to parallelize instructions. I'm not sure about the jvm. FP makes it easier to implement automatic parallelization at compiler level.
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Automatic_parallelization

title: Is it possible to write a tail recursive Pascal Triangle?
post_text:
i wasn't able to find a way to write the function in a way that is tail recursive.
I was wondering if it is possible. More in general, is it always possible to convert a recursive function to a tail recursive function?
If not, is there a set of rules to determine when a tail recursive version is obtainable?

thanks

title: Is it possible to write a tail recursive Pascal Triangle?
post_text:
def pascal(c: Int, r: Int): Int = {
    def pascaltailrec(acc:Int, c: Int, r: Int): Int = {
      if (c == 0 || c == r) acc + 1 
      else pascaltailrec(pascaltailrec(acc , c - 1, r - 1), c, r - 1)
    }  
    pascaltailrec(0, c, r)
  }

title: Does Scala leverge mutliple CPU's for parallelism
post_text:
Once the threads are created it's upto the OS scheduler to schedule and if there is nothing else going on the OS will schedule the threads. But the question is whether Scala will create the threads. If it does create threads, how is the work partitioned. 

I am guessing it will, otherwise there is not point in writing code that lends itself to parallelism.

title: Description of the Counting Change Algorithm
post_text:
You are given a natural number $$m$$ (= money) and a list $$c_1, c_2, \ldots, c_n$$ of positive integers. (= the list of coin types you have.)

The Question: What is the number of possible lists (of natural numbers) $$x_1, x_2, \ldots, x_n$$ which satisfy the equation $$ m = c_1 x_1 + c_2 x_2 + \ldots + c_n x_n $$.

Example: For $$m = 4$$, $$c_1=1$$ and $$c_2=2$$ the possible solutions are:

  1. $$x_1 = 0$$, $$x_2=2$$
  2. $$x_1 = 2$$, $$x_2=1$$
  3. $$x_1 = 4$$, $$x_2=0$$

In what sense is this formulation better?
It is less confusing and makes it clear what you should do for the cases $$m=0$$ and $$n=0$$.

In what sense is this formulation worse?
It makes the problem sound uninteresting.

title: Eclipse: File > New > No Applicable Items
post_text:
Background:
I'm on OS X Mavericks.
I had Eclipse installed for Java because we use that at work.
I'm a SQL guy and haven't written a line of Java in my life.

Steps:
1. Install the JDK
I already had 1.6 installed.

2. Install sbt
I took the homebrew path. Installed Homebrew. It requested to install Xcode developer command line tools, so I did. Everything went smoothly. sbt -h works nice.

3. Install Scala IDE for Eclipse
