title: TweetReader performance issue
post_text: As a small hint, consider what part of the union() function is the most expensive one. If you figure that out, then consider if you can find a way to apply that expensive part on the smallest tree possible, which greatly reduces its cost.

title: TweetReader performance issue
post_text:
If you are forming the union of left and right in your recursive union definition, as I think was suggested in one of the videos, this results in a lot of unneeded new structure and more calls, and fails in my view to utilize the recursive tree structure. A rewritten union that:

  1. Sees if it should add this's element to other.
  2. Takes the union of the left subtree with the result of 1, and
  3. Takes the union of the right subtree with the result of 2.

Is I think the way to go, and feels more natural: We traverse the this tree, adding elements to that as we move along.

I don't know if that is related to the TweetReader problems or not, but it would not surprise me at all if this were the bottleneck (especially if your current implementation takes the union of the rest of the tree and only at the very end tries to include the current node element, as that essentially isn't tail-recursive).

title: Lecture 3.1 - are there other implementations of union
post_text:
In my view that is not a good implementation of union, it creates a ton of unnecessary structures with every "left union right", and having the incl at the end kinda messes up with tail recursion in my view. I think the best way is to add elements from this to other as you recurse down the this tree. This way you have a solid terminating condition: The first half of the union gets smaller very fast. And it is more in line with the way one usually recurses down trees, namely:

"Do something with the current element, then do something with the left subtree, then something with the right subtree"

Here's the way I think the recursive call should go:

  1. See if you should add this's element to other.
  2. Take the union of the left subtree with the result of 1, and
  3. Take the union of the right subtree with the result of 2.

title: different behaviour, lecture 2.2, 4:10 - 4:30
post_text:
sumFunctionFromToMPS(identity) _                //> res35: (Int, Int) => Int = <function2>

The question was, if sumFunctionFromTo and sumFunctionFromToMPS are really equal when there is different behaviour in IDE.

title: different behaviour, lecture 2.2, 4:10 - 4:30
post_text:
Depends on the definition of the equivalence. They are the same, except for the case when the call does not have an expected type. Then you need an additional `_` to make it work, but this is only syntactic and will not change the behavior of the program. For example, this works: `val x: (Int, Int) => Int = sumFunctionFromToMPS(x => x)`

Behaviorally they are completely the same.

title: Lecture 2.3 1:25 - 2:30
post_text:
Problem: There is a typo or other mistake on the page (e.g., factual error, information omitted)

Problem ID: pages-mistake

URL: https://class.coursera.org/progfun-005/lecture


Browser: Firefox 32
OS: Ubuntu


Additional details:
There is a mistake in the function   isCloseEnough :

val tolerance = 0.0001                          //> tolerance  : Double = 1.0E-4
  def abs(x: Double): Double = if (x < 0) -x else x
                                                  //> abs: (x: Double)Double
  def isCloseEnough(x: Double, y: Double): Boolean = abs((x - y) / x) / x < tolerance
                                                  //> isCloseEnough: (x: Double, y: Double)Boolean
 
  def fixedPoint(f: Double => Double)(firstGues: Double) = {
    def iterate(gues: Double): Double = {
      val next = f(gues)
      if (isCloseEnough(gues, next)) next
      else iterate(next)
    }
    iterate(firstGues)
  }                                               //> fixedPoint: (f: Double => Double)(firstGues: Double)Double
  fixedPoint(x => 1 + x / 2)(1)                   //> res0: Double = 1.999755859375
 
  fixedPoint(x => -1 - x / 2)(1)                  //> res1: Double = -0.25 ERROR


The right version is:
def isCloseEnough(x: Double, y: Double): Boolean = abs((x - y) / x) < tolerance
and then
  fixedPoint(x => 1 + x / 2)(1)                   //> res0: Double = 1.9998779296875
 
  fixedPoint(x => -1 - x / 2)(1)                  //> res1: Double = -0.6666793823242188

title: countChange what's wrong with my logic
post_text:
I know there is something wrong, but I am not sure what's the exact problem with this logic. Please help me to identify the flaw in my logic of this implementation : 

  def countChange(money: Int, coins: List[Int]) = {

    def nCountChange(money: Int, coins: List[Int], sum: Int): Int = 
      if (sum == money) 1 /* we just found a way */
      else if (sum > money) 0 /* sum of coins exceeded money, so no way */     
      else if (coins.isEmpty) 0 /* we have used all the coins, so no way */
      else nCountChange(money, coins, sum+coins.head) + nCountChange(money, coins.tail, sum+coins.tail.head)

title: Late Signature Track
post_text:
On https://class.coursera.org/progfun-005/assignment, it tells me:

"Assignments are authenticated overall if at least half of the submitted, non-optional assignment parts are authenticated. The authentication status for each part is the authentication status of the attempt counted as the effective score."

So I guess you won't have to re-submit your previous assignments if you join now and always authenticate your assignments from now on.

title: Style Checker
post_text:
Hi Satya,
(if (c) e1 else e2) is an expression in Scala, much like (_?_:_) in C. It returns e1 when c is true and e2 when it is false. So try using this structure instead of the statement style with the return keyword.

title: Lecture 2.2: Currying
post_text:
Hi Ivan, 
I'm not sure what you mean by "can't extract the function". sum(0) is indeed a function. To see what our does, substitute 0 for a in the implementation of sum. 
The separate syntax for currying can be seen as a weakness of the language, but it is necessary because Scala allows methods with the same name but different number of arguments. 
def sum(a:Int) = ... 
def sum(a:Int, b:Int) = ...
So is sum(0) now the first function or the second one, partially applied?

title: Lecture 3.1 - Implementation of the memory image of persistent data structures
post_text:
Hi Dan, 
Good observation. The compiler might apply some optimization in such cases, but the important thing is that Scala uses garbage collection: the old parts of the data structure that are no longer needed (and not visible from anywhere in the program) will be deallocated from memory be the garbage collector.

title: A simple way to express invariants (Lecture 2.6)
post_text:
I had already seen the use of "assert" in the assignments' test files, and also knew it was possible to use it inside methods. It was a good surprise to see that there is also a "require" in Scala for expressing and checking preconditions on the parameters of a class. Nevertheless, next I had hoped to see also the possibility to check "invariants" on internal "mutable variables" of a class (meaning, a boolean expression that shall always be true at the beginning and at the end of each method).

Side note: What we call "values", I suppose, can be seen as constants (haven't discussed mutable vars yet in the lectures before 2.6, if I am right?).

One possibility could be to include explicitly an assert at the beginning/end of each method with the desired invariant to be checked. But that would be too heavy and repetitive.

My question is: Is it possible to express this kind of conditions in Scala? Any simpler way than the proposition mentioned before?

title: Lecture 2.7 Presidence Example
post_text:
In the lecture, the question was asked where should parentheses be placed in the expression:
a + b ^? c ?^ d less a ==> b | c
so that the result doesn't change.

The solution given was:
((a + b) ^? (c ?^ d)) less ((a ==> b) | c)

But that would put the evaluation of (a + b) ahead of the operation (b ^? (c ?^ d)) which doesn't make sense to me.  I think the solution is instead:
(a + (b ^? (c ?^ d))) less ((a ==> b) | c)

Can anyone explain why (a + b) is evaluated before the operation (b ^? (c ?^ d))
?

title: Lecture 2.1 What exactly does => operator mean?
post_text:
from the video lectures, it looks like it depends on the context. 
I've seen it used in 2 different contexts.
1. def do_something (x: Int, y: => Int) = function_body
In this case, it means that you want to be passed by name as opposed to pass by value.

2. def sum(f: Int => Int, a:int) = function_body
In this case,   Int => Int   is the type of the function f (it means that function f takes an Integer and returns an Integer). and f is a parameter for the function "sum". 
i believe Lecture 1.3(Evaluation Strategies and termination) and 2.1(higher order functions) respectively have these 2 cases. I don't know about any other one. 
That's all I know so far.
 hope this helps!

title: Lecture 2.1 What exactly does => operator mean?
post_text:
Hi, Mark.  There are a couple of different uses here.  For one, perhaps it would help to think of it as a shorthand way to write a function.  In C, we might write something like
int square(int n) { return n * n; }
But, imagine there was a less cluttered way to write the same thing:
n => n * n
But, there's another use of =>, which delays the evaluation of arguments to a function.  I'm not sure which usage you mean.

title: A simple way to express invariants (Lecture 2.6)
post_text:
Hi, Wendi.  Great question.  Scala has an "ensuring" construct that helps with invariants.  It works something like this...
{ Some expression here } ensuring ( some predicate here )
So, suppose you had a min function that returned the minimum of a and b, you might try writing something like this
{ min(3,4) } ensuring ( _ < 4 )
Admittedly, this is a rather silly example.

title: Lecture 2.7 Presidence Example
post_text:
"^" isn't the operator in the example, "^?" is the operator.

According to the precedence rules:
(all letters)
|
^
&
< >
= !
:
+ -
* / %
(all other special characters)
"^?" has a higher precedence because it's a special character.   Parentheses were around the (c ?^ d) operation first because of this.

title: Week 2 Assignment Explanation
post_text:
Perhaps read the instructions again, taking note that for this assignment the type Set  is defined as a function taking an Int value and returning a Boolean. ie. it's a functional set (which can be infinite in size) not a concrete collection of values.

Yes, it could be even numbers, odd numbers, prime numbers because in those cases you can think of a function that would test an Int for inclusion in the functional set. No, it can't be complex or irrational numbers in this particular assignment but you could extend the idea of a functional set to cover those domains.

title: Lecture 3.3 - Why a special Class for Nil?
post_text:
Why would one bother to create the class Nil[T] as a marker for the end of list?  I'm wondering if it would be possible to implement the list in terms of just Cons that can contain null values.

traits List[T] { ... }
class Cons[T](val head:T, val tail:List[T]) extends List[T] {t
  require (tail == null || head != null)
  def isEmpty = (head == null)
}

title: Lecture 3.3 - Why a special Class for Nil?
post_text:
What if "null" is not a valid value for the type T? There is something nice in the certainty that if you have a Cons cell, then its head is an actual object of the type you want, and not "null" whatever null means. The mere existence of null as a possible value is problematic in many ways (and convenient in other ways), but let's not go there.

This way there is a very clear separation between a list that has no elements, and one that has at least one element. From an object-oriented point of view, almost all methods you would write would need to behave differently for the two kinds of lists. With your approach, you would have to have every single method do a check to see if it is "empty" or not, and behave accordingly. That's not taking advantage of subclassing.

Perhaps neither of those arguments would convince you, but at least they're food for thought.

And how about TweetSets, can't we do the same thing there and get rid of Empty? And let me turn the question around, why would you want to try to treat empty lists and non-empty lists the same, when they behave very differently?

title: Lecture 3.3 - Why a special Class for Nil?
post_text: If you wanted to allow head to be null, then you would have to constrain T to be a subtype of AnyRef, i.e. you couldn't have a List of anything that extends AnyVal (i.e. primitives).

title: Lecture 2.1 What exactly does => operator mean?
post_text:
Hello Mark,

As mentioned before, the uses we have seen so far are:

1. Indicating a call-by-name evaluation:

def f(x: => T1) : T2 = e

2. Expressing function types:

f : T1 => T2  

3. Writing anonymous functions:

x => e

or

(x : T1) => e
where 'x' and 'f' are identifiers, 'e' is an expression, 'T1' and 'T2' are types.


Watch the Lecture 2.4 (Scala Syntax Summary), it presents these uses of '=>' in Scala.

title: A simple way to express invariants (Lecture 2.6)
post_text:
Hello, Morgan. Thank you very much for your comment. This sure is something I would like to try and will search for more information about it. It may be very helpful when testing more complex programs!

(And hey, I would not call it "silly", just "simple" ;-) )

Thanks again!

title: union of sets
post_text:
Srikanth,

For the second assignment, we are defining sets by their "characteristic functions", it means that we define what it means for an element 'x' to be in a set 's' given a predicate 'p' that "characterises" all the elements in 's'. It's a mathematical (set theory) way of thinking about sets. For instance, we can express infinite sets using these notation. For example, in your tests, you are be able to manipulate "the set of all negative integers" or "the set of all even numbers", which in practice we can't do in a computer (that's why we are using the 'bound' so we restrict some of the functions to a subset of all the integers).

In the case of the 'union' operator, just think what it means for a given element 'x' to be a member of 'union(s,t)'. The same for the rest of the exercises!

title: Comment for map function is (slightly) inaccurate?
post_text: Alex, the comment for the 'map' operation in the second assignment is actually correct and we do not need to think of bounded sets to implement it. Think in a mathematical way what it means for an element 'x' to be in 'map(s,f)', in terms of the quantifiers defined before ('exists' or 'forall'). Write it down, use pen and paper, and it will be much easier to understand.

I think there is a simplier way than the presented one. I wrote:
def generalStuff(function: (Int, Int) => Int)(number1: Int, number2: Int): Int = {
  if (number1 != number2) function(number2, generalStuff(function)(number1, number2 - 1))
  else number2
}

generalStuff((x, y) => x * y)(0, 4)
It assume that number1 is lesser or equal than number2, but it don't take as much parameters as the presented one.

title: Lecture 2.6/2.7 How to subtract to 0 alongside require condition.
post_text:
Is there a downside to just wrapping gcd in abs()?   I haven't been able to find an example that breaks it, but I'm not interested in thinking too hard about the math.  :P

private def gcd(a: Int, b: Int): Int = if (b == 0) a else gcd(b, a % b)
private val g = abs(gcd(x, y))
def numer = x / g
def denom = y / g

title: Comment for map function is (slightly) inaccurate?
post_text:
I agree, a clear comment for that function would have been:

Returns a set transformed by applying `f` to each bounded integer within `s`

instead of just:

Returns a set transformed by applying `f` to each element of `s`

which is misleading, since comments for the forall and the exist functions DO specify that "detail", just like the assignment does.

title: How much did you score on Assignment 1 ?
post_text:
Well, in my opinion, if you are using google to look for answers to any of the assignments, then you are in violation of the Coursera Honor Code.

As far as I see, the objective of taking this course is to learn the functional way of thinking, and the best way to do that is to *think* about the problem (as long as the time permits, or the problem is solved). By getting the exact solutions to the assignment problems from google, the learning experience is vastly degraded.

When you are stuck with an assignment, just go to the discussion forums. They have enough hints to solve the problem. Google should not be an used as an option to solve the assignment problems.

Regards.

Create a .bat file which will startup a command line and where you add the path to the old scala / java folders in front of the environment/system variables => only that command line will be impacted with old libs.

I do have more issues with the mathematical stuff in the assignments ... that has been more then 14 years since I saw those things.

title: Lecture 3.1 - are there other implementations of union
post_text:
The union method still works if the terms are re-ordered as Randall suggests. The resulting set has a different tree structure but contains the same elements, as it should. The "incl" call has to be at the end though, since otherwise the recursion doesn't terminate because there is always a non-empty set on the left-hand side of one of the "union" calls.

In general I don't like code that seems to work by magic: it should be clear when reading a function what it does and how it works, since otherwise it is hard to be sure that it does work. It took me a long time to convince myself that the suggested implementation is correct, but then I am quite new to functional programming. To a seasoned functional programmer is probably a clear and intuitive solution. Certainly unravelling tricks like this is a good way to develop a deeper understanding. If you step through a few examples on paper you can see how it ends up breaking down the original tree structure and then adding terms back one at a time with "incl".

title: Lecture 3.1 why incl should be a last call in union? Is there some rule?
post_text:
The general rule could be stated like "the value you apply recursion on should converge towards the base of the recursion". 
What your solution does is call union on other.incl(elem), which in turn calls union on right.incl(<something>)... etc. This way, you will never reach the base case, which is the empty set. 
Hope that helps.

title: problem with filterAcc. How can use acc to accumulate the object in the tree?
post_text: Acc only contains the result, you are traversing this, so recursion will terminate because on each iteration you have smaller branches to traverse. Think about what would be a new Acc for left and right, and what do you do with filtered sub-branches.

title: union of sets
post_text:
Just adding to the above you cannot actually "access" the elements of a set defined this way. You can only test if an element belongs to a set. So you need to define union etc. in those terms.
(This is a weakness that will be alleviated in the next exercise.)

title: Tail Call Optimization?
post_text:
So if I wrote a factorial code this way with BigInt.

import scala.annotation.tailrec

object ScalaFactorial {

    def main(args: Array[String]) {
        println(args(0) + "! = " + factorial(1, BigInt(args(0)))) 
    }

    @tailrec
    def factorial(accumulator: BigInt, number: BigInt): BigInt = {
    	if (number == 0) accumulator
        else factorial(number * accumulator, number - 1)                                   
    }                            
}
The resulting assembly code looks pretty optimized compared to a Java version I tried out (which gives a StackOverFlow if a very large value is passed - say 10000).

javap -c ScalaFactorial
Compiled from "ScalaFactorial.scala"
public final class ScalaFactorial {
  public static scala.math.BigInt factorial(scala.math.BigInt, scala.math.BigInt);
    Code:
       0: getstatic     #16                 // Field ScalaFactorial$.MODULE$:LScalaFactorial$;
       3: aload_0       
       4: aload_1       
       5: invokevirtual #18                 // Method ScalaFactorial$.factorial:(Lscala/math/BigInt;Lscala/math/BigInt;)Lscala/math/BigInt;
       8: areturn       

  public static void main(java.lang.String[]);
    Code:
       0: getstatic     #16                 // Field ScalaFactorial$.MODULE$:LScalaFactorial$;
       3: aload_0       
       4: invokevirtual #22                 // Method ScalaFactorial$.main:([Ljava/lang/String;)V
       7: return        
}


Can anyone confirm how the recursion is treated in this case? The "invokevirtual" is a method call but I believe a new stack frame is not created in Scala (which would cause overflow if implement in Java).

title: Allowed changes in code of assignments
post_text:
Hi Ivan,

you can come up with new helper methods like myList#isEmpty. But changing function / method SIGNATURES (class => object or changing the return type or the like) is not allowed, the grader will check that in most cases and penalizes. My guess: an automated grading is much more complicated if the given signatures are allowed to change. Usually assignment can be done just using the given "ecosystem", maybe not in the most elegant way possible BUT the goal of the assignment (=what was intended for you to learn and implement) is ensured. Does that help any?

title: made additional inverse function
post_text:
That's probably not the way to do it... I did it with a one-liner using one of the functions from earlier in the assignment. (hint: you use forall to write exists, you use exists to write map)

It was actually really hard for me to reason about map at first; the way I was able to understand it eventually was just by stepping back and looking at the types and making them fit in a way that makes the most sense. map returns a Set, exists returns a Boolean... therefore, an anonymous function that passes an Int to exists somehow would have the return type of Set.

Having said that, I'd be curious to hear more about your approach if you got it working.

title: How to start writing code in functional style?
post_text:
Hi lads,

I have a good experience as a software developer. C# and Java were my favourite languages for a long period. Now I'm amused with Nemerle and Scala.

Funny, but I found myself unable to switch from imperative style coding to writing good code in functional manner. It's really disappointing. Whenever I'm touching a new task, I spend HUUUUUGE time looking for a clue about the solution. Solving the problem in imperative way with slighly different syntax is boring, silly and often inefficient (in terms of my potential productivity or program performance).

Recently I've got an idea. To write in functional style, you need to think the way mathematicians do. Why? Because this is what Scala and other functional languages allow you to express easily while writing a program. Then, the question is how do mathematicians think, right?

Do you solve most of the tasks top-to-bottom using the divide'n'conquer approach? Or may be you prefer thinking about the atomic, edge cases first and then grow your solution by combining them as building blocks?

Please, let me know what are your best practices!

Thank you!
-Igor

title: How to start writing code in functional style?
post_text:
I'm having the same problem: its hard to change your thinking from the imperative to the functional.  I'm finding that identifying the edge cases then building from there has been successful for me.

I've a vague feeling (not having completed the course yet) that there are some functional patterns that can be re-used once you master them rather than painfully figuring them out from scratch like we are now.

title: How to start writing code in functional style?
post_text:
There is one great course https://www.coursera.org/course/programdesign
One thing I learnt there: You should write test cases before your code.
When writing test cases, you start from the base case, the boundary condition, the very trivial cases.
Then you write next test case, which could be solved by 1 step further from the base case.
With a few increasingly more complex cases, you should know how recursion works.

By the way, that courses also uses many "function recipes", which are common recursion templates.
With the help of template, you could write recursion functions quickly,  even without thinking of how recursion works.
Although not said explicitly, that course actually teaches a style of functional programming.

title: How to start writing code in functional style?
post_text:
For those of us who aren't mathematicians, perhaps functional programming can be described as an emphasis on problem structure. While imperative code deals with structure it somehow always ends up obscuring it under great drifts of procedural frass - at least mine does.

I have the imperative approach (C, C++, Java etc) burnt into my frontal cortex from many years of coding. I first met Scala two years ago (via this course) and loved it immediately, but find I frequently slip into procedural coding unthinkingly. But some aspects took root very quickly such as first class functions, filtering and transforming collections, and the power of pattern matching.

title: Lecture 3.1 - Implementation of the memory image of persistent data structures
post_text:
Scala does support mutable objects (keeping vars instead of vals), but if you program pure object oriented and never take advantage of the functional expressiveness, then what's the point?

Here's a good read btw - http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Persistent_data_structure
Stamping the data structure sounds like a neat trick, although it still takes space to maintain the stamps.

title: Why Pattern Matching is bad?
post_text:
I don't know if it is not elegant or "functional enough".
In the OOP paradigm I think that this is a code smell because you are asking for the type of an object, when normally what you must do is to delegate this behavior to the object. What happens if I create a new class? Or what happens if instead of an "Empty" class, I create an null object? In those cases, I would need to modify the code in the pattern matching.

title: Problem found in TweetSetSuite.scala
post_text:
The size returned from the test case ("filter: a on set5") should be 3 not 1.
set5 contains element a, b, c and d. With this filter, the resulting set will contain element b,c and d. So the size should become 3 and not 1.

title: union of sets
post_text:
Here's my 5 mins:
1. What is an union of 2 sets? ===> it's a Set
2. What does a functional set take as argument in your code? ===> look at the provided code
3. What is the mathematical requirement for a number x to be in the union of two sets? ===> from wikipedia:
" The union of two sets A and B is the collection of points which are in A or in B or in both A and B. In symbols,
"
4. How do you translate "x is in something/ x belongs to something / something has x / something contains x" into code? ===> look at the provided code
5. Good luck!

Instead of getting {2, 3, 4} as the result of the function call I got back {0, 1, 2}. Similar tests indicate that rather than applying the test function to the argument set it seems that my map function returns the set that would give the orignal argument set if the function was applied to it. Can anyone give me a hint as to what I might be doing to cause this?

Tony

title: How to start writing code in functional style?
post_text:
For now, I'd say the basic thing is to think in terms of recursion instead of loops. Instead of asking yourself "how should I iteratively mutate this value", ask "how can I express the solution for the problem in terms of the recursive solution to a simpler problem".

But since one of the advantages of functional programming is that it offers general solutions, as you advance it will become more like "how can I combine these powerful abstract library functions to solve my concrete problem".

title: How to start writing code in functional style?
post_text:
I suffer from the same problem as the OP and so far what I've noticed is that to solve problems in functional style we have to define our problem very precisely, we have to find the most simple definition of the problem which work for all the cases all the time.

Once we have this definition we don't need anything else in mind at all, no state: we don't need to picture the state of our program in our head (and we should not try as mentally imagining recursion is quite difficult).

In fact we need to think like recursion does: we start as if it was the first time every time and we don't need to store things in our head for later use, there is just now because if our definition is accurate, it was also true in the past and it will stay true in the future.

There is a nice example of this kind of way of thinking in the second week assignment on the implementation of the map() function which is just the literal translation in Scala of the definition of the problem of returning a new set of numbers transformed by a function f "X is part of map(Set, f) if there exist an Int in Set such as f(Int) = X"

So I think that the important thing is to build little "truths" we can then use as bricks knowing that truths are immutable we can rely on them without a second thought. It's similar to OO programming where we have objects which we know do there job and we don't need to have any knowledge of their entrails or state to use them...

It's just about freeing our mind^^

This is what I think now but this is still a work in progress...

title: TweetReader.allTweets never terminates

title: How to start writing code in functional style?
post_text:
One thing that i find useful when trying to adopt the functional way of thinking is to think in terms of "declaring the solution".
Meaning: solutions in functional style tend to be more "declarative" in nature, in the sense that the developer declares his intent, and lets the compiler do the rest of the actual program construction.

The classical example of a (relatively) declarative style programming is SQL. In a way, SQL queries are functional programming kind of programs ('select' clause is actually map, aggregate functions are reduce functions, 'where' clause is filter, etc.).

To me, this resonates with the mathematical roots of functional programming. Immutability and referential transparency are basically language features that help us to adopt this way of thinking, because they prevent us from thinking about memory locations, references and program counters (as in imperative style).

So in short - think "declarative", it usually works for me :-)

title: SBT Import failed in Intellij IDEA
post_text:
The easiest way that just works:
  • Unzip
  • Delete .project & .classpath
  • File > Open... Select the unzipped folder
  • Select auto-import
Bonus: explanation for the problem
The problem is that if you just open the project without deleting the eclipse project files, IDEA imports it as an eclipse project. That way paths aren't set correctly. Making IDEA import the sbt settings on top of that probably just makes it worse :) As I wrote above, as long as you delete the eclipse specific files you don't even need to point IDEA to the sbt project file – it will recognize it by itself.

title: filterAcc problem
post_text:
Typically you would pass the accumulator to them, if that makes sense. The way to update state is by passing the new state to your substructures. So add what you need for the current element, then pass it on to the subtrees. One side first, then the other.

I talk about this idea, for a different example though, about halfway through this: https://gist.github.com/skiadas/15f2e6f82b1cb3a41f39

title: Abstract class TweetSet
post_text: Placing left and right methods at the abstract class breaks encapsulation. However, I feel it's fine to add allTweetsLessThan(x: Tweet): TweetSet. This would return left on NonEmpty, or it would be an application of filter() on anything else.

title: Can some one explain Cons and Union
post_text:
The nth.sc example is a chained contructor call. You can think of it like this:
val emptyTail: List[Int] = new Nil //it didn't compile without explicit type
val list_3 = new Cons(3, emptyTail)
val list_2 = new Cons(2, list_3)
val list = new Cons(1, list_2)

The second one can be rewritten as

left.union(right).union(other).incl(elem)
Syntax is explained in one of the lectures

title: Solution - Use JetBrains Idea IDE
post_text:
If you're having trouble with the eclipse scala sdk on windows or linux, you may want to try jetbrains idea instead. Or even the netbeans scala plugin.

The eclipse 64 bit scala sdk works on opensuse 13.1 and windows.
But crashes with outOfMemory exceptions on ubuntu regardless of permsize and maxpermsize settings with oracle java jdk1.7.0_45 and java 8 update 5

After testing the eclipse scala ide on ubuntu 13.10 this morning with many different  settings and many new and imported projects, I am going back to jetbrains and netbeans.

This isn't my only bad experience with eclipse and plugins. Many immature plugin projects for haskell and C/C++ and the Eclipse Modelling Framework have crashed eclipse or slowed it to a crawl.

If you experience this problem, try another development environment or a good editor, and save your sanity.

title: forall and exists
post_text:
Can someone explain what forall and exists functions are suppose to do?  It does not make sense and I do not really understand the documentation for each function means.   I was able to do union and intersection because I understood them mathematically and how they work.  However, I do not understand the mathematical meaning behind forall and exists

bound =1000
forall: def forall(s: Set, p: Int => Boolean): Boolean = {.....}
exisits: def exists(s: Set, p: Int => Boolean): Boolean = {....}

Suppose that I have a set a, b such that 
a ={1,2,4,5,6,10, 34, 50} and b = {1,4,7,9,6,99, 100, 62}
If I were to apply forall to a, what is suppose to happen mathematically?
i.e forall(a),  where bound = 1000  or if the same was applied b?

Similarly what will happen if the same was applied to exists?

title: forall and exists
post_text:
So unless we have the definition of forall and exists, it's hard to answer what exactly they do.
However, we may infer their supposed function by their respective names -

$$forall$$ - perform p on each x in s. I.e., for all x$$∈$$s, compute p(x), and return true in the event...(implementation dependant). This is likely equivalent to the functional concept of map (read more here - http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Map_(higher-order_function)) 

$$exists$$ - perform p on each x in s. I.e., for all x$$∈$$s, compute p(x), and return true in the event...(implementation dependant, but probably here return true if any one application of the function p returns true. In other words, return $$∪$$p($$x_i$$)). That's to say, $$exists$$ likely returns true if some element in $$s$$ satisfies $$p$$.

title: forall and exists
post_text:
Take your two sets a and b.

Suppose you wanted to find out in set a if every element were divisible by two.  You could do forall(a, i:Int = > i % 2 ==0)  it would then return a boolean to indicate whether every element in a is divisible by 2.  This should be false (5 is not divisible by 2)

Exists is like forall, but only indicates if there is at least one element that meets your predicate.   This would return a true if you ran it on set A

title: What About a Paris Meetup ?
post_text:
Hello,

comme je le disais, je suis pas mal pris par le boulot, et j'ai pas de visibilité sur mon planning. Mais si je suis dans le coin, why not! Toutefois, étant donné que je suis loin d'être sûr de pouvoir venir, je peux pas prendre le rôle de réferrant vis-à-vis du lieu. Donc ce serait bien que quelqu'un passe un mercredi soir pour:

  1. demander la permission pour venir faire un « évènement » ;
  2. s'assurer qu'il n'y a pas un autre truc de prévu ce jour-là (le 10-11 ça risque d'être les journées portes ouvertes du lieu)
  3. socialiser avec les « autochtones » et essayer de participer !

Il faut comprendre qu'un hackerspace, c'est ouvert, mais qu'il faut respecter le lieu et les autres personnes qui l'utilisent. Et au dela du simple meetup, des sessions d'approfondissement sur scala, ou des cours avec ceux qui ne font pas le coursera sont toujours le bienvenu dans un hackerspace !

--
Guyzmo

title: forall result for empty set and clause p that always evaluates to false?
post_text:
forall on empty set is meant to always be "vacuously" true. The way I like to reason it is this:

The statement we are trying to determine the truthiness of is: "For every x in the set S, p(x) is true". Now in order for us to demonstrate such a statement to be false, we would need to produce an element in S for which p(x) is false. Since we cannot produce such an element if S is empty, the statement is vacuously true.

"having nothing to check" is a reason for making the statement true, not for making it false.

title: Problem passing a function - syntax question
post_text:
x is defined by the function.  The return  someTypeOrOther may or may not be the same return of the function.

For example from the homework: 
def filter(s: Set, p: Int => Boolean): Set
takes a function(any function) that takes an integer does returns a boolean.  However, filter will return a Set.

Let us define a set with the following:
val oneToTen: Set = i => i > 0 && i <= 10
val p = (i: Int) => i % 3 == 0
val newSet = filter(oneToTen, p)

Here I define a set with a function such that i is between 1 and 10 (inclusive); I then define a function to return a boolean that will return true if the number given it is divisible by three.  A second set is then created that includes all elements from the first Set divisible by 3.

I could have also done:

val newSet = filter(oneToTen, i => i % 3 ==0)

If I wanted to refer to that function within the body of my function, I could simply call

if (p(i)) foo
else bar

or

if (p(5)) foo
else bar



An important note as given in the assignment is that we cannot actually create the Sets, rather we are just giving it parameters, and the program will simply tell us if a particular integer would be in that Set if it were actually created.

title: def or val for constants?
post_text:
The 'val' evaluates when defined, while 'def' on every call.

If you're gonna access the variable a lot of times, the compiler always gonna evaluate the def expression on every call.

As the value of the variable not gonna change, the clever way of declaring is 'val', because the 'overhead' of always evaluating the expression isn't gonna happen.

Ah, and if you think the variable has a low chance of be accessed, you could use 'lazy val'. With lazy val, the expression is evaluated only on the first call.

Of course, the expression is only a simple attribution, the efficiency of the code with both types will be practically the same, but it's good to use the most reasonable and clever ways, to keep that in mind :D

title: def or val for constants?
post_text:
val is completely immutable, very comparable to adding 'final' to a variable in Java.  It is evaluated when defined, and only then.

def is much more like a method in Java, and evaluated every time it is called.  Because Scala is a functional language the line between a method and a variable, or field, is not very distinct.  

For performance, if it is something that will be accessed frequently, and will never change while in scope...make it a val.  If it has a lot of overhead, and may not be accessed you can make it a def (but it will be re-evaluated every time it is called) or as pointed out above, you can use lazy val, where it is evaluated when called, but only evaluated once.

title: forall result for empty set and clause p that always evaluates to false?
post_text:
Yes, I saw this in another thread, but I was reasoning by analogy with continuity on sets of real numbers. Consider the set $$s_\epsilon = (0,\epsilon)$$ (basically an open-ended interval on the real line), and call it `s_eps` (if we had some way of representing it in code). Then, for any $$\epsilon>0$$, the set $$s_\epsilon$$ is non-empty and
forall( s_eps, (x => false))
evaluates to false. However, $$\lim_{\epsilon\rightarrow0}s_{\epsilon} = \emptyset$$ (the empty set), and this makes the evaluation of forall "discontinuous" in the sense that the limit of the value is not the same as the value of the limit. I hope my explanation makes sense.

This said, I understand that putting real numbers and logic together is the root of all evil...After all, real numbers only really exist in the minds of mathematicians ;-)

I accept the answer for now, since it makes the coding assignment easier, but please note the paradox for future reference. -Thanks!

title: Evaluation sequence of function "def contains"
post_text:
Hello!

We have a function in week 2 assignments, called "contains" that returns a Boolean value if the element is contained in the set.

def contains(s: Set, elem: Int): Boolean = s(elem)

If we call the function with (contains(Set(5),4)), how will this function evaluate?

My thoughts:
* At some point (Set(5) == Set(4)) needs to occur, however the function does not have such a statement
* Therefore passed function "Set" is evaluated like a mathematical function?
* Set(x) = x, Set(5) = 5.
* by calling s(4) we are doing the following expression 5 = 4, which is false?

title: is exists() a one-liner or does it still have an iteration?
post_text:
Hi all,

I think am stuck on a syntactical issue or I am not getting this. Lets say our bounds are {1, 2, 3, 4} and our predicate gives a true on either element 1 or 2.

Now if I negate my predicate and supply the set {2, 3, 4} to function forall, then I get a "false" because 3 and 4 are accepted but 2 is not, and thus I can return true for exists else I would return false.

The problem is the signature of forall contains a set and a function, and function is a black box not a boolean variable that can be negated. So how do I get around this, or is this wrong way of approaching this problem?

Thanks.

title: Why is filterAcc defined in TweetSet?
post_text: As defined, filterAcc doesn't understand the difference between NonEmpty and Empty.  Left and right are TweetSets composed of a combination of NonEmpty and Empty, so defining filterAcc on TweetSet allows you to call that method regardless of which concrete TweetSet you encounter.

title: parentheses with extra parameter and 0 grade
post_text:
Think of the original balance signature as an interface method which you should implement, so therefore you shouldn't change the signature. Imagine the user of you class, who wants to check the string for being balanced and he is required to pass to params to the function, the second one being Int. What should he pass there? 1, -3, 12? In case there is only one value he can pass, then this parameter is superfluous. Noone is restricting you in creating helper functions internally.
Regarding submitting unit tests - how will the correctness of your unit test be checked? What if it's just assert(true)?

title: Lecture 1.7 - Tail Recursion -- limited implementation of factorial
post_text:
Hi there,

I was answering the quiz regarding implementing factorial function and found out that my implementation handled larger numbers better than the one given in the lecture. So I thought of sharing it in case it's of any interest:

    def factorial( n: Int ): Int = {
        def inner( i: Int, n: Int ): Int =
            if ( i == n-1 ) i * (i+1)
            else inner(i+1,n)
        inner(1,n)
    }                                      
       
    factorial(4000000)                        //> res1: Int = 1242822400

If you give the same input to the tailrec factorial function presented in the lecture, it returns 0. If you give 20 it returns a negative number (-2102132736). It works with small numbers though ;)

title: Evaluation sequence of function "def contains"
post_text:
Hi Volkan,

By Set(5) I imagine you mean the singleton set that contains only 5. 
There is no such thing as (Set(5) == Set(4)). Recall Set is an alias for (Int => Boolean). So "Set(5)" should be a function from Int to Bool that returns true, if and only if its argument is 5. You are required to implement the construction of such sets with the function singletonSet.
When you call contains(singletonSet(5), 4) according to the definition of contains, singletonSet(5) will be applied on 4 and should return false.

title: Problem passing a function - syntax question
post_text:
Darrel, I think I understand it now. When I pass fee(7) I'm NOT passing a function because I'm getting pass by value resolution which resolves the function to its returned Int value BEFORE passing it foo thus it's passing an Int instead of a function. I moved the argument to fee back to an additional argument for foo giving me the code below which works:)

object TryIt {
  def main(args: Array[String]) = {
      foo(fee, 7)
      foo(fee, 2)
      foo(fee, 9)
  }
  
  def foo(f: Int => Int, i: Int) = {
    println(f(i))
  }
  
  val fee = (i: Int) => {
    if (i < 5) i
    else 0
  }
}

Thanx muchly for your help - Charlie

title: Question: Should we implment this method here, or should it remain abstract??
post_text: How do I decide whether to implement a method in the abstract class or not for several methods?? It seems to me like this is more of a style issue.

title: Question: Should we implment this method here, or should it remain abstract??
post_text: One factor to consider is whether or not the subclasses have different behavior or the behavior depends on members available only in the subclasses.

title: Question: Should we implment this method here, or should it remain abstract??
post_text: There are semi-formal rules to answer this question, but I'll admit to having to brush up on them. As a rule of thumb, you would put methods in an abstract class you absolutely want all children classes to have, but you cannot necessarily be specific enough in it's implementation in the abstract class. For instance - suppose you have an abstract class $$Animal$$ which has the method $$communicate$$ and extends to the classes $$Human$$, $$Dog$$, and $$Cat$$. The latter classes are then required to implement their respective methods of $$communicate$$. That's to say, all $$Animal$$s communicate differently (uniquely).

title: Lecture 3.1 IntSet not producing expected results
post_text:
Can someone please check what is going on with the code that I will post below?.
- look at the result from the scala worksheet from or even from the println(t1)
val t1 = t2 incl 4
which turns out to be {.10.}

- So I modified the command for incl, to print the result when the function is called: 
def incl(x: Int): IntSet = {
    if (x < elem) {
      println(x, elem)
      println(left, right)
      println(new NonEmpty(elem, left incl x, right))
      new NonEmpty(elem, left incl x, right)
    }
    if (x > elem) new NonEmpty(elem, left, right incl x)
    else this
  }
and the output is the correct one, namely: {{.4.}10.}.

Is this a bug in the scala worksheet?, or what am I missing here?


package week4

object IntSet {
  val t2 = new NonEmpty(10, new Empty, new Empty) //> t2  : week4.NonEmpty = {.10.}
  val t1 = t2 incl 4                              //> (4,10)
                                                  //| (.,.)
                                                  //| {{.4.}10.}
                                                  //| t1  : week4.IntSet = {.10.}
  println(t1)                                     //> {.10.}
}

abstract class IntSet {
  def incl(x: Int): IntSet
  def contains(x: Int): Boolean
}

class Empty extends IntSet {
  def contains(x: Int): Boolean = false
  def incl(x: Int): IntSet = new NonEmpty(x: Int, new Empty, new Empty)
  override def toString = "."
}

class NonEmpty(elem: Int, left: IntSet, right: IntSet) extends IntSet {
  def incl(x: Int): IntSet = {
    if (x < elem) {
      println(x, elem)
      println(left, right)
      println(new NonEmpty(elem, left incl x, right))
      new NonEmpty(elem, left incl x, right)
    }
    if (x > elem) new NonEmpty(elem, left, right incl x)
    else this
  }
  def contains(x: Int): Boolean = {
    if (x < elem) left contains x
    if (x > elem) right contains x
    else true
  }
  override def toString = "{" + left + elem + right + "}"

}
Thank you for your help in advance.

- One last comment, if I choose a larger value, then the output is correct: 
 val t1 : IntSet = t2 incl 77                    //> t1  : week4.IntSet = {.10{.77.}}

title: Signature track & unverified submissions
post_text:
Hi I'm in the same position as you, as I joined the Signature Track this Tuesday, I agree that the info was a bit vague about how the track works if you enroll later than you can submit all the assignments without score penalty. But having said this I will quote this sentence from the assignments page https://class.coursera.org/progfun-005/assignment which you can find under each assignment's submission score table:

"Assignments are authenticated overall if at least half of the submitted, non-optional assignment parts are authenticated. The authentication status for each part is the authentication status of the attempt counted as the effective score."

This actually may explain why you didn't receive authenticated status for the first assignment. The reason may be that your unauthenticated score is higher than that of the authenticated score because the authenticated score has a penalty due to being submitted after the due date. If this is the case it will pick the higher score as the final score and it's authentication status.

You should also remember to regenerate your submission passwords before submitting. They expire pretty quickly as well so it is best to generate them right before submitting.

In any case, as long as you submit at least half of the assignments with proper authentication you should be ok, as you can see from the quote above. By the way, check this page out https://www.coursera.org/signature/guidebook/joining for any more questions, it helped me out.

title: what should mostRetweeted return for an empty set?
post_text:
if you want to check if a set is empty you should implement that isEmpty function.
There is a way by using "instanceof" but you should avoid using that.

An alternative to checking for empty is writing a helper function "def mostRetweeted( currentBest: Tweet): Tweet" that never throws an error. It will traverse the entire tree and keep track of the current best tweet similar to how you usually use an accumulator.
You'll have to figure out the implementation and how/where to call it yourself tho.

title: Why is filterAcc defined in TweetSet?
post_text:
In general, it does make sense for any set or tweet set to have a filter function. As Charilaso pointed out, filterAcc is more general than filter function. filterAcc can take the desire elem from the current set and add to another, i.e. "acc", while filter just takes the desire elem.
As a subclass of set, generally, we should not have the case "What if a subclass doesn't need to do that?". Of course, this is just a general rule/requirement, you might still argue that "what if a subclass of tweet set doesn't even need a union function"?

title: Currying - Readability vs Concisibility ?
post_text:
I would refer to the Scala style guide that recommends all public API methods have an explicit return type (i.e. do not rely on type inference to get the return type defined).

http://docs.scala-lang.org/style/types.html

Aside from readability usefulness, this also prevents some unexpected errors when Scala silently compiles a return type that is not what you expected.

title: Counting change resolution
post_text:
holy moley, I am just a programmer, and coming from an assembler/c background found myself fairly falling all over the place in the scala stratosphere!

My approach to the first problem was to ignore the 'triangle', set the coordinate system as if the apex was in a top-left corner of a matrix, and find out what superior coordinates imposed their values on the target coordinate: It strikes me as efficient because the problem was getting the value for a given coord, not the fancy production of an imaginary triangle.

Second one was just evaluating a string one token at a time, checking for abort conditions - negative count at any point, positive on end of run - and verifying you have a zero at the end for success.

The third problem needed a bit of thinking and I got a piece of paper, drew a circle with pennies in it, made a list of denominations in that (1,5,10,25,50,100,500,1000,2000) and figured the logic out using muscle power - I think algebra and calculus were invented after I left school!
It just came down to taking from the running total whatever current denomination allowed, and recursing after deduction and keeping the current denomination, or recursing without deduction and the list of remaining denominations. Exit on zero or less.

I apologize if people are shocked by my use of braces - it is a crutch to my memory and eyesight 

So, here's my solutions to the problems - start chucking rocks folks!

package recfun
import common._

object Main{
  def main(args: Array[String]) {
  }

  /**
   * Exercise 1
   */

  def pascal(c: Int, r: Int): Int = {
    val badCoord : Int = -1
    val apexCell : Int = 1
    val nullCell : Int = 0

    /* If the current cell position is out of range, return null */
    if ( c<=badCoord || r<=badCoord || c>r )  nullCell
    else
    {
      /* Apex cell? */
      if ( c==0 ) apexCell
        /* Call each of the parent cells to get their values
           and hand the sum back to the lower cell */
      else pascal ( c-1 , r-1 ) + pascal ( c , r-1 )
    }
  }

  /**
   * Exercise 2
   */
  def balance (chars: List[Char] ) : Boolean = {
    def validatePar ( chars : List[Char] ,
                      level : Int) : Boolean = {
    // No more characters to process?
      if ( chars.isEmpty ) {
        // Uneven parentheses at end of line?
        if ( level!=0 ) false else true
        // Even parentheses at end of line!
      }
      else {
        chars.head match {
        // Left parenthesis
        case '(' => validatePar ( chars.tail , level+1 )
        // Right parenthesis
        case ')' => {
          if ( level<=0 ) false
          else validatePar ( chars.tail , level-1 )
          }
        // Other characters
        case _ => validatePar ( chars.tail , level )
        } // end of match
      }
    } // end of validatePar

    validatePar ( chars , 0 )
  }

  /**
   * Exercise 3
   */

  def countChange(money: Int, coins: List[Int]): Int = {

  // No more money?
  if( money == 0 ) 1 // end of current result
  else
    // overdrawn?
    if( money < 0 ) 0 // result expired on previous iteration
    else
      // no more denominations? but money remaining?
      if(coins.isEmpty && money >= 1 ) 0 // result expired
      else
        // money remains for current denomination level
        // and/or valid denominations remain
        countChange ( money - coins.head , coins ) +  countChange ( money , coins.tail )

  } // countChange

}

package objsets

object MaxTest {

title: difference between ; and else
post_text:
because you have code after your if it is not the last line, and not treated as a return statement.

The first example you could say
If (a>b) return a; else return b

The second would be treated as:
if (a>b) a; return b

Edit: Made a false statement, and removed it

title: Lost points on submission -- no meaningful message provided
post_text: I just received the same error, while I was playing with my code after getting a full score first. My error was in the mostRetweeted function. When recursing through the binary tree, I missed half of the leaves in this implementation. Apparently, returning a wrong order TweetList apparently leads to this error message as well.

title: difference between ; and else
post_text: An expression like { e1 ; e2 } says "evaluate e1, discard its result, then evaluate e2, and return its result as the result of the whole { ... } expression. So your max2 simply always returns its second argument.

title: Is it ok to use var instead of val inside method?
post_text: The purpose of these assignments are to learn functional programming and reverting to other styles will prevent you from learning some valuable techniques.  I could have solved all of the first three exercises using any number of methods, packages, and/or styles.  What I've been focusing on is embracing this style and learning as much as I can about it.  When tempted to drop back to "old" techniques, I take a minute and think - "I wonder what the instructor is trying to teach me this with this challenge".  The main issue I have is that getting 10's on the assignments doesn't mean I've really done the assignment the way it was meant to be done.

title: Emacs + ensime
post_text:
Good news!

ensime-sbt now works flawlessly [1] with the environment used by the assignments.

To make it work install ensime package in your Emacs and create or edit the file ~/.sbt/plugins/build.sbt with the following content:
resolvers += Resolver.sonatypeRepo("snapshots")

addSbtPlugin("org.ensime" % "ensime-sbt" % "0.1.5-SNAPSHOT")
Then in each project directories in the sbt REPL type: gen-ensime
Open a file of the project in Emacs and execute the command: M-x ensime

You should be ready to do the assignment in Emacs :-)

[1] https://github.com/ensime/ensime-server/issues/646

title: Question: Should we implment this method here, or should it remain abstract??
post_text:
Here's how I think about it.

If the implementation of the method does not depend on any of the implementation details of one of the subclasses, then you may safely implement it in the abstract class.

If it does, then it naturally *has* to be in the subclass.

So, actually, the compiler will tell you the answer!

Just try to implement the method in the abstract class.  If Eclipse whines at you about stuff that is not visible in the abstract class, then it doesn't belong there!

title: mostTweeted method
post_text:
Hi, everyone!

I implemented this method (mostTweeted) using filter .
But in order for my implementation to be short I needed to extend the TweetSet class a bit.

In particular, I needed to have an access to the elem
 And this is the part I don't really undestand in Scala (Java?) behavour?

If I append val  to "elem" in the NonEmpty's constructor OR define a separate accessor (field / parameter - you name it), then I only have access to it, unless I call another method in between (i.e chaining is NOT working).

For example:

val test = new NonEmpty(new Tweet("A", "A", 1), new Empty, new Empty)

test.elem # => Works.
test.filter(tw => 1 == 1).elem # Doesn't work
In order to make the latter example work I had to define a method inside of the TweetSet abstact class and then implement it inside both "Empty" and "NonEmpty" classes.

But why is that? Why can't it be specific to "Empty" or "NonEmpty"?

And it behaves like that for every single extra method (or parameter) you define separately in either of classes (w/o being defined in the abstact class) 
It just keeps telling that "<something> is not a member of objsets.TweetSet".

2) Is it allowed to define your own methods in scope of this assignment? Would that be counted as cheating or not? 

3) Can this method be implemented without any additions to the code (except isEmpty)? 

4) What if there are 2+ tweets with the exact same number of retweets and this number happens to be the max - which tweet should this method return? 

Thank you for all your answers and attention.

title: mostTweeted method
post_text:
Hi. 

Your example doesn't work because in general case you don't know which of subclasses a function will return. So you can call only those metods, that are defined in TweetSet class. 

And, anyway, you don't need access to elem from outside. And even isEmpty is not obligatory. But, it looks like implementation of your own methods isn't prohibited, though.

title: mostTweeted method
post_text:
Hi.

Thank you for your answer. 

1) I though that Scala OOP had a dynamic method dispatching, as mentioned in course lectures.
So invoking a method on something that returns "NonEmpty" instance (even though, defined as TweetSet), should just call this method on it and that's all. Dunno. I was really expecting another behaviour.

2) Well, my implementation is kinda simple. At each iteration (it's a recursive function, though) I call "filter" in attempt to find at least a single tweet with a number of retweets higher than the currently checked one against, and if something is found -> keep on, and if an empty set is returned - I know I found the max. But that really involves in getting the "current" element from the TweetSet - elem, which is by default NOT accessible from the outside of the instance scope (this).

title: mostTweeted method
post_text:
If you define a method in Empty or NonEmpty but not in TweetSet then you cannot use Empty or NonEmpty as TweetSets ... the point of them extending TweetSet is so you can use either one wherever you use TweetSet.  If you want to define new methods you need to define them in TweetSet and either implement there or implement them in both Empty and NonEmpty.  If you change the parameters of mostRetweeted you'll have to change them in all three classes (this will probably break the tests).

You can write mostRetweeted without defining new class methods (other than isEmpty); you might need a helper method which can be defined in mostRetweeted itself.  One way to look at mostRetweeted and how to solve it is to (1) pretend it already works the way it should i.e. pretend that a call to mostRetweeted already returns the tweet with the greatest number of retweets, then (2) look at the structure of NonEmpty ...  elem, left tweetset, right tweetset ...  how would you manually look through that structure to find the most retweeted tweet given that calling mostRetweeted works as expected?

title: In Scala, is a function that takes call by name parameter different from a function that takes another function as parameter?
post_text:
Hi guys,

I found this to be a very thought-provoking question, and I believe we'll discover as we learn more about Scala that there is really no such thing as a call-by-name parameter - and it's just a convenient way of talking about a parameter that expects a function that returns in int (for example) instead of a parameter that expects an int.

Consider this:
1/ There's a shortcut for defining functions literals (inline) that I'm not sure has been covered yet - but this anonymous function:
    (x) => x * 2
can be shortened to just this:
    _ * 2
(try it with the Set stuff we dealt with in assignment 2 - call the map function as map(_ * 2) instead of map((x) => x * 2)

If that's possibly, than couldn't a literal number like "2" be interpreted as either an Int, or a function that takes no parameters, and returns an int?

2/ When calling a function, the () is optional - even with a parameter, as we've seen (with operators and the inline style), but especially if it takes no parameters.

3/ Scala's type inference system can put all of the above together and make it work - if the literal "2" is being passed to something that expects () => Int, then it's a function - otherwise, it's a literal int. If a () => Int function is being passed to something that also expects a function, then the function itself is passed - if it's being passed to something that expects an Int, then the function is called, and the value is passed.

So I suggest that the 2 functions being compared in the original question are exactly the same - one of them has just omitted the (presumably, optional) () when writing a function type that takes no parameters. ...and so called "pass-by-name" parameters are really just passing around functions.

What do you guys think?

-Jonathan

title: How to generate large tweetSets  for testing?
post_text:
thanks Michael

Initially didnt work until I figured that "incl" only uses tweet text as key so the following small mod works a treat

Updated to use the md5sum hash for text to make it more challenging for the incl function and remove the random to make it deterministic.

def makeTweetSet(user:String,numTweets: Int): TweetSet = {
    import java.security.MessageDigest
    val digest = MessageDigest.getInstance("MD5")

    def iter(n: Int, accu: TweetSet): TweetSet =
      if (n == 0) accu
      else 
        iter(n - 1, accu incl (new Tweet(user, digest.digest((user+n.toString).getBytes).map("%02x".format(_)).mkString, n)))


    iter(numTweets, new Empty)
  }
scala> size(makeTweetSet("userfoo",10))
res36: Int = 10




Thanks to https://gist.github.com/amscotti/2467512 for the md5sum code.

title: forall and exists
post_text:
The bounds for `forall` and `exists` are +/- 1000.Returns whether all bounded integers within `s` satisfy `p`.

Assuming the set contains elements between -1000 and 1000. forAll function returns true if the given condition (second parameter) is true for every element in set s (first parameter)

Assuming the set contains elements between -1000 and 1000. exists function returns true if there is at least one element in set s (first parameter) for which given condition (second parameter) is true.

Ex: For set (2,3,5,7,9) there exists atleast one element (2) for which (x%2==0) is true.

Ex: For set (2,4,6,8,10) for all elements of set (x%2==0) is true.

Iterate between -1000 and +1000, 

a) if the element is in set (as we are simply iterating between -1000 & 1000), if you find at least one element for which condition is not satisfied return false. 

b) If bound reaches 1000 that implies 'a' never occurred.

c) Keep iterating to next element.

title: What does type mean ?

I assume you understand what the meaning of "Int => Boolean" is (see lecture video 2.1). The "type" keyword allows you to create an alias for the function type ("Set" for Int => Boolean). I think this is not explicitly explained in the lectures of this week. 

There is no collection type or some kind of array used for the assignment. Its only "described" by the Set function.

Try to start with the first exercise (singletonSet) and you will get the idea. Good luck with the assignment.

title: can we write map function in one line?

I believe for "map" it is possible to write it in one line, but I still haven't received my assigment results to verify it :)

I think it is useful to think like a mathematician. "Exists" is like saying "there should be x which...". And you have "forall" which is like "for every x some_expression". If you do a negation of that, you would get "there should be at least on x that does not satisfy expression". If you do a double negation, logically you get the same thing, but one of this negations you can use to transform "exists" into "forall". Hope it helps.

title: Is Filter similar to Intersect ?
post_text:
Hi All,

I am completly confused,
we have the two definitions below who are identical in fact:

def filter(s: Set, p: Int => Boolean): Set =
def intersect(s: Set, t: Set): Set =

If I consider "Set" as it is defined, I can write:
def filter(s: Set, p: Int => Boolean): Set = intersect(s,p)

But, if Set has a different implementation, my function definition will fail.
Is this definition more appropriate ?

def filter(s: Set, p: Int => Boolean): Set = (i : Int) => contains(s,i) && p(i)

Please let me know if I am in the right direction.

thanks.

title: Encoding simplest possible text question
post_text:
I am currently working on the Huffman Coding Assignments. I have difficulties to understand the following case:

Assume I have a text containing only "aaaaaaaa". The corresponding optimal Huffman Code would be a degenerated tree with only a single Leaf node.

How would the corresponding "bit sequence" look like to express this text? It can't be "0000000" because this would mean I had to choose the left subtree of the root node several times, but the root node does not have a left subtree.

Which detail of the explanation of the algorithm I have missed?

Thanks and regards
-stefan-

title: Is Filter similar to Intersect ?
post_text:
That's the way I did it at least. (filter = intersect).
Intersect takes two sets but a set is just int=>bool anyhow so if you just rewrite it a bit you get the same thing like filter.
However filter is expected to take a set and a function acting on that set.
Presumably it's the way the functions are meant to be used that is the biggest difference, but apart from that I've not noticed any implementation difference between the two.

title: Test "descending: set5" is not correct
For mostRetweeted, what if many tweets with same reweetCount ?
post_text:
It isn't specified, so it shouldn't matter.
An example of this is the unit test that was given for "descendingByRetweet":

  test("descending: set5") {
    new TestSets {
      val trends = set5.descendingByRetweet
      assert(!trends.isEmpty)
      assert(trends.head.user == "a" || trends.head.user == "b")
    }
  }

As you can see, the correct answer is the "a" OR "b" tweet, which both have the same # of retweets.  descendingByRetweet should use mostRetweeted under the covers, so again, doesn't matter for the assignment.

title: Timeout on union function
post_text:
Ok. here is my 5 cent
  def union(that: TweetSet): TweetSet = 
    right.union(left.union(that.incl(elem)))

works fast because under the hood it turns out that you are just including all elements from "this" to "that", traversing the tree "this" in-order, one by one.

title: Currying - Readability vs Concisibility ?
post_text:
syntax and style aside, I would write code in a manner that a newbie would be able to look at my code and understand the style and concept quickly. I write code in the mindset that some day, I might pass away and leave my *legacy* (chuckle) to some green horn. This came from my own exp having to read the code without documentations nor comments from someone who wrote it, and passed away 2 weeks before my arrival at the company @_@. I don't make other's life hard when I can avoid it

And always remember this:
Any fool can write code that a computer can understand. Good programmers write code that humans can understand.
Martin Fowler, 2008

title: For mostRetweeted, what if many tweets with same reweetCount ?
post_text:
Depends on how you write your test. For me it would normally return the first one it finds with the highest retweet count. Maybe in an ideal world we would return a list/array of TweetSet if there are more than one TweetSets with highest count. But that would be a pain I imagine >_<

PS: nice to see someone from Vietnam finally ;)

title: Encoding simplest possible text question
post_text: But when the tree only contains a single root Leaf, I immediately "reach a leaf" (without consuming any bit) and decode the character from this Leaf, than I start again at the root, "immediately reach a leaf" (without consuming any bit), consume the character, then I start again... Finally I would produce a neverending stream of a single character without consuming any bit of the bit sequence.

title: How to start writing code in functional style?
post_text: I like scala, but for learning to program in a functional style, I wonder if classes and objects all over the place aren't too distracting.  A less ambitious language like clojure (on the jvm) or scheme or ml is maybe easier to learn the functional style with, because they don't give you the opportunity to use all those lovely but anti-functional design patterns you learned in java. It's just a theory.

title: Unit tests for part 4?
post_text:
because a text might contain both the keyword in google family AND apple family, it would be hard to write unit tests. Since unit test depends on known values, you can't know the size of the union until you actually count yourself, or write another unit test that does the thing (then again, you can't be sure if it counts correctly :D, so you'll have to UT that, too)

My test for this would just print the size of the google and apple tweet, I look at the result and was like, "Ok, this looks correct", then the same for the size of the union. The perfectionist's way of UT would be too much for me in this case in particular.

I just tested that way to see if there is any error occur during the operation (there was - I got a stack overflow >_<), then, based on the concrete methods filter, mostRetweeted etc. that I have done UT and have made sure that they worked, I just decided that the method formed based on them with an understandable logic can't fail

title: Lecture 4.7: 1st quiz question, list pattern matcher
post_text:
You misunderstood the lecture.
The list x :: y :: List(xs, ys) :: zs has at least 3 elements, which are x, y and List(xs, ys). The remainder zs might be empty or not, so the total length of the list would be >= 3.
This does not mean it would match ANY list of length >= 3. Just that any list that matches it would have a length >= 3.

As for the type error, obviously if the list contains both Ints and a List[Int], it can't be of either of those types, as neither one is a supertype of the other. From what I can tell, Any is indeed the closest supertype of both. AnyVal wouldn't work here.

post_text:
Like Ahmed suggested, Haskell is a great language for functional.

The book is available online, and is great for introducing people to Haskell. When you get to chapter 5, recursions will seem much easier.

assert(combine(leaflist) === List(Fork(Leaf('e', 1), Leaf('t', 2), List('e', 't'), 3), Leaf('x', 4)))

(a Fork element and a Leaf element).

title: eclipse folder structure?
post_text:
Eclipse does not force a structure per se, but you are wise to put all files that belong to the same project in a single folder tree.
A frequently used setup is to have a structure like this:

project
- src
-- main
--- java
--- resources
--- scala
-- test
--- java
--- resources
--- scala
- target
(with sub folders for all generated/compiled code and resources)

General advise: use a structure that works for you, your team, or your employer. When integrating with existing build tooling (maven, grunt, whatever), adhere to the conventions used/advised by the community using those tools ('go with the flow'). Yes, that may mean you have to learn several different setups, but in the end you will make it easier on yourself and others when you need their cooperation.

title: Eclipse Setup doesnt show Run As Scala ?
post_text:
Hi, David.  Just to reiterate... "Run As Scala" will not appear if you don't have a correctly named object in a .scala file, and that object must extend App.  If you are seeing "Run As Java", did you create a main() method instead?

Also, you did not mention which assignment.  In one of the assignments, you have to highlight the object name in your editor before the "Run As Scala" appears because of a mismatch between the filename and the object name.

Also, how did you create your Eclipse Project?  Did you take care to create a Scala project and not a Java one?

title: createCodeTree(someText)' not giving an optimal encoding
post_text:
I was just debugging the exact same issue right now.

The solution to my bug was hidden in the description:
"Write a function combine which (1) removes the two trees with the lowest weight from the list constructed in the previous step, and (2) merges them by creating a new node of type Fork. Add this new tree to the list - which is now one element shorter - while preserving the order (by weight)."

 Let me know if you need another hint.

title: createCodeTree(someText)' not giving an optimal encoding
post_text:
I guess I do...
I don't see any "hidden hint" there, just grab the first two elements of the list (as is sorted by weight) and combine them.

title: createCodeTree(someText)' not giving an optimal encoding
post_text:
The point is (at least for me) that the order needs to be preserved.

Or in other words, if you have (a, 1), (b, 1), (c, 1), (d, 1) you should end up with  (a, 1), (b, 1), (c, 1), (d, 1) -> (c, 1), (d, 1), (a, b, 2) -> (a, b, 2) , (c, d, 2) -> (a, b, c, d, 4). If you don't keep the order preserved in the combine method, you will probably end up with  (a, 1), (b, 1), (c, 1), (d, 1) -> (a, b, 2), (c, 1), (d, 1) -> (a, b, c, 3), (d, 1)  -> (a, b, c, d, 4).

Sorry for the notation, can't think of anything better right now.
