title: createCodeTree(someText)' not giving an optimal encoding
post_text: I see, so preserve the order of trees in the list; not the order of the leaves. Will check up tomorrow.

title: Submit assignment after signature track
post_text:
Problem: Submit assignment after signature track

URL: https://class.coursera.org/progfun-005/help/programming/content


Browser: Chrome 37
OS: Windows 8


Additional details:

Do I need to submit all my assignment (1 and 2) again due the fact that I am now in the Signature Track?

I have generated a new Submission Password for the 1st assignment and says "verified" but nevertheless in the score table the Authenticated column says "No"

title: Submit assignment after signature track
post_text: You have to submit again. But give the system some time to update itself. Mine said the same thing, but after 30 mins, my resubmissions (with the new password) were authenticated.

title: Assignment 3 (TweetReader.scala) does NOT compile
post_text: You have to download the Eclipse IDE for Scala 2.10.4. Here is the link: http://scala-ide.org/download/sdk.html

title: Handling encoding of characters not in code tree
post_text: The assignment does not describe how to handle the case of a text to be encoded that contains characters which are not in the code tree. Should we raise and exception? Can we assume the grading system will not call our solutions to encode/decode text with chars not in the codetree?

title: Handling encoding of characters not in code tree
post_text: Since it wasn't specified in the instructions, I thought it was probably safe to skip checks for missing chars in CodeTrees and CodeTables. My submission got full marks so that seems to be the case. Feels a bit wrong though :)

title: Function def or val (Relates to Set assignment)
post_text:
Just to add to Charles' answer... In this context both forms will work fine but they are a little different "under the hood".

When you use def you are creating a method which belongs to the object or class containing that definition. That method could also be called from outside the object or class (unless you declare the method as private). The method has a name (emptySet).

When you use val here you are creating an anonymous function (aka function literal) and assigning that to the val emptySet.  Here "emptySet" is not the name of the function. You could for instance do this...
val emptySet = (Int) => false
val anonFunCopy = emptySet
Now both values point to the same function literal and you can use either to evaluate the function.

The Scala compiler is very flexible, so if you have a function that expects a function literal as a parameter it will also work with an equivalent class or object method, as you've found.

title: Working with netbeans
post_text: If your Netbeans setup works with Scala by all means. I tried setting it up and failed miserably. All Scala files showed up with errors of all kinds including, syntax errors, package not found errors, dependencies not found, etc. I eventually gave up and downloaded the Scala IDE for Eclipse.

title: running from Main in eclipse?
post_text:
hi all - this has a lot of posts on the web, but I was wondering if anyone else in the class is having an issue running from Main in eclipse with the scala ide plugin? 

I've uninstalled/installed both the current & prior plugins, tried both versions of greeter.hello, etc. and still nothing works. I get the usual class not found exception that a lot of people seem to have with lots of different versions of the plugin... I tried their fixes & they don't work for me.

The unit tests don't work in eclipse either.

Both run & test work in the command line.

I'm using eclipse kepler on a mac... does anyone have any ideas on how I can get this to work or should I just give it up as a lost cause & run/test from the command line?

Thx a bunch in advance!!

title: Unit tests for part 4?
post_text: Thanks Le

title: Function def or val (Relates to Set assignment)
post_text: my understanding was that a val is evaluated once where it is declared and treated as a constant after that whereas def declares a function that is re-evaluated each time it is used.

title: Grading error
post_text:
Problem: Grading error

URL: https://class.coursera.org/progfun-005/forum


Browser: Chrome 37
OS: Windows


Additional details:
I submitted my second assignment for week 2 of Scala a day late. The penalty is supposed to be 20% but my final score is 6/10 though the feedback shows that my score without the penalty would have been 10/10. 

Am I the only person to encounter this problem?

title: Test "trending: google and apple tweets"
post_text:
I had the same problem. (I also added a test for trending.)

Submission 1: tests took a little over 3 seconds locally, timed out (over 40s) when submitted.

Submission 2: tests took a little more than 1 second locally, time out (over 40s) when submitted.

Submission 3: tests took around 1 second locally, time out (over 40s) when submitted.

title: Do we have to develop something ?
post_text:
I'm not part of the course staff, so I can't confirm anything ;)

As I understood it, the first assignment's goal is simply to check that you installed your IDE properly and that you understand how to submit assignments via SBT. If you look through the Cheat Sheet's List part, you'll find some useful functions that will help you:

xs exists p    // true if there is at least one element for which predicate p is true
xs forall p    // true if p(x) is true for all elements
xs zip ys      // returns a list of pairs which groups elements with same index together
xs unzip       // opposite of zip: returns a pair of two lists
xs.flatMap f   // applies the function to all elements and concatenates the result
xs.sum         // sum of elements of the numeric collection
xs.product     // product of elements of the numeric collection
xs.max         // maximum of collection
xs.min         // minimum of collection
xs.flatten     // flattens a collection of collection into a single-level collection
xs groupBy f   // returns a map which points to a list of elements
xs distinct    // sequence of distinct entries (removes duplicates)

title: Lecture 3.1 - are there other implementations of union
post_text:
The problem I have with the union operation as shown in the video is that the flow is very unclear.  What actually happens is that 'other' is never broken apart; instead "this" is picked apart and eventually every element is built up into a giant chain of inserts.  When 'this' has become empty, then the whole recursive descent into "union" terminates in a call to EmptySet.union other - producing 'other' - and all the unpicked elements are then inserted.  It was very unclear to me that this is how it worked; I had to sit down and work it out.

Much more straightforward and understandable would be to insert the value just removed from "this" to "other" at every iteration.  I was actually convinced the implementation shown in the video was incorrect for a few minutes until I saw how the flow works out.

title: What does this function syntax mean?
post_text:
def run {
  // some code 
}
is syntactic sugar for 
def run : Unit = {
  // some code
}
I think that this syntax will not be present in future versions of Scala, though.

Now for the second part, I'm not quite sure what you mean. Is doSomething a function you defined before? If so, 
doSomething {
  block
}
is syntactic sugar for 
doSomething(block)
It is nice to have when you pass call-by-name parameters, because it reminds of syntax of built-in language structures (like while) which take blocks as "arguments". Then you can do cute stuff like here: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/13331600/how-to-write-function-simulating-while-loop-in-scala

Hope this answers your question.

title: 4.2 testing custom Boolean class
post_text:
in the lecture 4.2, custom Boolean class looks like

package coursera.chapter4

abstract class Boolean {

  def IfThenElse[T](t: T, e: T): T

  def &&(other: Boolean) = IfThenElse(other, false)
  def ||(other: Boolean) = IfThenElse(true, other)
  def unary_! = IfThenElse(false, true)

  def ==(other: Boolean) = IfThenElse(other, other.unary_!)
  def !=(other: Boolean) = IfThenElse(other.unary_!, other)
}

object true extends Boolean {
  def IfThenElse[T](t: T, e:T) = t
}

object false extends Boolean {
  def IfThenElse[T](t: T, e:T) = e
}

It seems that `true` and `false` are reserved word so that they can't used as identifiers.

title: Balance between pattern matching and inheritance
post_text:
Hi, I will take the assignment 4 as example but is illustrative. I also take that the assignment could be forcing the use of pattern matching for the sake of learning.

The assignment starts with case classes

  abstract class CodeTree
  case class Fork(left: CodeTree, right: CodeTree, chars: List[Char], weight: Int) extends CodeTree
  case class Leaf(char: Char, weight: Int) extends CodeTree


and then as a first exercise it suggests to complete the following methods:

  1. def weight(tree: CodeTree): Int = tree match ...
  2. def chars(tree: CodeTree): List[Char] = tree match ...
 
These two could perfectly be abstracts of CodeTree.

My question is: what would be a good balance here between pattern matching and oop here?

As an old java programmer; I really feel that these should be methods of the class and that using case for checking the types having different behaviors for each of them is exactly what you SHULDN'T do; but of course could be that I need a mentality shift :-D.

title: testing sets longer than singleton?

So you can write your own additional sets to test edge cases

yes, in this case, Nil should always be an object, since there can only be one instance of an empty list of Tweets.

In the lectures, the type of elements for the List class is generic, so Nil is first introduced as a class (since there needs to be an empty list for each type of element).

you can still have Nil be an object with a generic element type; I would recommend watching lecture 4.4 if you're interested :)

title: Balance between pattern matching and inheritance
post_text:
Hi Ariel,

First of all, you do need a little mentality shift: I think you would agree that "checking the types" with pattern matching in Scala is actually much more elegant than would be in Java: it does the Java-equivalent of checking the types, then type casting, then extracting the fields of each subclass, in a much more readable and concise syntax. It should be seen as a generalized switch-expression rather than checking the types (actually, it comes from pattern matching in functional languages such as ML and Haskell).

Secondly, the OO way can be better in some cases, namely when new subclasses of your abstract class may be added in the future. Then you do not want to have to re-implement your weight function every time to add the new cases.

title: mergeCodeTables

title: Balance between pattern matching and inheritance
post_text:
I agree with the "code elegance" against if (xx instanceof Blah) { Blah blah = (Blah) xx .. but that is completely secondary.

The point is your last observation; the open-closed principle being broken by using the pattern matching.  Any OO language could add such a "case" construct for making easier to do a cascaded type checking operation (for instance as you have with the try..catch blocks in java); maybe is because of the principle that other languages don't.

title: Balance between pattern matching and inheritance
post_text:
I completly agree with Ariel, at least weight method asks to be in abstract. But I think this example was designed so we get used to pattern matching. CodeTree is just markup, no behavior specified there and it is used in all method signatures. So it does not represent anything alone. In order to used it, you MUST do some pattern matching or casting. Implementation classes could be private, for usege of Huffman; the CodeTree itself could not be visible to user if interface would be just encode/decode methods from Chars to Bits and vice versa.

If I would be developing this example from scratch I would add some behaviour/property to CodeTree, to get rid of weight and chars methods and keep CodeTree as class with private visibility But again for learning the pattern matching it is great.

BTW: Honestly does anyone consider other implementation of CodeTree? always consider default cases test("ha-ha"){ decode(new CodeTree(){}, List(0)) }

title: 4.6 optional quiz solutions
post_text:
What are your solutions to the last optional quiz of the 4.6 lecture on pattern mathing?

I came up with the following for the show method but I'm wondering if there isn't a better way of achieving the same result. (all my methods are implemented in the Expr trait);

def show: String = {

    def showInParens(e: Expr): String = e match {
      case Sum(_,_) => "(" + e.show + ")"
      case _ => e.show
    }

    this match {
      case Number(n) => n.toString
      case Sum(l, r) => l.show + " + " + r.show
      case Var(name) => name
      case Prod(l, r) => showInParens(l) + " * " + showInParens(r)
    }
  }
}

title: Encoding simplest possible text question
post_text:
val aTable = createCodeTree("aaa".toList)
val as = encode(aTable)("aaaaaa".toList)
println(aTable)
Leaf(a,3)

println(as)
List(0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0)

println(decode(aTable, as))
List(a, a, a, a, a, a, a)

I would think if your given only a single character alphabet then the only allowed bit is '0'.  I have a simple check to see if the leaf node I'm on is also the root node, if so, then I consume a bit during encode and output a character during decode.

title: import from sbt file structure
post_text:
Hi Charlie
Here is a hacky way to do it...

1. In the funsets project folder, do "sbt publish-local".  That creates a jar of the funsets project and adds it to your local ivy repository (used by sbt as its cache of jars).

2. Go to the top folder of the project you want to import funsets classes into. Open the build.sbt file in an editor. Look for one of the 'libraryDependencies" blocks - if there is more than one choose the longest. Add the following:

"progfun-funsets" %% "progfun-funsets" % "1.0.0"

If you add it to the end of the list of dependencies, make sure to add a comma to the line above.

3. Save the build.sbt file and try "sbt console". If all is well you should see output about resolving dependencies and then be given the REPL prompt.  You can now do an import from funsets such as "import funsets.Funsets._"

title: Is it OK to add an abstract `weight` method to `CodeTree`?
post_text:
The abstract CodeTree class declares no methods and has two subclasses Fork and Leaf that both have a weight: Int method/field. Is it OK to add that as an abstract method (or field) to CodeTree?

I ask because the implementation instructions for the combine method ask us to add a node "back into the remaining elements of trees at a position such that the ordering by weights is preserved". Being able to polymorphically get the weight of a tree would make this much easier to implement,

override def toString: String = this match{
      case Number(n) => n.toString
      case Sum(e1, e2) => e1 + " + " + e2
      case Product(Sum(e1,e2),Sum(e3,e4)) => "(" + Sum(e1, e2) + ") * (" + Sum(e3,e4 ) + ")"
      case Product(e1, Sum(e2,e3)) => e1 +" * (" + Sum(e2, e3) + ")"
      case Product(Sum(e1,e2),e3) => "(" + Sum(e1, e2) + ") * " + e3
      case Product(e1, e2) => e1 + " * " + e2
      case Variable(name) => name
    }

post_text:
I'd like to use the ::: operator similar to how it's shown to use the :: operator to do pattern matching on a list.

The lecture shows how to do something like: 

List(1,2,3,4,5,6) match {
   case 1 :: 2 :: _ => "success!"
   case default => "failure :'("
 }

The above works great. In the above matcher, _ can be a list of any size.

So I try to do: 

List(1,2,3,4,5,6) match {
   case _ :: 5 :: _ => "success!"
   case default => "failure :'("
 }

This does not work, because :: can only be used to prepend a single element to a list, not an entire list. The above results in failure.

So the natural thing to do would be: 

List(1,2,3,4,5,6) match {
  case  _ ::: 5 :: _ => "success!"
  case default => "failure :'("
}

Instead of matching a single element prepending to a list beginning with 5, I can prepend a list to a list beginning with 5.

However, this results in the following error: 

Cannot resolve symbol :::

So what gives? Is it impossible to use the ::: operator in pattern matching because it could lead to ambiguous matching? Ie, in the above example, if there were multiple 5's in the list, it seems like it would be ambiguous which 5 was chosen.

Anyway, I know the alternative is to use recursion (well, depending on the use case...), I'd just be curious to learn more about this, and google doesn't really like ":::"

title: Lecture 4.7 List pattern matching using :::
post_text: Interesting question Fred.  This blog article explains how the use of :: in match case works. In short, it depends on an object called '::' which extends List and has an 'unapply' method allowing extraction for pattern matching. As far as I know, there is no ':::' object in the standard library.

post_text:
Could someone please clarify what the "singleton(trees: List[CodeTree])" function is supposed to do exactly?
The description states that it "checks whether the list of trees contains only one single tree". Which one of the following does it mean:
1. A naive implementation that checks that trees is of length 1
2. Check that all nodes in trees belong to one tree. E.g. if trees = List(A, B, C) where B.left = A and B.right = C, then trees is considered a singleton.

Please advise. Many thanks in advance!

JJ

title: Huffman Singleton
post_text:
Every subtree is a tree in itself, so it does mean a single node.
Also note that in order to store tree and all it's subtrees, you really only need the root node, since the left/right would be pointing to to the rest of the tree anyways.

title: Assignment 3 FAQ
post_text:
This is a FAQ from a previous version of this course (003 to be exact), some information could be out-of-date. It is authored by Pavel Lepin

Why is Empty a class rather than an object?

Looks like a simple oversight. Yes, a singleton would likely make more sense here.

Can I extend the interface of provided classes?

Yes. As long as your implementation conforms to the behavior specified by the assignment, you may extend class definitions with additional methods. Note that you probably shouldn't tinker with classes outside of TweetSet.scala.

I'd like to use foreach in my solution. May I?

Not really. foreach doesn't evaluate to anything useful, so the only way to use it would be resorting to side effects, which is something we're trying to keep away from in this class.

I don't get filterAcc. What's it for?

It's a helper function for filter. It builds the result using acc as an intermediate result.

Should filterAcc be tail-recursive? Accumulator variable seems to hint at it.

No. There's no point in making filterAcc tail-recursive as it won't result in any substantial performance gain.

How exactly am I supposed to collect the values for filterAcc? I can recurse on just one branch.

Actually, you can recurse on both. Think about Pascal's triangle. There's an additional complication in this case, as one of your recursive calls should be using the result of the other.

Okay, but I don't know how to add values to acc. It's immutable.

You can't and you don't need to. Create a new set and use it as accumulator afterwards.

I seem to need union for filter. Am I right?

Not really, it can be done without union, and the solution is pretty simple.

How do I detect an empty set? There doesn't appear to be any way to do it.

An OO approach would be to provide different implementations of some methods for Empty and NonEmpty. A particular case of this would be to create an isEmpty method that returns different values for Empty and NonEmpty, though this is not necessarily the best approach, depending on one's style preferences. You definitely shouldn't be using isInstanceOf or using null, however. We will learn yet another way to tackle this problem in later weeks.

Catching a thrown exception seems to be a sound way to deal with the problem of handling empty sets.

You shouldn't do that. Exception handling seems to come with substantial overhead on JVM, and in previous run of the class some students ran into grader timeouts due to taking this approach.

Just how fast should union be? Can I use the implementation given in the lectures?

Pretty fast. At the very least you should be able to run the program and see the results in a second or so (this may vary depending upon hardware and JVM settings, with some students reporting execution time for run of up to ten seconds when running perfectly fine solutions in resource-constrained environment). The implementation in the lectures does not fit this criterion.

Note that there are several simple implementations that achieve linearithmic asymptotic complexity on average, which should be sufficient for your solution to be accepted. If you want an extra challenge, try finding and implementing a linear solution. It's a good deal more involved than simpler approaches, but it's a beautiful algorithm, and it balances the resulting tree as an added bonus. Hint: this is somewhat similar to mergesort. The tricky part is reconstructing the tree from a linear representation of the resulting set in linear time. This may require some degree of recursive ingenuity.

So how do I implement union efficiently?

Various approaches may succeed, including an implementation very similar to the one in the lectures that exhibits much better peformance. Some students used a variety of alternate approaches, including some making use of filter.

Shouldn't mostRetweeted be leastRetweeted instead?

No. mostRetweeted should return the tweet with the highest number of retweets in a set. It is perfectly possible to implement descendingByRetweet using mostRetweeted rather than leastRetweeted.

How do I break the ties for mostRetweeted?

Ties may be broken abritrarily in this case. When two or more tweets have the same number of retweets, it doesn't matter which one of them you return as mostRetweeted.

My descendingByRetweet is in reverse order. How do I reverse it?

You can simply "reverse" the way you're constructing it. It's not quite as straightforward as exchanging two expressions, but it's not much more challenging than that.

Running the program / accessing allTweets seems to take forever.

See the question about union performance. union affects quite a lot of other stuff, including provided code.

title: Lecture 3.3 Polymorphism
post_text:
trait List[T] {
	def isEmpty: Boolean
	def head: T
	def tail : List[T]
}

class Cons[T](_head: T, _tail: List[T]) extends List[T] {
  def isEmpty = false
  val head = _head
  val tail = _tail
}
We have a trait that has on implemented function (isEmpty) and two abstract functions head and tail. head is a function that takes 0 arguments and returns an element of type T and tail() takes 0 arguments and returns a List[T]

1. How can class extend a trait ? I thought class must implement (with keyword) a trait.
2. Above code, class Cons implements the trait List abstract methods? How is this possible. 
val head = _head is like a assignment but not function implementation.
Same goes for val tail = _tail.

After i understand #2, i will be able to make sense of the shorter syntax of using class Cons[T](val head : T, val tail: List[T]).

title: 4.6 optional quiz solutions
post_text:
My solution would be to have an addition parameter 'root' which defines is a given expr is a root expr or not. Non-root Sum & Prod expressions need to be enclosed in brackets, a root one doesn't need that. See:

def show(e: Expr, root: Boolean = true): String = (e, root) match {
    case (Number(n), _) => n.toString
    case (Var(name, value), _) => name
    case (Sum(e1, e2), true) => show(e1, false) + " + " + show(e2, false)
    case (Sum(e1, e2), false) => "(" + show(e1, false) + " + " + show(e2, false) + ")"
    case (Prod(e1, e2), true) => show(e1, false) + " * " + show(e2, false)
    case (Prod(e1, e2), false) => "(" + show(e1, false) + " * " + show(e2, false) + ")"
  }

It might not be the best solution however it should be good enough for this exercise. And yet, it's simple:)
Any comments?

	def show(e: Expr, root: Boolean = true): String = (e, root) match {
		case (Number(n), _) => n.toString
   		case (Var(name, value), _) => name

title: 4.6 optional quiz solutions
post_text:
My solution would be to have an addition parameter root which defines is a given expr is a root expr or not. Non-root Sum & Prod expressions need to be enclosed in brackets, a root one doesn't need that. See: 

def show(e: Expr, root: Boolean = true): String = (e, root) match {
	case (Number(n), _) => n.toString
	case (Var(name), _) => name
	case (Sum(e1, e2), true) => show(e1, false) + " + " + show(e2, false)
	case (Sum(e1, e2), false) => "(" + show(e1, false) + " + " + show(e2, false) + ")"
	case (Prod(e1, e2), true) => show(e1, false) + " * " + show(e2, false)
	case (Prod(e1, e2), false) => "(" + show(e1, false) + " * " + show(e2, false) + ")"
}

Then show(Sum(Prod(Number(2), Var("x", 0)), Var("y", 1))) will print (2 * x) + y.

title: Lecture 3.3 Polymorphism
post_text:
1) There is no special "implements" keyword as in Java. What is the need of two keywords anyway? :)
2) This is an interesting question. First of all, it is no "assignment" in the imperative sense but rather initialization, since "val" denotes an immutable value. It says "define an immutable field head in Cons, and initialize it with the value of the argument _head provided in the class constructor".
To answer your question, in Scala, defs without parameters can be implemented by vals. The idea is that, in the case of Cons, we do not actually need to calculate anything when executing List.head: we can always return the same constant value. If you are asking yourself, why not make head a val in the parent class too, see the implementation in Nil: there we actually do need to execute some code.
Finally, the shorter syntax you are referring to is just syntactic sugar: 
(val head: T, ...)
defines an argument of the class constructor and a class field at the same time.

Hope this helps!

title: Lecture 4.6: Pattern match vs Types tests (cast)
post_text:
Hi all,

I am in doubt. What's advantages of the matching compare to types tests. It seems that they use the same constructions i.e. type determination.  What's the difference between them.

My idea is that the types tests use runtime info i.e. are applied during the program execution. The matching is done by compiler during the program compilation (aka templates in C++). Am I right or wrong?

title: Lecture 2.2: Currying
post_text:
Tagir,

you are right, they are only conceptually equivalent. The thing is, functions are values, but methods are not. In Week 4 you will see that functions are in fact objects while methods are, well, methods of objects (in the Java sense). So when you try to use a method as a value, Scala complains. You have to put the _ to make it understand you want a partially applied function instead.

However, if the compiler knows from its type analysis that it expects a function there, it will automatically transform the method into a function for you:
def f1(i : Int) = i + 1 
def f2 : Int => Int = i => i + 1
def foo(f : Int => Int) = f
foo(f1) // now it's fine
foo(f2) // also fine, of course
In fact,

foo(f1)
gets desugared to 
foo( x => f1(x))

Hope this helps!

title: Assignment 4 FAQ
post_text:
This is a FAQ from a previous version of this course (003 to be exact), some information could be out-of-date. It is authored by Pavel Lepin

May I use List methods from the standard library in this assignment?

You could give it a shot, but you would be at grader's mercy. None of the List methods are needed for this assignment (including sortBy / sortWith - Prof. Odersky demonstrated a simple implementation in the lectures, though a very practical mergesort implementation wouldn't be hard to put together either), and solutions based on pattern matching will be pretty concise.

Should I make my solutions tail-recursive?

until and codeBits are two functions where it would make sense (because it's a very natural way to express those two functions). Other than that, no.

Is empty list a singleton?

No.

Should combine process the list recursively until only a singleton is left?

No. combine performs one iteration of that process, decreasing the list size by one on the outside. The rest is the job for createCodeTree.

Should combine try to repair invalid inputs, such as duplicate characters in the trees to be combined?

No. You may assume valid input.

May I throw an exception if combine is passed a Nil?

No. Assignment instructions are unambiguous here.

until looks like an imperative loop. How do I implement something like that in a functional fashion?

Iteration is equivalent to tail-recursion. You might want to take a look at FAQ for assignment 1.

Do I really need to use mergeCodeTables in my implementation of convert?

Not really. The grader won't explicitly check for dependencies here. Using a certain approach to implementing mergeCodeTables will lead to a particularly elegant and succint version of convert, but that's not to say there cannot be elegant and succint implementations of convert that take a different approach.

When I'm traversing the code tree using a helper function, I have to pass an extra argument that is completely useless until I need it for a recursive call at the very end of the traversal. That kinda looks ugly.

Note that you helper function closes on everything in the outer function's scope... including its arguments.

Grader says my encoding is not minimal.

combine relies on a certain list invariant (described in the handout) for picking a pair of trees with the lowest weight. It's rather easy to overlook that combine also needs to maintain said invariant. If you fail to do so, your encoding will be sub-optimal.

Grader says my encoding is impossibly efficient.

There are great many ways to get this wrong. You should start looking for bugs by checking that the composition of your encode and decode is an identity (that is, you get your plaintext back by encoding then decoding).

Why would someText need 1919 bits to encode?!

That's just the name of the variable containing the plaintext to be encoded on the grader side.

What does it mean for an encoding to be optimal?

The short answer is, you don't need to worry about this, if you precisely follow the assignment instructions your encoding will be optimal.

A longer answer is, proper Huffman encoding is optimal in the following sense: if we assume that our sample string is representative of the true underlying distribution of character frequencies, and that individual characters/symbols are independent and identically distributed, then Huffman code for sufficiently long strings drawn from said distribution will minimize the expected length of codetext among all possible lossless encodings for said distribution. If you're interested in this topic, Wikipedia would be a decent start for further reading:

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Huffman_coding

There are many possible optimal trees. Which one should I pick?

The provided test for combine is an implicit specification of how exactly you should construct your tree. The same test will be run on the server, so make sure your implementation passes it.

What should I do if the sample text only has one unique character / no characters at all in it?

Feel free to blow up the grader's fridge. Huffman code is not particularly well-defined for these cases.

CodeTable is a very inefficient representation with awful lookups. Should I redefine it?

No. This is really just for demonstration purposes, so you should leave it be, despite its inefficiency.

OK. Other way around: 

def show(e: Expr, parens: Boolean = false): String = (e, parens) match {
    case (Number(n), _) => n.toString
    case (Var(name), _) => name
    case (Sum(e1, e2), false) => show(e1) + " + " + show(e2)
    case (Sum(e1, e2), true) => "(" + show(e1) + " + " + show(e2) + ")"
    case (Prod(e1, e2), _) => show(e1, true) + " * " + show(e2, true)
  }

title: 3.1 method evaluation syntax
post_text:
Found the tutorial on operators

"Any method which takes a single parameter can be used as an infix operator in Scala"

Union fits the requirements to become an infix operator. Question 2 is false because the method takes multiple arguments. There is also a new question of precedence and association. According to page 25 of the documentation (actual 33rd). All infix operators are by default left associative (((A method B) method C) method D) and have the same precedence.

2 Questions:

  1. "type operators ending in a colon ':' are right-associative; all other operators are left-associative." I don't understand what that would look like.
  2. * has precedence of + in Scala. In Lecture 4.2 how would Martin make the * function for his int Int or Float classes take precedence?

title: Question about including elements and then empty set.
post_text:
Hi,

I'm trying to understand something which is really puzzling me. Suppose I have a code as follows:
Where list01 can be a list of words or something similar and bigSet is some strange large set of elements.
The parameter name is some text. 

lazy val someSet : Set = {
    var set = new Empty
    var i = 0
    for (word <- list01) {
      for (someElement <- bigSet) {
        if (someElement.name.contains(word)) {
          set incl someElement
          println(i)
          i = i+1
        }
      }
    }
    println(set.isEmpty)
    set
  }          
  ...   
  func(someSet)
the output that I get is the list of numbers (due to the iteration in i) but at the end I get that set is empty. ( since it is a lazy val I do need to evaluate at least once later)

What am I missing here?.

Thank you!

PS: I really tried to modify the code so that it does not hints to the solution, and also, I wrote it imperatively so that the question becomes clear.

Please remove if this is not appropriate.

title: Question about including elements and then empty set.
post_text: The line set incl someElement is returning an updated Set but you are not putting it anywhere, so it is lost after each iteration.

title: Classes & Matching
post_text:
When I first learned about case classes I started making everything in my code a case class :) After a while it became a bit clearer when they fit well and when they probably don't. In general, any time you need a simple 'data class' to carry around values, with perhaps a very small number of methods or additional vals, then a case class is a good fit. They give you 'equals' and 'toString' for free which is great for data classes, and also a 'copy' method which can let you use them for the builder pattern (as in this pizza shop example). 

Some times when a case class probably isn't the best option:
- When you have a complex class with lots of calculated vals and / or methods.
- When you don't want the parameters for a class constructor to be publicly accessible (you can use 'private' on parameters to a case class but it's a bit of a code smell). 
- When you want your own custom companion object for a class (e.g. to provide a variety of apply methods for different parameter forms).
- When you need to test equality in a specialized way (e.g. allowing for round-off errors in numeric vals)

Hope that helps.

title: Huffman Singleton
post_text: Jenny, your option 1 is the correct one.  Singleton should return true if and only if the list contains exactly one tree.

title: Lecture 3.1 - Subtitles are wrong
post_text:
I've gone through the whole subtitles file.  Besides missing of the first 50 seconds, I also find that there are many irrelevant or duplicated subtitles included.  Below is the whole subtitles file I have fixed.  Though it is not perfect, and the first 50 seconds is still not included, it does at least in-sync with the current version of mp4.
=======================================================================
1
00:00:48,500 --> 00:00:53,591
In the last session, we have looked in
depth at a lot of different aspects of a

2
00:00:53,591 --> 00:00:57,581
single class.
What we're going to do in this session is

3
00:00:57,581 --> 00:01:03,000
generalize that so that we now look at
class hierarchies, where more than one

4
00:01:03,000 --> 00:01:05,780
class cooperates to achieve a certain
task.

5
00:01:06,000 --> 00:01:12,051
So, as a running example in this session,
we consider the task of writing a set of

6
00:01:12,051 --> 00:01:18,078
classes, that implement sets of integers.
And these integers set will be called

7
00:01:18,078 --> 00:01:24,064
inset and support two operations.
Include, to include an element x in the

8
00:01:24,064 --> 00:01:30,482
inset and contain, which is a test whether
an element x is a member of the set.

9
00:01:30,482 --> 00:01:35,477
So, to do that, I would open a fresh
worksheet.

10
00:01:35,477 --> 00:01:44,797
Call it insets and the definition of the
class here.

11
00:01:44,797 --> 00:01:50,476
What you see, what's particular is that
we've given you two definitions of

12
00:01:50,476 --> 00:01:54,731
functions, but they do not have a body.
The equals is missing and the body is

13
00:01:54,731 --> 00:01:59,685
missing, and that's permissible as long as
the class is abstract.

14
00:01:59,685 --> 00:02:05,498
If I would remove the abstract, I would
get a problem which would say, class inset

15
00:02:05,498 --> 00:02:11,219
needs to be abstract since method contains
is not defined and method include is not

16
00:02:11,219 --> 00:02:15,712
defined.
So, let's add the abstract again.

17
00:02:15,712 --> 00:02:23,577
So, you've seen that abstract glasses can
contain members which are missing in

18
00:02:23,577 --> 00:02:27,371
implementation.
On the other hand, we get instances of an

19
00:02:27,371 --> 00:02:34,668
abstract glass with the operator new.
So, if you would try that.

20
00:02:34,668 --> 00:02:42,809
Write here, new inset.
I will get an error, which says that the

21
00:02:42,809 --> 00:02:46,699
class inset is abstract and cannot be
instantiated.

22
00:02:46,699 --> 00:02:50,920
So, since inset is incomplete, how would
we implement it?

23
00:02:50,920 --> 00:02:56,674
Well, one way to do that would be using
the binary tree data structure.

24
00:02:56,674 --> 00:03:00,887
In the data structure, there are two types
of possible tree.

25
00:03:00,887 --> 00:03:07,306
A tree that represents the empty set and a
tree that consists of an integer and two

26
00:03:07,306 --> 00:03:13,882
subtrees and the idea would be that you
keep always the invariant that the trees

27
00:03:13,882 --> 00:03:17,421
are sorted.
So, that means if I give you an example

28
00:03:17,421 --> 00:03:24,079
here, we would have a tree, let's say,
with a seven, and that would have a two

29
00:03:24,079 --> 00:03:30,740
subtrees, and here, we would have maybe an
eleven, and here we would have five.

30
00:03:30,740 --> 00:03:40,701
And then, the eleven could have one, nine.
And the response would all be empty.

31
00:03:48,012 --> 00:03:53,024
So, that's an example of a binary tree.
And the invariant that we want to maintain

32
00:03:53,024 --> 00:03:58,337
is that for each node, the nodes on the
right-hand side of this node, all have

33
00:03:58,337 --> 00:04:01,058
integer values that are higher than the
node.

34
00:04:01,058 --> 00:04:06,089
Whereas, the nodes on the left-hand side
all have values that are less than the

35
00:04:06,089 --> 00:04:09,091
node.
Now, that this will make it easier later

36
00:04:09,091 --> 00:04:15,043
on to implement, the contains test that
determines whether a given value is in the

37
00:04:15,043 --> 00:04:18,516
tree.
So, let's start with the empty tree here.

38
00:04:18,516 --> 00:04:21,389
The empty tree is very simple to
implement, we would simply say that

39
00:04:21,389 --> 00:04:27,387
contains is always false, because the
empty tree does, cannot contain any value.

40
00:04:27,387 --> 00:04:32,238
Whereas, include is a method that returns
an inset.

41
00:04:32,238 --> 00:04:37,706
So, what set would it return?
Well, it would return a non-empty set to

42
00:04:37,706 --> 00:04:43,480
be defined, that contains the given
element and two empty subtrees.

43
00:04:43,480 --> 00:04:51,093
So, going from the empty set to an include
set, would give us a set like that, that

44
00:04:51,093 --> 00:04:55,400
contains a single node and two empty
subnodes.

45
00:04:55,400 --> 00:05:08,007
Let's put that class into the worksheet.
Now, it still remains to define what a

46
00:05:08,007 --> 00:05:14,316
non-empty set would be.
A non-empty set in that implementation,

47
00:05:14,316 --> 00:05:20,291
would be represented by a class non-empty
that takes an element, that's the integer

48
00:05:20,291 --> 00:05:26,276
stored in the node, and the left and the
right subtree which is, in each case, an

49
00:05:26,276 --> 00:05:29,283
inset.
And the implementation of contains and

50
00:05:29,283 --> 00:05:33,251
includes now makes use of the sorted
criterion of trees.

51
00:05:33,251 --> 00:05:38,236
So that means that, for contains, we
always have to look only in one of the

52
00:05:38,236 --> 00:05:41,310
possible subtrees.
If the given number x is less than the

53
00:05:41,310 --> 00:05:46,308
current element value, then we know we
will have to look in the left subtree

54
00:05:46,308 --> 00:05:49,304
here.
Whereas, if it's greater, we know we will

55
00:05:49,304 --> 00:05:54,296
have to look in the right subtree.
If it's neither less nor greater than, it

56
00:05:54,296 --> 00:05:57,317
must be equal.
And in this case, we have found the

57
00:05:57,317 --> 00:06:00,322
element.
The include method follows a similar

58
00:06:00,322 --> 00:06:04,264
algorithm.
If the element to be added is less than

59
00:06:04,264 --> 00:06:09,255
the element in the tree then we need to
include it in the left subtree.

60
00:06:09,255 --> 00:06:13,272
If it is greater, we need to include it in
the right subtree.

61
00:06:13,272 --> 00:06:19,232
And otherwise, the element is already in
the tree and we can return the tree as is.

62
00:06:19,232 --> 00:06:21,153
There's nothing that needs to be added.

63
00:06:21,153 --> 00:06:26,205
One important aspect here is that we are
still purely functional, there is no

64
00:06:26,205 --> 00:06:29,853
mutation.
So, when I say, we include an element in

65
00:06:29,853 --> 00:06:34,967
the left subtree, what I really mean is
that we create a new tree that contains

66
00:06:34,967 --> 00:06:40,701
the previous element of the tree and a
larger left subtree, where x is included

67
00:06:40,701 --> 00:06:47,162
in the previous left subtree and the
current subtree on the right.

68
00:06:47,162 --> 00:06:55,129
So, visually, if I would say, include the
number three in the tree that we see here.

69
00:06:55,129 --> 00:07:03,008
Then, what would happen is I would create
a new node three with two empty subtrees.

70
00:07:03,008 --> 00:07:11,290
That subtree would be the left subtree of
a new node with element five, and an empty

71
00:07:11,290 --> 00:07:17,253
right-hand subtree.
And, finally, my tree would be a new tree

72
00:07:17,253 --> 00:07:23,427
with the, as before the node seven is the
node and the same as the right-hand side

73
00:07:23,427 --> 00:07:26,600
tree here.
So, we see that now, we really have two

74
00:07:26,600 --> 00:07:30,093
trees, the old one and the new one after
the include.

75
00:07:30,093 --> 00:07:37,205
The two trees share the sub tree here on
the right hand side but they differ in the

76
00:07:37,205 --> 00:07:43,300
left tree, where, on the new tree, we have
a three in the left most bottom corner

77
00:07:43,300 --> 00:07:47,220
whereas, for the old tree, we just have
two empty trees.

78
00:07:47,220 --> 00:07:56,411
One way these data structures are called,
are called persistent data structures,

79
00:07:56,411 --> 00:08:06,177
because even when we do changes or
so-called changes in quotes to a data

80
00:08:06,177 --> 00:08:11,034
structure, the old version of the data
structure is still maintained.

81
00:08:11,034 --> 00:08:14,905
It doesn't go away.
And persistent data structures are

82
00:08:14,905 --> 00:08:21,239
actually one of the cornerstone of scaling
functional programming up to collections

83
00:08:21,239 --> 00:08:25,018
and the like.
So, let's take the definition of class

84
00:08:25,018 --> 00:08:33,205
non-empty and also, add it in the
worksheet so that we can test something.

85
00:08:33,205 --> 00:08:43,816
So now, instead of new inset, I would
create a set by saying, well, if this

86
00:08:43,816 --> 00:08:53,838
would be, maybe, new non-empty of three,
new empty, new empty, so it would be my

87
00:08:53,838 --> 00:09:01,133
first set.
I would give me non-empty set, and I could

88
00:09:01,133 --> 00:09:12,202
then write things like include a four, and
that would give me an inset, which is

89
00:09:12,202 --> 00:09:17,195
another non-empty set.
Now, before we go further, let's add a two

90
00:09:17,195 --> 00:09:24,136
string operation to our set so that we can
actually see what sets we have created

91
00:09:24,136 --> 00:09:27,172
here.
We need two definitions of two string.

92
00:09:27,172 --> 00:09:35,151
One in empty, and one in non-empty.
For empty, how would we define two string?

93
00:09:35,151 --> 00:09:43,196
Well, let me just define it in a very
minimalistic way to give you a period.

94
00:09:43,196 --> 00:09:51,142
For non-empty, I want to define two string
as follows.

95
00:09:51,142 --> 00:09:59,597
I want to say it should be an open brace
followed by the, the description of the

96
00:09:59,597 --> 00:10:06,193
left element followed by the, sorry, as
follows.

97
00:10:06,193 --> 00:10:15,249
It should be an open brace followed by the
string value of the left subtree and the

98
00:10:15,249 --> 00:10:22,150
element in the middle in the right
subtree, and then, a closing brace.

99
00:10:22,208 --> 00:10:30,136
If we do that, then we see that here we
get a sort of visual representation of our

100
00:10:30,136 --> 00:10:34,144
tree.
So, the first t1 would be an element tree,

101
00:10:34,144 --> 00:10:40,436
and empty tree to the left and right.
Whereas, t2 would be the root of t2 would

102
00:10:40,436 --> 00:10:46,142
be three, the right subtree is a tree that
has four as its element.

103
00:10:46,142 --> 00:10:52,839
So, we see that this tree, in particular,
has maintained the invariant that trees

104
00:10:52,839 --> 00:10:57,671
are sorted.
So, one new thing you see here is that

105
00:10:57,671 --> 00:11:05,152
both empty and non-empty extend inset.
So, extension means that these two classes

106
00:11:05,152 --> 00:11:12,198
are subclasses of the base class inset.
One consequence of that is that the types,

107
00:11:12,198 --> 00:11:16,216
empty and non-empty, conform to the type
inset.

108
00:11:16,216 --> 00:11:24,189
What that means is that an object of type
empty or non-empty can be used wherever an

109
00:11:24,189 --> 00:11:32,129
object of type inset is required.
Some more terminology.

110
00:11:32,129 --> 00:11:37,215
We say, insert is the super class of empty
and non-empty, and empty and nonempty are

111
00:11:37,215 --> 00:11:42,214
the subclasses of inset.
In Scala, any class that you can define

112
00:11:42,214 --> 00:11:47,164
extends another class.
Even for a class like rational, where you

113
00:11:47,164 --> 00:11:51,142
didn't give an extends clause, there is a
superclass.

114
00:11:51,142 --> 00:11:56,191
So, if no explicit superclass is given,
the standard class object in the Java

115
00:11:56,191 --> 00:12:01,590
package, Java language is assumed.
Object is the root class of all Java

116
00:12:01,590 --> 00:12:05,678
class, and also of all user-defined Scala
classes.

117
00:12:05,678 --> 00:12:10,809
If you take the direct superclass of a
class and then its superclass and so on,

118
00:12:10,809 --> 00:12:15,784
so all the direct and indirect super
classes of a class C, then these are

119
00:12:15,784 --> 00:12:20,937
called that the base classes of C.
So, for instance, the base classes of

120
00:12:20,937 --> 00:12:27,863
class non-empty or insert and then object.
So, what you've seen in the example is

121
00:12:27,863 --> 00:12:33,234
that the definitions of, contains and
including classes empty and non-empty,

122
00:12:33,234 --> 00:12:39,228
implement the abstraction functions in the
base class insert, they were not to be

123
00:12:39,228 --> 00:12:44,909
find in insert but they, they are
implemented in the subclasses, empty and

124
00:12:44,909 --> 00:12:49,196
nonempty.
It's also possible to redefine an existing

125
00:12:49,196 --> 00:12:56,118
non-abstract definition of a superclass in
a subclass, but then, you have to use

126
00:12:56,118 --> 00:12:59,215
overwrite.
So, in this example here, you see the, the

127
00:12:59,215 --> 00:13:03,176
difference.
If you write in the base class, foo = one.

128
00:13:03,178 --> 00:13:09,169
And then you redefine foo in the subclass,
which, which extends base, then you have

129
00:13:09,169 --> 00:13:14,128
to put an overwrite.
So, let me demonstrate that to you in this

130
00:13:14,128 --> 00:13:17,494
worksheet.
We have two classes, a base class and a

131
00:13:17,494 --> 00:13:21,175
subclass.
And each of these classes have two members

132
00:13:21,175 --> 00:13:25,852
named foo and bar.
The bar member in class sub, implements

133
00:13:25,852 --> 00:13:30,216
the abstract definition of bar in class
base.

134
00:13:30,216 --> 00:13:37,500
Whereas, the full member replaces the
concrete definition of who in class base.

135
00:13:37,500 --> 00:13:44,048
If a member replaces or overwrites the
definition in a superclass, then the

136
00:13:44,048 --> 00:13:49,425
override here is mandatory.
So let's say, say I leave that out,

137
00:13:49,425 --> 00:13:52,610
compile.
And we will get an error which says,

138
00:13:52,610 --> 00:13:58,199
overwriting might method foo in class base
the method foo here needs an overwrite

139
00:13:58,199 --> 00:14:00,160
modifier.
So, why is that?

140
00:14:00,160 --> 00:14:03,223
Why here Scala is actually more picky than
Java?

141
00:14:03,223 --> 00:14:09,133
Well, the reason is that sometimes we do
not really know what methods you do

142
00:14:09,133 --> 00:14:11,222
inherit.
So, you might actually accidentally

143
00:14:11,222 --> 00:14:17,159
overwrite a method in a base class, and in
that case, is good that you have to be

144
00:14:17,159 --> 00:14:21,155
explicit about it.
There's an added benefit namely when you

145
00:14:21,155 --> 00:14:26,213
intent to overwrite but let's say, you
can't remember the name correctly or you

146
00:14:26,213 --> 00:14:30,217
get the numbers of parameters wrong, or
things like that.

147
00:14:30,217 --> 00:14:35,693
So, if I write something like that,
overwrite the foo two, then I get an error

148
00:14:35,693 --> 00:14:38,597
again.
Where we say, method foo2 overwrites

149
00:14:38,597 --> 00:14:41,777
nothing.
So, in that case the ovewrite will give me

150
00:14:41,777 --> 00:14:47,422
the opposite protection results when I
write overwrite then I want to be sure

151
00:14:47,422 --> 00:14:50,990
that, in fact, I do overwrite another
definition.

152
00:14:50,990 --> 00:14:56,889
For methods that implement definitions in
base classes, the overwrite is optional,

153
00:14:56,889 --> 00:15:01,446
you can write it if you want to.
And, in that case, you will be warned in

154
00:15:01,446 --> 00:15:04,930
the same way.
So, if I write part two, I will get an

155
00:15:04,930 --> 00:15:08,324
error as before.
But you don't have to do that.

156
00:15:08,324 --> 00:15:13,510
So, you don't need to write the overwrite,
you could just write def bar.

157
00:15:13,510 --> 00:15:16,744
And that's usually less noisy, so,
preferred.

158
00:15:16,744 --> 00:15:22,263
So, let's get back to the insets example.
One thing to improve would be the status

159
00:15:22,263 --> 00:15:26,937
of the empty inset class.
You could argue that there's really only a

160
00:15:26,937 --> 00:15:31,028
single empty inset.
So, it seems overkill to have the user

161
00:15:31,028 --> 00:15:35,614
create many instances of it.
And, in fact, that's very easy to achieve

162
00:15:35,614 --> 00:15:38,826
in Scala.
You just use an object definition instead

163
00:15:38,826 --> 00:15:45,164
of a class definition as before.
So, this object definition is exactly the

164
00:15:45,164 --> 00:15:51,155
same as the class definition, except that
instead of the keyword class, you use

165
00:15:51,155 --> 00:15:55,126
object.
And that will define a single item object

166
00:15:55,126 --> 00:15:58,204
named empty.
There is only one of them and you don't

167
00:15:58,204 --> 00:16:02,137
need or can create that explicitly with
new.

168
00:16:02,137 --> 00:16:07,190
So the object empty simply exists,
technically it will be created the first

169
00:16:07,190 --> 00:16:12,223
time you reference it.
Your reference to the object simply by

170
00:16:12,223 --> 00:16:17,373
naming it with empty.
So, empty here and here replaces the

171
00:16:17,373 --> 00:16:26,168
creation of new MT that we had before.
In terms of evaluation, singleton objects

172
00:16:26,168 --> 00:16:30,181
are values.
So, empty is already a value, there's no

173
00:16:30,181 --> 00:16:34,137
evaluation step that needs to be
performed.

174
00:16:34,137 --> 00:16:38,801
So, since we're already looking at objects
let's, take a quick excursion and look at

175
00:16:38,801 --> 00:16:44,410
what a program would be in Scala So far,
we've executed all Scala code from the

176
00:16:44,410 --> 00:16:49,206
RPEL or the worksheet, but it's also
possible to create standalone

177
00:16:49,206 --> 00:16:52,652
applications.
Each as applications would contain an

178
00:16:52,652 --> 00:16:55,658
object and that object contains a main
method.

179
00:16:55,658 --> 00:17:00,674
Let's look at this with the mandatory
Hello World Program written in Scala.

180
00:17:00,674 --> 00:17:03,579
So, you would write an object, name it
Hello.

181
00:17:03,579 --> 00:17:08,579
It has a main method, then as in java,
that main method will have to take an

182
00:17:08,579 --> 00:17:11,941
array of string, you can ignore that for
the time being.

183
00:17:11,941 --> 00:17:16,183
And the body of the main method would be a
println with Hello World.

184
00:17:16,183 --> 00:17:21,878
Once you compile this program, you can
start it from the command line simply with

185
00:17:21,878 --> 00:17:26,366
Scala, and then Hello.
Or you could also use Java and Hello, they

186
00:17:26,366 --> 00:17:28,738
would do the same thing in this case.

187
00:17:28,738 --> 00:17:31,927
So, let me demonstrate that in
Eclipse.

188
00:17:31,927 --> 00:17:35,367
So, we create in the Week three package,

189
00:17:35,367 --> 00:17:42,407
this time not a worksheet but a Scala
object, call it, Hello.

190
00:17:45,363 --> 00:17:51,440
And then, we have to add the main function
which takes this.

191
00:17:52,368 --> 00:18:04,796
And it would print something.
We can run this program as a program using

192
00:18:04,796 --> 00:18:10,032
the green arrow here.
So, we will run it as a Scala application,

193
00:18:10,032 --> 00:18:16,647
and we see on the console, Hello World.
So, that's how you would run full programs

194
00:18:16,647 --> 00:18:19,991
in Scala from Eclipse.

195
00:18:19,991 --> 00:18:24,551
So, let's do an exercise.
The task is to add a new method to our

196
00:18:24,551 --> 00:18:29,865
insert class hierarchy.
The method should take the union of a set

197
00:18:29,865 --> 00:18:35,126
and some other set.
So, you should extend the class insert to

198
00:18:35,126 --> 00:18:40,600
be the following abstract class and
implement that.

199
00:18:40,600 --> 00:18:51,596
So, how we would we go about that?
Let's first start with the abstract class.

200
00:18:51,596 --> 00:19:00,027
So, here's the signature of union.
And now, we get two errors because we have

201
00:19:00,027 --> 00:19:05,751
to implement it in the two sub classes.
So, let's start with empty.

202
00:19:05,751 --> 00:19:11,269
What would the union of an empty set and
some other set be?

203
00:19:11,269 --> 00:19:19,176
Well, that's very simple, empty set union
some other set is always the other set.

204
00:19:19,176 --> 00:19:21,273
So, for non-empty sets, how would we

205
00:19:21,273 --> 00:19:28,189
define union in this case?
Well, the idea is that we split the set

206
00:19:28,189 --> 00:19:33,209
into its constituents.
So, we have the left inset, the right

207
00:19:33,209 --> 00:19:37,254
inset, and the element.
Let's form the union instead from

208
00:19:37,254 --> 00:19:41,250
something that is smaller.
So, one of the subsets.

209
00:19:41,250 --> 00:19:48,243
Let's start with left and two union right.
So, that would give us the set without the

210
00:19:48,243 --> 00:19:53,213
initial element.
Then, let's finally give the union of the

211
00:19:53,213 --> 00:20:00,797
other set.
And as a last action, action, let's

212
00:20:00,797 --> 00:20:07,246
include the element back into the set.
So, the new union has all the parts of the

213
00:20:07,246 --> 00:20:13,190
previous ones that contain the left set,
it contains the right set, it contains the

214
00:20:13,190 --> 00:20:18,208
element, and it contains the other set.
So, it's very easy to convince ourselves

215
00:20:18,208 --> 00:20:23,885
that indeed the two the, the, the results
set here would have all the elements of

216
00:20:23,885 --> 00:20:26,639
the union and would have no other
elements.

217
00:20:26,639 --> 00:20:31,848
But there's another concern and that is
well, how do we know that this recursion

218
00:20:31,848 --> 00:20:36,565
actually terminates, because after all,
union calls union and we've seen already,

219
00:20:36,565 --> 00:20:40,239
cases where calling yourself again would
not terminate.

220
00:20:40,239 --> 00:20:45,251
So, the argument you, we could make here
is to say, well, every call to union is

221
00:20:45,251 --> 00:20:50,197
actually on something that is smaller than
the set we started with.

222
00:20:50,197 --> 00:20:55,279
The first call to union was on the left
subtree here, and obviously, that set is

223
00:20:55,279 --> 00:21:00,563
smaller than the whole non-empty set.
The second call to union was on the union

224
00:21:00,563 --> 00:21:06,510
in left and right, and then again contains
one element less than the full set that we

225
00:21:06,510 --> 00:21:10,583
have here.
Because every union, every quarter union

226
00:21:10,583 --> 00:21:15,639
is on a set that is smaller, it follows
that, at some point, we have to reach

227
00:21:15,639 --> 00:21:19,192
zero.
And if the set is zero, then we fall back

228
00:21:19,192 --> 00:21:24,966
to the case of empty sets where the union
is immediate, we just return the other

229
00:21:24,966 --> 00:21:28,179
set.
So, that's how we convince ourselves that

230
00:21:28,179 --> 00:21:33,169
the union that we, operations that we do
here are in fact terminating.

231
00:21:33,169 --> 00:21:38,223
And once those are terminating, we can
safely add element back with an include

232
00:21:38,223 --> 00:21:43,777
operation as before, okay.
What object oriented language is do in

233
00:21:43,777 --> 00:21:47,875
this case?
Scala included, is to use th dynamic

234
00:21:47,875 --> 00:21:52,969
method dispatch model.
That means, that the code that's invoked

235
00:21:52,969 --> 00:21:58,000
by a method call depends on the runtime
type of the object, that contains the

236
00:21:58,000 --> 00:22:01,624
method.
I believe that's best shown in an example.

237
00:22:01,624 --> 00:22:05,400
So, let's say, you have the code empty
contains one.

238
00:22:05,400 --> 00:22:11,658
What do you do?
Well, you look up the contains method in

239
00:22:11,658 --> 00:22:19,166
empty.
Remember that was, remember that was an

240
00:22:19,166 --> 00:22:32,499
object empty and we had a def contains y =
False, that was its definition.

241
00:22:32,499 --> 00:22:37,467
So, looking up that method and performing
the necessary substitutions, we get False.

242
00:22:37,467 --> 00:22:39,467
Here is another evaluation using

243
00:22:39,467 --> 00:22:42,663
non-empty.
We would have to set non-empty seven,

244
00:22:42,663 --> 00:22:47,096
empty, empty, and we ask whether it
contains seven.

245
00:22:47,096 --> 00:22:52,683
So, if you look back at the definition of
contain and non-empty, that's what we see

246
00:22:52,683 --> 00:22:56,134
here.
And if we apply our substitution rules,

247
00:22:56,134 --> 00:23:02,164
then it means this call of the method will
be replaced by the right hand side of the

248
00:23:02,164 --> 00:23:08,156
contains method, which you see here.
And at the same time, the substitutions of

249
00:23:08,156 --> 00:23:13,164
the parameters of the class, and the
method, and the self-reference.

250
00:23:13,164 --> 00:23:20,127
So, the three elements that you see here.
If we perform the substitution, we arrive

251
00:23:20,127 --> 00:23:25,243
at this expression here.
So, instead of x and ln we have we, we

252
00:23:25,243 --> 00:23:31,696
have we see seven in each case, and
instead of the, this, we see new non,

253
00:23:31,696 --> 00:23:37,141
non-empty seven, empty, empty.
If you perform the simplification, we get

254
00:23:37,141 --> 00:23:43,147
that seven is neither less nor greater
than seven, so we fall into the else case,

255
00:23:43,147 --> 00:23:48,167
and we get true.
So, for the end of this session, here's

256
00:23:48,167 --> 00:23:52,330
something to ponder.
You've seen that dynamic dispatch of

257
00:23:52,330 --> 00:23:57,759
methods in object oriented languages is
actually quite similar to calls of high

258
00:23:57,759 --> 00:24:01,069
order functions in pure functional
languages.

259
00:24:01,069 --> 00:24:07,074
The similarity is that in both cases, the
code that gets executed on a functional

260
00:24:07,074 --> 00:24:13,093
method call is not known statically, it's
not apparent from the name or the type of

261
00:24:13,093 --> 00:24:18,499
the thing you called, but it is determined
by the runtime value that is passed.

262
00:24:18,499 --> 00:24:23,694
So, it's a fair question whether we can
implement one concept in terms of the

263
00:24:23,694 --> 00:24:26,807
other.
Can we maybe implement objects in terms of

264
00:24:26,807 --> 00:24:31,637
high order functions or can we implement
higher order functions in terms of

265
00:24:31,637 --> 00:24:34,257
objects?
Or can we maybe go both ways?

266
00:24:34,257 --> 00:24:39,842
It's a question that is fairly open and
that has a range of possible answers.

267
00:24:39,842 --> 00:24:46,106
So, I just let you with that think a
little bit, bit about it and maybe discuss

268
00:24:46,106 --> 00:24:47,113
with others.

title: Lecture 4.2 - Objects Everywhere - Wrong Subtitles
post_text:
I find that the subtitles of Lecture 4.2 - Objects Everywhere is wrong.  It seems that the video was updated since 18:39, and thus the subtitles become incorrect since that moment because not being updated accordingly.  Below is my edited subtitles since 00:18:39,287 (subtitle #214).  You can just replace this to your subtitles file.

Besides, the order of videos in lecture 4 should be 4.2 -> 4.1 --> 4.3 --> 4.4 --> 4.5...

=====================================================
214
00:18:39,287 --> 00:18:44,309
original subtraction.
However, that's still not sufficient

215
00:18:44,309 --> 00:18:51,136
because the "that" argument here could be zero, in which
case we wouldn't be allowed to take the predecessor.

216
00:18:51,136 --> 00:18:58,540
So, we have to treat that case specially.
So, if "that" is zero, what can we return?

217
00:18:58,540 --> 00:19:04,914
Well, in that case we could just return the number itself,
because a number minus zero is the number itself.

218
00:19:04,914 --> 00:19:10,321
So, we return this,
and else we return the expression we started with.

219
00:19:10,321 --> 00:19:16,345
So, what we've seen here is a complete and rather
concise treatment of natural numbers from first principles.

220
00:19:16,345 --> 00:19:22,100
We didn't need any primitive types to produce that.
While we've seen that we use Booleans,

221
00:19:22,100 --> 00:19:28,209
but you've seen already before that
Booleans also can be encoded as just classes.

222
00:19:28,209 --> 00:19:38,209
There's a technical term for this,
it's called Peano numbers.

223
00:19:38,209 --> 00:19:42,209
Starting from Peano numbers,
we could then construct further data types

224
00:19:42,209 --> 00:19:46,209
such as integers including negative numbers,
and even floating point numbers.

Then added this to the tests:

title: Problem submitting assignment

title: Encoding if the Huffman tree is just a Leaf
post_text: Let's say we have a text "aaa", then the Huffman tree would be simply a Leaf('a', 3), thus no left/right Fork of the tree. So which bit do we use to encode character 'a'? 0 or 1 or either?

title: Test Cases for forall and exist
post_text:
Hi,

I am getting confused about what the forall and exists tests would look like. I am using a function to determine whether a set element is even, However, I am not clear about what the output should be. My understanding is that if a set has even and odd numbers, then the following 
forAll(setOfEvenAndOdd,isEvenFunction)

would return false, but 
exists(setOfEvenAndOdd,isEvenFunction)

should return true. Am i right in my assumption?

title: There is a mistake in the video "Lecture 4.6 - Pattrern Matching"
post_text:
Hi Ruslan,

title: Style question: do we need Boolean "classification functions"?

title: Test Cases for forall and exist
post_text:
Yep - that's right.  You might find it easier to state the test in words first, and then when you've got that down turn it into code...
- "given a set with even and odd integers, testing if all members of the set are even should return false"
- "given a set of even and odd integers, testing if there exists an even value in the set should return true'
Then the "given..." part describes the set which you can turn into an indicator function, and the "test..." part describes the predicate which you want to pass to forAll or exists

title: I probably missing something with the encoding function

still , missing something having the CodeTree as one of the parameters why do we need the text in order to build the List[Bit]
i.e  for 
val t2 = Fork(Fork(Leaf('a',2), Leaf('b',3), List('a','b'), 5), Leaf('d',4), List('a','b','d'), 9)
we can construct the List[Bit] using pattern matching such as 
def run(subTree:CodeTree,acc:List[Bit]): List[Bit] ={
      subTree match {
        case Leaf(_,_) => acc
        case Fork(l,r,_,_) => run(l,acc:::List(0)):::run(r,acc:::List(1))
      }
    }
and produce List(0, 0, 0, 1, 1) without the text:List[Char] (the 2nd param to encode func)

title: mistake in sample tree picture in assignment 4
post_text:
Agreed that given our explanation on how to combine trees it should be swapped. But that's not the only way to construct minimal trees. It doesn't matter if you swap nodes like what happened in this example.

Another algorithm for constructing Huffman trees is to just take the 2 subtrees with the lowest weight in the combine step without sorting the tree again every time. But then you need to find those 2 first so it's easier to always sort your remaining list again and take the first 2 in the list.

title: Lecture 3.1 and Lecture 3.2 — How Null and Nothing can subclass all the other classes?
post_text:
I think it's more a "legal fiction" that the scala compiler and type system allow, rather than some implementation like "class Nothing extends _ {}" (which of course is not valid). In terms of Java and the JVM it's of course not possible to have a type that's a subclass of every other type, since multiple inheritance is forbidden.

Doing runtime testing of classOf[Nothing] using Class.isAssignableFrom shows that the running JVM at least doesn't believe that Nothing is a subclass of anything other than Object.

I also learned that the running JVM believes that classOf[Any] and classOf[AnyRef] are the same as classOf[Object] (or at least, they all .equals each other).

title: How to generalize a binary tree set, such as TweetSet?
post_text:
The structure of TweetSet in assignment 3 is valuable enough that I  might want to generalize it. For example, imagine I want to have a binary tree for a new type "IntChar"

class IntChar(val num: Int, val letter: Char){
	override def toString: String = ...
}
abstract class IntCharSet {
	def isEmpty: Boolean
	def incl(x: IntChar): IntCharSet
	def remove(x: IntChar): IntCharSet
	def contains(x: IntChar): Boolean
	def filter(p: IntChar => Boolean): IntCharSet 
	def filterAcc(p: IntChar => Boolean, acc: IntCharSet): IntCharSet
	def union(other: IntCharSet): IntCharSet	
	def mostValuable: IntChar
	def descendingByVal: IntCharList
}
as a reminder, here is the Tweet, TweetSet definitions:
class Tweet(val user: String, val text: String, val retweets: Int) {
  override def toString: String = ...
}
abstract class TweetSet {
  def isEmpty: Boolean
  def incl(tweet: Tweet): TweetSet
  def remove(tweet: Tweet): TweetSet
  def contains(tweet: Tweet): Boolean
  def filter(p: Tweet => Boolean): TweetSet = filterAcc(p, new Empty)
  def filterAcc(p: Tweet => Boolean, acc: TweetSet): TweetSet
  def union(that: TweetSet): TweetSet
  def mostRetweeted: Tweet
  def descendingByRetweet: TweetList 
}
Notice the similarity in structure between Tweet and IntChar and between TweetSet and IntCharSet. It would be great to generalize this, using a more abstract type:
class compositeType(val key: T1, val value: T2, val otherAttribute: T3) {
  override def toString: String = ...
}
abstract class compositeSet {
  def isEmpty: Boolean
  def incl(x: compositeType): compositeSet
  def remove(x: compositeType): compositeSet
  def contains(x: compositeType): Boolean
  def filter(p: compositeType => Boolean): compositeSet
  def filterAcc(p: compositeType => Boolean, acc: compositeSet: compositeSet
  def union(that: compositeSet): compositeSet
  def mostSomething: compositeType
  def descendingBySomeValue: compositeSet
}
Where I have left  the types T1, T2, T3 to be defined on instantiating the compositeType. In addition, I might want to change the number of additionalAttribute types (e.g. have 0, 1, 2, or more in addition to "key" and "value").

Is there a way to do this in scala (or rather, what is the recommended way)? Also, is there some way to make the names of methods such as "mostSomething" and "descendingBySomeValue" , such that I can give them meaningful names ("mostRetweeted") upon instantiation?


PS: I apologize if this is to be answered in week 4 lectures (which I haven't had the time to watch yet)

title: Encoding if the Huffman tree is just a Leaf
post_text: I'd argue that if a huffman tree contains only a single character, the encoding should be an empty List().

title: Encoding if the Huffman tree is just a Leaf
post_text: If empty, how would one know what character the tree encodes?  I don't know if it's specified but since most computers store in multiples of 8 bit bytes, one might need two bits anyway.  0 could specify a valid character and 1 would be used for padding.  For larger trees with more bits per code, I'm not sure what is done for padding.

title: Encoding if the Huffman tree is just a Leaf

title: efficiency of TweetSet binary tree
post_text:
In the assignment, we represent tweets in a binary search tree. Why do we do this? It seems that most of the methods we are to write don't make use of the tree's organization (i.e. we don't traverse the tree using binary search with respect to the tree's key) and thus don't take advantage of a BST's performance. 

Is there a particular reason why this data structure was chosen?

title: Encoding if the Huffman tree is just a Leaf
post_text:
Actually, after thinking about this a bit more, I'd suggest that just a leaf is not a valid top-level encoding, and maybe the encode/decode functions should only accept a Fork parameter, rather than a CodeTree.

We could catch and prevent this at the tree-creation stage if we did something like this:
tree match {
    case l:Leaf => new Fork(l, l, l.char, l.weight)
    case _ => tree
}

title: Reversing a list
post_text:
I'm running into a couple places where my lists are coming out in reverse order.

Unless I'm missing something, there is no easy way to append to a list - which makes sense given the immutable linked-list structure.

This results in my helper-function accumulator ending up in the wrong order though. I solved this in decode() by using a String for the accumulator, and converting to a list only when I hit the stopping condition - but that still doesn't feel right.

I'm running into the same problem now with a list of bits that I'm accumulating as I write encode().

Am I missing something here? I was thinking I could pass just the single next character down to the next level of recursion, and then build the list as I unwind, but that would prevent tail-recursion, and looks messy - (especially since there isn't always a next character when encoding - so I'd need to check for null)

Has anybody else run into the same scenarios? Am I missing something obvious?

title: Lecture 4.6, expr trait, how to implement simplify?
post_text: The expression matching can drill down into sub-objects of the item being matched. The simplify for x * z + y * z would need to happen at the level of the + operator - so you're looking for a plus operator that contains two multiplication operators - you should be able to match for that - and you can then check for operands that are equal (z) between the two subexpressions.

title: Reversing a list
post_text: In some cases, list.reverse is a good call. It has O(n) performance, but only needs to be applied once, so probably has little impact on the overall performance.  Using tail recursion is the best from a performance view, but it isn't always simple to use tail recursion.  The :+ operator is O(n) and has to be applied repeatedly, so may end up being $$ O(n^2) $$ or worse.

title: StyleCheck returning Cyclomatic complexity exceeds 10
post_text:
Generally, cyclomatic complexity applies to a single function or method. The best way to think about it is as a measure of the number of different execution paths that can be taken through a given code block. If you get a number over 10 for a method, look at the method and see if it still makes sense to you. Ask the guy next to you for a code review - I can almost guarantee he'll have to squint hard to make sense of it.

That said, some guys that I work with routinely get cyclo numbers over 20.  One guy in particular writes code so convoluted that IntelliJ Idea's cyclo check will bomb out and give a message saying there are to many paths for the machine to even count. Personally, I think guys that write spaghetti should have their pay docked; of course management tends to like them because they can hammer out an Italian feast every day... :)

title: createCodeTree(someText) - Test timeout: aborted after 40 seconds
post_text:
try to check your createCodeTree method for extreme cases. (Or just test with a tree consisting of more than one Fork and 2 Leafs). My first guess is that one of your checks to end recursion somewhere is incorrect so that your program keeps looping.

Look for a case that does not change anything in the recursive call.

Simple example to give an idea what could be wrong:
// this function calculates 2^x
def powerOfTwo(x: Int) : Int = {
  def powerOfTwo(a: Int, result: int): Int = a match {
    case 0 => doSomething(a, result)
    case 1 => result * 2
    case _ => doSomething(a-1, result * 2)
  }
  
  powerOfTwo(x, 1)
}

For any "x" larger than 0 this will give the correct result. But if a == 0 it will keep calling doSomething again and again ...
Your method (or one of the methods that it uses) has a case like that where nothing changes.

About insertion sort: since you have 1 element and an already sorted list, insertion sort is about the best you can do.

title: Reversing a list
post_text: Sometimes functions with accumulators indeed reverse your list; this is because you see the first element of the original list first, which means you put it first into (i.e. on the bottom of) the output list. In this cases you have to call List.reverse in the end.

title: Lecture 3.1 and Lecture 3.2 — How Null and Nothing can subclass all the other classes?
post_text:
Yes, Nothing is a subclass of all classes, and Null is a subclass of all reference classes. Yes, they break all rules of Scala, but Null and Nothing are special built-in classes that you could not define in Scala itself.

Matt, the JVM is not a good place to check how things behave in Scala. Likewise you wouldn't look into binary files to understand type coersions in C, for example. Nothing in the JVM level has to obey the JVM rules, so it is made a subclass of Object. After all, there is no object typed as Nothing, so there is no restriction on what arbitrary things we can do to satisfy the JVM. Likewise, the only element of Null is null (null in the Java sense). Also, AnyRef is an alias for java.lang.Object, so it is only logical they are equal, and finally Any is only a high-level Scala concept, since value classes are not objects in the JVM.

title: Is my Huffman `decode` method too complex?
post_text:
I'd say around 19 is too much. How well guarded is your implementation against invalid bit-streams?
I don't guard against any invalid bit-stream for example. So if there is are no more bits left and have still not reached a Leaf my solution will most likely throw some kind of runtime exception/error.

I use one helper function with one match clause and a if-else for easy 0/1 detection and the main decode method uses also a 'match' clause. And I use recursion all over the place and no accumulator. Decoding the character is handled by my helper method which on his turn calls the main decode method with the remainder of the bits. And no other methods then the helper and the main decode method :-)

title: Why is filterAcc defined in TweetSet?
post_text: Nick, the answer is quite simple: It IS an implementation detail, but it is a method that you need to call on any TweetSet, regardless of which concrete subtype you have. So you do have to define it in the parent class. If you don't like it to be visible from outside (which you shouldn't), you can always define it as protected.

val set1 = new Empty
    val set2 = set1.incl(new Tweet("a", "a body", 20))
    val set3 = set2.incl(new Tweet("b", "b body", 20))

Set 2 = {a}
Set 3 = {a, b}
c = {c}
d = {d}
set4c = set 3 + c = {a,b,c} size 3
set4d = set 4 + d = {a,b,d} size 3
set5 = set4c +d = {a,b,c,d} size 4
