title: Union implementation not returning correct answer - Week 3 video lecture "Data and Abstraction"
post_text:
Hi All, I have implemented the NonEmpty set from Week 3 video lecture "Data and Abstraction". I am getting wrong result when trying some test cases. Please find the attached code. The var v4 should have printed a different result.

object intsets {


  var v1 = new NonEmpty(3, Empty, Empty)          //> v1  : week3.NonEmpty = {.3.}


  var v2 = v1 incl 4                              //> v2  : week3.IntSet = {.3{.4.}}


  var v3 = new NonEmpty(5, Empty, Empty)          //> v3  : week3.NonEmpty = {.5.}


  var v4 = v2 union v3                            //> v4  : week3.IntSet = {.3.}


}




abstract class IntSet {


  def incl(x: Int): IntSet


  def contains(x: Int): Boolean


  def union(other: IntSet): IntSet


}




object Empty extends IntSet {


  def incl(x: Int): IntSet = new NonEmpty(x, Empty, Empty)


  def contains(x: Int): Boolean = false


  override def toString = "."


  def union(other: IntSet): IntSet = this


}




class NonEmpty(elem: Int, left: IntSet, right: IntSet) extends IntSet {


  def incl(x: Int): IntSet = {


    if (x < elem) new NonEmpty(elem, left incl x, right)


    else if (x > elem) new NonEmpty(elem, left, right incl x)


    else this


  }


  def contains(x: Int): Boolean = {


    if (x < elem) left contains x


    else if (x > elem) right contains x


    else true


  }


	def union(other: IntSet): IntSet = ((left union right) union other) incl elem


  override def toString = "{" + left + elem + right + "}"


}

title: How do I use Mockito with Scala?
post_text: Personally, I wouldn't use a mocking lib. I've used Mockito, and I noticed that (because they use reflection) there is a performance penalty, and also tests aren't as readable with all the doReturn().when().someMethod() business sprinkled throughout. It's usually much cleaner to write your own stubs, and if that's too difficult it says something about your code structure.

title: Difference between abstract class and trait?
post_text:
In practice, by the way, in many languages you'll see that (abstract) class inheritance is used to define what a certain type of object is, while interfaces, traits, mixins and such (depending on what language you're working with) will be used to define what that object type behaves like.

I'm not good with examples, but I hope this helps: let's say you have a set of files on your computer. Some of these files might be binaries and unreadable, some might be videos, other might be music, yet other might be images, and still other might be documents. Now one could model all these file types are different classes. Only some of theses, however, are printable: printing binaries makes no sense, nor does printing a video, but printing a photo or document does. But there are other properties that some of these files might have in common: some might, for example, be shareable via a certain online service. The more behaviors are introduced, the harder it will become to model all of this in a single-inheritance structure. However, once we realize that things like Shareable and Printable are behaviors, we might want to extract them to traits (mixins, interfaces, what have you).

Hope this helps!

title: Difference between abstract class and trait?
post_text:
One of the differences that I see - for the abstact class you need to implement all the methods you define there in the concrete subclasses that are going to inherit from this abstract class whereas for traits this is NOT compulsory.
On the other hand, Traits don't allow you to have method definitions only (w/o implementation) - either you define the implementation along, or you don't define it at all (just define it inside of the subclass).

title: Understand FunSets.contains implementation
post_text:
I am not able to understand the "contains" function.
If "s" is a Set variable, "s(elem)" means somehow that we try to access the element "elem" in the set "s", but I do not see the implementation of that anywhere.

Could someone please explain it to me?

/**
   * Indicates whether a set contains a given element.
   */
  def contains(s: Set, elem: Int): Boolean = s(elem)

title: Understand FunSets.contains implementation
post_text:
Set is NOT a Scala.Set. It's an alias for the function definition (Int => Boolean). It's defined just above the "contains" function.
And inside of "contains" - you just invoke this function by passing the element (elem) inside and get your Boolean result.

title: Question regarding Uniqueness of a "Tweet"
post_text:
I had similar conundrums.

I noticed that incl is not implemented to add to the retweet count when an incl is applied to an already-contained user and text. 

According to the comments in TweetSet.scala, ("Returns the tweet from this set which has the greatest retweet count.")  mostRetweeted should return a tweet from a TweetSet for which the value of retweets is greatest. If the number of retweets we are interested in is the value of retweets for each Tweet, it seems the incl method should not return "this" when a tweet user and text are identical to those of a tweet already in the TweetSet. Rather it should increase the retweets for the tweet of that user and text.

On the other hand, the instructions page suggests that a retweeting count should count merely the number of users associated to a particular text. It says: 'The more often a tweet is "re-tweeted" (that is, repeated by a different user with or without additions), the more influential it is.' If a retweet only matters if it is associated to a different user, then the retweets value of each Tweet is of no consequence. And at first look it seems reasonable not to attach more influence when a given user retweets the same text.

The possibility of "different user with ... additions" seems to throw a further wrench in the mix.

However, when I looked at the given data in the final part of the problem, from each of just a few tech-site "users" there are a number of texts, perhaps none of which are identical, and each with a substantial retweets value. For the given tasks, it appears that, while the code for incl (and other methods) does not meet requirements of a general situation, it will be adequate for the data and tasks to which it is applied in the problem. I am not certain, as I have yet to complete the final part.

title: How to generalize a binary tree set, such as TweetSet?
post_text:
It can be done using a type parameter and a comparator passed to the class' constructor, so that the Set class has means to compare objects without having to have any knowledge about their structure. This way T can be anything you want:

abstract class Set[T] (comparator: T, T => Int) {
   def incl(x: T): Set[T]
   def remove(x: T): Set[T]
   def sortedBy(comparator: T, T => Int) : List[T]
   // and so on...
}

Java's SortedSet is implemented that way. Type parameters are covered in lecture 3.3.

title: Out of curiosity: Why is CodeTree defined as an abstract class?
post_text:
In the lecture, we learned that the root class of a case class hierarchy is usually defined as a trait.

Consulting the "Programming in Scala" book (Chapter 12) on this, it gives several reasons why you might choose one or the other, clearly leaning towards traits, which give you more options for re-use later.

However, one of the reasons cited there might apply here, namely that abstract classes are preferred "if efficiency is very important".

Is this why CodeTree is an abstract class, not a trait? Or is there another reason behind that?

title: Timeout on union function
post_text:
I figured out that the key to union performance is that in each recursive step when do you perform the "incl" operation, because the incl operation is the really expensive one.

An "incl" operation's timing depends on the set it calls, larger the worse.

therefore, the following will give the worst performance

right.union(left).union(that).incl(elem).  Because elem is getting inserted into a large set

right.union(left).incl(elem).union(that) will be better off but still quite bad.

perform an "incl" before any further union should render best results

such as:
right.incl(elem).union(left).union(that)
that.inclu(elem).union(right).union(left)

or others

title: mostRetweeted without var
post_text:
You may find it helpful to define a helper function for mostRetweeted. If this function can make recursive calls to itself, rather than to mostRetweeted, it will not incur the exception that Empty.mostRetweeted throws. If your helper is accumulator-style, its implementation in Empty is straightforward.

All that's left is to spell out (in your helper function) what the most retweeted Tweet is for a given TweetSet and accumulator. As usual, the value you are looking for can be described in terms of the accumulator, the fields of your TweetSet and the results of recursive calls to your helper function.

Note that in this case, using an accumulator-style helper will not achieve tail recursion. This is typical in branching data structures. However, I find that it simplifies the recursive logic enough to warrant its use here.

title: Stack Overflow on descending by retweet

title: Stack Overflow on descending by retweet
post_text:
You shouldn't get a stack overflow. The problem most people (myself included) ended up with is an efficiency problem, that makes the program run seemingly indefinitely. I left my machine crunching away at it overnight and it was still going in the morning.

The overflow is caused by an infinite recursive loop that's not tail-recursive. Your code runs indefinitely and by calling itself over and over again inflates the stack, causing an overflow.

For instance, this code would produce a stack overflow:
def myFunc(l: List[Int]): Int = myFunc(l) + 1
myFunc(List(1, 2))
Note, the +1 is necessary for the error. Without it this function would be tail recursive and would simply run indefinitely, as the stack will not expand.

Try looking for places where you are calling a function recursively, and verify that you've reduced the size of the input parameters (if they're lists or sets) or their value (if they're primitives).

title: Stack Overflow on descending by retweet
post_text:
Are you sure it's the descendingByRetweets function that's causing that?
And no, this function should not be called 2 times.
Just remember this function is used by that TweetList.
Just think like this:
you have a set of 4 Ints: [4, 2, 1, 3] and you have to create a sorted list from it.
you already have the function that gives you the maximum value (mostRetwitted).
so your new list should look like this:
head: [4, 2, 1, 3].maximum_value tail: [4, 2, 1, 3].remove(maximum_value).sorted
or
head: [4] tail: [3, 2, 1]

So, the only recursion happening here is at the tail (which is a smaller TweetList than the previous one, because you are always removing the maximum value (which you are using as the head)).

title: What does "all bounded integers within `s` satisfy `p`" actually mean???
post_text:
Mathematical terminology involves precise use of language to avoid the ambiguity inherent in natural language. The description used in the assignment is actually very precise and less likely to be misunderstood but as you note you do have to speak the language. 

A set is by definition a mathematical construct so in my opinion there won't be a way to truly understand the nuances of the assignment without approaching it from a mathematical perspective. 

'All bounded integers within $$s$$':

Since our sets are defined by a characteristic function we don't have a way to list the members of the set or even know how many elements are in the set. In fact, a characteristic function can specify an infinite set (e.g. even integers: x => x % 2 == 0). We can only test to see if a particular integer is in the set and that is what its characteristic function does.

In order to implement foreach we therefore have to look at a finite (or bounded) range of possible set members. The assignment template code contains a val labeled bound which gives us a way to specify a range of integers to test for membership in $$s$$. 

'satisfy $$p$$':

The predicate $$p$$ is a function that tests a condition on the input value. It returns a boolean, so 'satisfy' means that the test passes and the boolean value will be true. At this point you should be thinking that $$p$$ is defined and acts just like a characteristic function. There is no difference!

Once we know if an integer from the bounded range is in $$s$$ (ie. satisfies $$s$$) then we test to see if that integer also satisfies $$p$$. From a mathematical set perspective, foreach is testing if the bounded subset of the set $$s$$ is a subset of the set $$p$$.

Similarly, from a mathematical set perspective, exists is testing if the bounded subset of $$s$$ and the bounded subset of $$p$$ have a non-empty intersection.

title: Lecture 5.1 more concise flatten implementation possible?
post_text:
There is no answer given for the quiz question at the end of Lecture 5.1 'More Functions on Lists'. I implemented the following function, did anyone come up with anything shorter and simpler?

  def flattenAny(x: Any) : List[Any] = x match {
    case Nil => Nil
    case y :: ys => flattenAny(y) ::: flatten(ys)
    case y => List(y)
  }
                                                  
  def flatten(xs: List[Any]): List[Any] = xs match {
    case Nil => Nil
    case x :: xs => flattenAny(x) ::: flatten(xs)
  }
  
  flatten(List(List(1, 1), 2, List(3, List(5, 8))))
                                                  //> res2: List[Any] = List(1, 1, 2, 3, 5, 8)

title: Efficiency of descendingByRetweet
post_text:
I followed the hints for implementing descendingByRetweets. It compiles and runs fine. However, now that it's all submitted, I have some time to think about code efficiency. The recursive implementation of searching through a binary tree and removing an element and then repeating this process seems inefficient.

I haven't done a hard analysis on the problem or anything but intuitively it seems to make more sense to construct a sorted list of tweets as you walk through the tree. This way, you'd only have to traverse the tree of tweets one time.

title: What does "all bounded integers within `s` satisfy `p`" actually mean???
post_text:
Hi Paul,

Thanks so much for the clarification. In essence, if I understand your response correctly, the gist of the phrase I highlighted was:

"Check whether, between the upper and lower bounds, all values within set S are also within set/characteristic function P." So the "foreach" function is testing a complete intersection, where S must be a complete (within bounds) subset of P. Whereas the "exists" function must check to see whether there is any intersection at all between the two, of at least a single element (integer)

Hmm, my complaint about phrasing speaks to excessive parsimony and assumptive knowledge, which are the bane of technical writers. If a phrase is reduced to its minimum possible words, then it is often found to be difficult to comprehend from those not in the field. Even worse, if the original writer is an expert, the phrase may seem to be completely obvious to them, yet may be very difficult to parse for readers not in the field. 

When words are few, then each must be freighted heavily with meaning, thus I have spent 2 days agonising over the meaning of the word satisfy. Once you clarified the matter, thank you, the meaning of satisfy seems simple and easily grasped, and some may be tempted to say it was obvious in retrospect. But simple is not the same as obvious and it is foolishness to conflate them, otherwise there would have been no debate on whether the earth was flat or round, as once the fact is grasped the curvature can be discerned visually. Thus, while the questions in the assignment were simple, they were never obvious, otherwise a FAQ would not have been needed.
 
In the past I have found these problems can be resolved by increasing the verbosity slightly (i.e. ~10-15%) so the logic can be carried more clearly. I am not suggesting massive increases, nor superfluous descriptions. Can you please amend the FAQ for this assignment to include these extra clarifications on the second question, so that future students may grok the gist  more quickly.

Thanks once again for the clarification

title: Encoding if the Huffman tree is just a Leaf
post_text:
As it has already been stated in the previous answers, I reckon that case has not been considered in the structure of the provided code, and as far as I can tell from my submission, it isn't tested.

Nonetheless, I leave here some explanation on Huffman compression (beyond the scope of this assignment) and some comments to this issue of single-character strings, for those who are interested. Please pardon any grammar mistakes, as English is a foreign language for me. I know what I've written is somewhat long, but I just find lossless compression quite interesting :)


A few general explanations for (lossless) compression algorithms (the bold ones are the ones used in the assignment, the italic ones are their counterparts):
  • Static compression: The string is processed once so as to build a frequency table from which the optimal codeTree is made, and a second time afterwards for the actual encoding/compression using the previously built codeTree. To decompress, the frequency table has to be written in the compression's output together with the actual compressed string so that the decompressor (or decoder) can rebuild the codeTree before decompressing the actual string; otherwise it wouldn't be able to know which code has been used for that particular string. This makes the encoding to be optimal, but the compressed output is usually very big for short strings, since the entire frequency table has to be written to the output as well.
  • Dynamic compression: The string is processed only once, updating the frequency table (and therefore the codeTree) after each character is processed (the compressor "learns" the optimal coding as it encodes the string). The frequency table starts always in the same initial state (usually, every character is assigned the frequency 1). Therefore, there is no need for the frequency table to be written in the compressor's output, since the decompressor can just update it in the same way the compressor did and that way there is no ambiguity.
  • Order-0: The frequencies are simply the number of repetitions of each character along the entire string, i.e. how many times each character appears in the given string. For example, for the string "abaca" the frequency table would be { ('a', 3), ('b', 1), ('c', 1) }
  • Order-N: The frequencies are relative to the context (i.e., the N previous characters) of each repetition of the character. Therefore, the frequency table is much bigger, since there is one table (and one codeTree) for each context. This makes the coding of a (not too short) structured string more optimal, since the distribution of character weights (and therefore length of bit-code) is more adapted to its structure, but unusable for short strings because the frequency table is so long that it may be (much) longer than the original uncompressed string. Usually the first N characters are left uncompressed so as to avoid the problem of their not having an order-N context. For example, for the string "abaca" the order-1 frequency table would be: {in context 'a': ('b',1), ('c',1); in context 'b' ('a',1); in context 'c': ('a',1) }

What we are making in the assignment is a static order-0 Huffman compressor and decompressor.
With that in mind, if the entire string contains repetitions of only one character, then that frequency table would have only one entry, and the the resulting codeTree would only have a single (root) node. Therefore, the code for that character is 0-bits long (i.e., it does not need any bits to be represented) and the decoded string can be infered from the frequency table without the need of a code. It follows that the compressor's output would be simply the one-entry frequency table, and no coded binary sequence representing the string.
In this case, the Huffman coding degenerates into Run-Length coding of a string that repeats a single character, which is an algorithm that simply writes how long each character repetition is (the Run-Length code of the string "aaabaa" would be some representation of: {('a',3), ('b',1), ('a',2)} ).

In the exercise, there is no need for the frequency tables to be written to the output, since the decoder reads the encoded string from memory and not from a file (because the encoding and decoding happen in the same program) and gets the codeTree built earlier in the same program. However, this raises an issue if the same algorithm is to be used for actual compression (where one instance of the program encodes and another one decodes, so the encoded string is written to, and read from a file): Since the minimum bit-group in every file is a byte, how would the decompressor know when to stop if the length of encoded output isn't a natural number of bytes? This means that if the string is "ab" and the encoded output is just "01", there are 6 "rubbish" bits in the compressed file, and the decompressor would interpret them as "a"s or "b"s and thus produce an eight-character string, which is wrong.
The best way to avoid this is for the decompressor to calculate from the frequency tables the length of the original string and stop decompressing when that length is reached (this is impossible if the only thing the decompressor gets is the previously-built codeTree, it has to at least get the length of the original string as well). Another common solution is to add the EndOfFile character to the frequency table and the codeTree, and when that character is decoded, the decompressor stops. However, this is a slightly worse solution, because the frequency tables are one entry longer (due to the added character) and the compressed code is a few bits longer (due to the encoded EOF), thus producing a slightly worse compression ratio.

----------------------------------------

I hope some of you find this interesting as well, and I recommend for those people to read Matt Mahoney's book on http://mattmahoney.net/dc/dce.html. Personally, I find the different algorithms for entropy reduction together with arithmetic coding most interesting, as well as Shannon's Information Theory (from which I only know the basics so far).

title: Pattern Matching Advanced Questions
post_text:
about your first question, I don't think there is a better way to ignore parameters.

for your second question, what you're saying and what your code is doing is kind of different.
If you want to match a list with head 0 and optional tail (no matter how long), you can use this:

case 0 :: xs => doSomething //xs can be Nil

If you only want to match up to size 2, I don't think there is a better way to do this, although an alternative would be something like

case 0 :: xs if xs.size < 2 => doSomething

title: Does combine create a correct Huffman tree?
post_text:
I've implemented all of the functions in parts 1, 2, and 3 of the assignment and my implementations passed the predefined unit tests. However, there's something that I noticed as a result of combine. The implementation of combine is supposed to combine elements from an ascending-ordered list from left to right. The result of this would be a tree where the left-hand side would contain the deeper subtrees than the right. This is verified by the unit test that was provided with the assignment below.

assert(combine(leaflist) === List(Fork(Leaf('e',1),Leaf('t',2),List('e', 't'),3), Leaf('x',4)))
Isn't the resulting formation the exact opposite of what a proper Huffman tree should look like; where the right-hand side should have the deeper portion of the tree than the left? Because of this, in order to get my implementation of decode to work correctly I had to reverse the traversal of the tree where if it encountered a 1 it would traverse left rather than right. What am I missing here?

title: union performance
post_text:
These two implementations of TweetSet NonEmpty union have very different performance characteristics:

  def union(that: TweetSet): TweetSet = right.union(left.union(that)).incl(elem)    

  def union(that: TweetSet): TweetSet = right.union(that).union(left).incl(elem)

The first one is fast; when I use that one the trending list is computed more or less instantly. The second one is slow; computing the trending list takes minutes.

Are there rules of thumb that Scala programmers follow to avoid writing pathologically slow recursive code?

title: Does combine create a correct Huffman tree?
post_text:
Huffman trees do not have the property "the right-hand side should have the deeper portion of the tree". The ones we construct here have the property "the right-hand child of any node has  more total weight than the left-hand child".

(Note that this is not a sufficient (or even necessary) condition to get a Huffman tree. They have a balance property that is achieved by the bottom-up, merge-lowest-weight-subtrees-first construction).

As an example, consider the codes for the following two strings: "aaabc" and "aaabbcc" (I suggest testing it yourself). The trees are nearly identical, except in the former case the "a" node is on the right (weight 3) and the "bc" tree is on the left (weight 2). In the latter case, "a" is on the left because the "bc" tree now has weight 4.

title: union performance
post_text:
It's nothing unique to scala. When you are building data structures from scratch you have to understand their structure and efficient algorithms for traversing them, combining them, and splitting them apart. Naive implementations rarely perform well. Some say in functional programming you shouldn't be worrying about that but this is the perfect counterexample for when you still do.

That said, in most programming languages, scala included, we can rely on standard libraries that define useful data structures where those decisions have already been made. Occasionally use cases can arise where even these will not perform adequately. At that point the developer may have to dive in and get dirty.

Professors usually prefer to keep students on the same timeline and working on the same portion of the material for two primary reasons:

post_text:
First I want to say that so far in this course, pattern matching fascinates me the most. 
One of the advantages I see is much cleaner code. In my opinion, last and init implementations on the List which are shown in 5.1 lecture are a great example. Very simple and elegant code.
Looking at the same examples, the fact that you can match on the content of the class instance (an empty List vs a List with one element or a List with more than an element aka a head and a tail), tells me that matching is not done only by the compiler. title: No idea how to start writing the times() function
post_text:
I don't mean to step on toes, but isn't suggesting a solution based on library functions similar to telling a first-year computer science student "the way to sort lists is by calling list.sort()"? It's certainly a true statement, but I can't imagine implementing that solution and feeling like I'd learned anything about how to sort lists.

In this case, there are solutions using what we have learned from the lectures which take fewer than fifteen lines of code. I can't help but think that knowing how to implement them will be useful to students in this course. I do agree that knowing about the library functions is important, since in practice they should be used when appropriate.

In the interest of contributing to times(), I would suggest writing a function incrChar(freqs: List[(Char, Int)], c: Char) which returns a new List[(Char, Int)] that is identical to freqs except that the Int value for Char c is incremented by 1 (or equal to 1 if it was not in the list to start). If the OP implemented a working version of incrChar, I think it would point him or her in a good direction towards implementing times and having a better grasp on functional programming.

title: Problems with Filter, Exists and Map - Time to Give up?
post_text:
Dear Brett,

I'll try to reply to some of your technical questions: 

1) 
def exists(s: Set, p: Int => Boolean): Boolean = !(!forall(s, p))
You're trying to express here that $$\exists (x \in s).p = \neg \forall (x \in s). \neg p $$. But what you are doing is applying negation twice on the same value: 
!(!forall(s,p)) == forall(s,p)
so this is of course wrong. 

Instead,
!forall(s,!p)
(as you are trying to write in the first code line, I assume) would be more to the right direction, but then of course the types don't match: p is of type Int => Boolean, but we want to apply ! on a Boolean value. So what you want here is a new predicate of type Int => Boolean, that returns the negation of what p would return. So let us create this predicate as an anonymous function:
(x : Int) => !p(x)

2) map is solvable by using exists and anonymous functions, although it is a little tougher than the rest.

3) There is no distinction between Set and Int => Boolean. In fact, Set is just an alias for Int => Boolean. Intersect and filter seem ok, I'm not sure what problem you encountered.

title: Lecture 4.6: Pattern match vs Types tests (cast)
post_text: I would point OP to lecture 1.1, in which the instructor discusses programming paradigms. One of the assets of functional programming is that it can reason about theories. Operations like "asInstanceOf" tend to gum up the works in (typed) formal languages. It's probably true that the two constructions are similar under the hood, but the pattern-matching approach greatly simplifies our ability to reason about expressions by not having to keep track of extraneous rules for absurd things like Nil.asInstanceOf[Char].

title: Problems with Filter, Exists and Map - Time to Give up?
Timeout with Filter , how can it be optimized ?
post_text:
You probably know that union(that) can be reduced to 
this.filterAcc(_ => true, that)

Now, filterAcc was the bottleneck also in my implementation, which looked like 

  override def filterAcc(p: Tweet => Boolean, acc: TweetSet): TweetSet = {
      val acc1 = acc.union(right).union(left) // 392
      if (p(elem)) acc1.incl(elem) else acc1
  }

You add left and right to the acc and then this element itselft. This is what Odersky taught in the lectures. Looks correct, right? I just disliked it from very beginning because of poor efficiency. You see that acc grows with every item we include. You add right to acc. This means that large acc must be decomposed (and composed again) for every left item you add then. Once node is decomposed into left and right, you recompose the tree and so on, for every subitem. This is like Hanoi tower movement -- utmost inefficient process, which takes exponential time (w.r.t. the num of items you join). It cannot be worse. But, this is what Odersky design. Or it is not?

Actually, there is 6 ways you can add 3 things together:

left+right+acc
left+acc+right
right+acc+left
...
without changing the concept. Furthermore, even within a definite order, you can either (a+b)+c or a+(b+c). I have guessed that the best result would be achieved if you only add to the accumulator but never decompose it and tried different implementations

var cnt: Int = 0

case class NonEmpty(val elem: Tweet, left: TweetSet, right: TweetSet) extends TweetSet {

  override def filterAcc(p: Tweet => Boolean, acc: TweetSet): TweetSet = {
  	//val acc1 = left.filterAcc(p, right.filterAcc(p, acc))
  	cnt += 1 ; println("acc " + this +  " + " + acc + " = " + (cnt))
//  	val acc1 = left.union(right).union(acc) //22
//  	val acc1 = acc.union(left).union(right) // 22
//  	val acc1 = right.union(left).union(acc) // 38
  	//val acc1 = right.union(acc).union(left) // 262
  	val acc1 = acc.union(right).union(left) // 392
  	//val acc1 = right.union(left.union(acc)) // 7
//  	val acc1 = left.union(right.union(acc)) // 7
//  	val acc1 = left.union(acc.union(right)) // 44
//  	val acc1 = acc.union(left.union(right)) // 40
//  	val acc1 = acc.union(right.union(left)) // 48
  	if (p(elem)) acc1.incl(elem) else acc1
  }

for the single test

inclAll(1,2,3,4,11,12,13) union inclAll(5,6,7,8,9,10)

You see, we add 7 items to 7 items. In the best implementation, 
if (p(elem)) acc1.incl(elem) else acc1

in the union-filterAcc recursion should be called no more than 7 times. And, you see, this happens in case of

  val acc1 = right.union(left.union(acc)) // 7
and

  val acc1 = left.union(right.union(acc)) // 7

implementations. In both cases we supply acc only as argument to the union, which means that it is never decomposed. My guess was right.

The worst implementation was 

acc.union(right).union(left)

with almost 400 recursive iterations. It is because acc is always decomposed. Furthermore, once acc is decomposed, we start decomposing the right, because it becomes the argument. Once they are decomposed/recomposed into to new acc, the process is repeated with acc.unite(left). This implementation won't pass the performance test!

title: Problems with Filter, Exists and Map - Time to Give up?
post_text:
1) The first thing you should think about is the types. I suggest you try the code you suggest in an IDE to see the type errors.
The first alternative you gave does not typeckeck at all: You want to return a boolean, but you return a function (Int => Boolean). So it's definitely wrong. 
When defining exists, look at the type of forall: Its first argument is a set. You want the exists to apply on exaclty the same set s, so why try to change it at all? You don't need to define a new one, just pass the same! Whereas the predicate you pass to forall is not at all the same: think of the formal definition I gave above. You have to construct a new one, that's why you need the anonymous function. You cannot apply ! directly on a value of type (Int => Boolean), of course.
2) Of course you can do iteration. One of the advantages of functional programming though, is that you don't need to: Higher-order functions are so powerful that by synthesizing them you can express many things without explicit iteration. So your long loops from Java or C++ become one-liners. So the best solution would be to reuse some of the functions you define already.
As to when you use anonymous functions, it is whenever you need to construct a function on the fly; there is no specific rules.
3) Can you express (in words!) what map should do, in terms of exists? As in: "map(s, f) is the set of all elements x, for which ..."
After you do this, just translate it directly into code and you are good to go! (I will post the solution in a comment below)

title: Lecture 5.5: foldRight and reduceRight
post_text:
Hi everybody!

If I understand the material right, foldRight and reduceRight methods of lists aren't efficient (in comparison with foldLeft and reduceLeft), due to expansion of the expression:

x1 op (x2 op (x3 op ...))
It cannot be evaluated until there will be no more foldRight calls inside it. Only after that the expression will be evaluated, starting with (x{n-1} op xn) and so on, going up to x1.

My questions are:

  1. Are foldRight and reduceRight implemented in Scala library in such a way?
  2. Can the following code, doing the same job, be faster than the foldRight?
    l.reverse.foldLeft(...).reverse

Thank you in advance!

title: Lecture 5.5: foldRight and reduceRight
post_text:
I don't think the Right operations suffer from an inherent inefficiency. It's just a different direction of approaching the list.
The aspect that may interfere with efficiency is that it would have to be done in a recursive way with the mapping operation done before returning the value, so tail recursion seems difficult, and that can impact efficiency.

In the solution you suggested, since fold doesn't return a list but actually reduces it to a single value, the second reverse call isn't necessary (an error, actually). Besides, since lists are immutable in Scala, reverse would create an entire new list before calling foldLeft which might be more detrimental to performance, not to mention the fact that you need two traversals of the list now, instead of one.

All that being said, sometimes the better implementation is indeed to reverse the list and do a foldLeft. Here's a StackOverflow thread about it: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/11004715/foldright-efficiency

title: Why encode method uses that signature?
post_text:

Why does it use this signature

title: 5.4 `encode` function type mis-match
Why encode method uses that signature?
post_text:
This allows you to make an encode function for a specific tree first, so that it's easier to use (and faster?) later.

For example:
val frenchEncode = encode(frenchCode)_
frenchEncode("Omelet du fromage".toList)

title: Pattern matching syntax is too verbose
Pattern matching syntax is too verbose
Pattern matching syntax is too verbose
post_text: Thank you! At least something shorter.

title: Pattern matching syntax is too verbose
post_text:
Artisiom,

what you are writing is unnecessarily complex:

def foo(tree: CodeTree): Char = tree match {
  case Fork(left: CodeTree, right: CodeTree, chars: List[Char], weight1: Int) => chars.head
  case Leaf(char: Char, weight: Int) => char 
}
For example, the left : CodeTree subpattern constraints left to be a CodeTree, but you know this from the context already!

So you can write instead
def foo(tree: CodeTree): Char = tree match {
  case Fork(left, right, chars, weight1) => chars.head
  case Leaf(char, weight) => char 
}
Also, as was pointed out before, you can replace a variable which you don't use (and thus don't need to name) with an _ :

def foo(tree: CodeTree): Char = tree match {
  case Fork(_, _, chars, _) => chars.head
  case Leaf(char, _) => char 
}

If you don't care about the case class fields but only about the type you can pattern match on types as Jon suggests.

title: Why encode method uses that signature?
post_text:
The method is defined with currying so you can give only one parameter list, as Wessel suggests before.
You may want to review previous sessions on currying and partial application.

title: Pattern matching syntax is too verbose
post_text:

title: 5.4 `encode` function type mis-match
post_text:
:: is the cons operator, which prepends an element to a list. So when you say
List((x.head, x.length)) :: encode(xs1) 

you should provide a List[(T,Int)] on the right (which you do) and a (T, Int) on the left to be prepended. However, you are providing a list on the left: List(x) is equivalent to x :: Nil. You don't need the List(_) constructor here.

title: Lecture 5.5: foldRight and reduceRight
post_text: The problem with the right version is that you cannot express them in a tail recursive form in an obvious way. Scala library has optimized (maybe even imperative) implementations that somehow bypass this.

title: Does combine create a correct Huffman tree?
post_text:
Hi all,

Here is the thing, see this post: https://class.coursera.org/progfun-005/forum/thread?thread_id=699
Alex Li explained it all: aside from the fact that the text in assignment is dubious and not clear, he stated that combine is a one-step operation and should behave exactly as "combine the first two, reorder and return". Nothing more. It should not be recursive.
The real job is done in the until function, since that is the point where combine will do its job recursively.

I rearranged my solution and now I got a perfect score.
Hope this helps.

title: union performance
post_text:
My rules of thumb are as follows:
1. determine when your algorithm should terminate
2. detemine/sketch, preferably on a piece of paper, how you can recurse to a termination state
3. choose the fastest way to termination

In the example above, the union method terminates only when the set upon which union is called is empty. The faster you get there, the better. The first implementation does this by calling union only on the reft and right subtrees.

The second implementation calls union on right.union(that) which doesn't reduce nearly as fast to the empty subtree. This is in line with James observation. In fact, this will get worse for larger sets.

You can improve performance even more by adding the elem to that instead of the end result, making the function tail recursive:

def union(that: TweetSet): TweetSet = right.union(left.union(that.incl(elem)))

title: Problems with Filter, Exists and Map - Time to Give up?
post_text:
Keiths remark about always spelling things out is extremely good advice. It helps in two ways:
1. you're avoiding the syntactic sugar, which only helps when you're proficient with the language; it's only a hindrance now
2. by creating a new function/value for every step, you're naming/describing what you're doing

Especially the last bit is the key to understanding if your solution is correct. So take it seriously: you'll learn faster that way.

title: Prior training in this area?
post_text:
To answer your first question, I have taken several undergraduate- and graduate-level courses that used functional programming, and have contributed to a fairly large project written in Scheme. I spend most of my professional time writing imperative code.

For the second part, I think the lectures and assignments in this course do a good job of starting from first principles and building up to practical functional programming. You should be able to learn everything in this course with no prior functional programming training.

The hardest part will probably be breaking your imperative-programming habits (modifying objects vs. building new ones, iteration vs. recursion, etc.).

title: assignment due date is wrong

Hi Jian, 

For every assignment there is a soft deadline and a hard deadline. You can only achieve the maximal score if you submit before the soft deadline. After that, a penalty of 20% will be applied for each day that has passed since the soft deadline. 

The hard deadline is defined to be 5 days after the soft deadline: no more submissions are accepted once the hard deadline has passed.

I'm afraid that with so many students enrolled in our courses, it's very hard for us to consider deadline extensions on an individual student basis.

Thanks for your understanding!

title: Difference between ::: (concatenation) and ++ (append)?
post_text: You already point out the different signatures, which show that ++ is more general whereas ::: gives a better hint to the reader of your code that you're operating on lists. I would consider it better style to use ::: if you're already using :: on the same list. Performance differences should be negligable, possibly ::: could be a bit faster since it probably does less type checking, but I haven't done any benchmark.

title: Difference between ::: (concatenation) and ++ (append)?
post_text:
You can write 
List(1, 3, 5) ++ "178"
but not
List(1, 3, 5) ::: "178"

post_text: Typically in a functional program you would use an Option type (http://www.scala-lang.org/api/current/index.html#scala.Option) for these kind of scenarios. Nevertheless an decode(encode()) operation always succeeds.  My encode/decode functions also correctly deciphered the secret message.

val ex1=createCodeTree("AAAAAAAABBBCDEFGH".toList)
//> ex1  : patmat.Huffman.CodeTree = Fork(Leaf(A,8),Fork(Fork(Fork(Leaf(G,1),Leaf(H,1),List(G, H),2),Fork(Leaf(E,1),Leaf(F,1),List(E, F),2),List(G, H, E, F),4),Fork(Fork(Leaf(C,1),Leaf(D,1),List(C, D),2),Leaf(B,3),List(C, D, B),5 ),List(G, H, E, F, C, D, B),9),List(A, G, H, E, F, C, D, B),17)
val encd=encode(ex1)("D".toList) //> encd  : List[patmat.Huffman.Bit] = List(1, 1, 0, 1)
decode(ex1,encd)     //> res6: List[Char] = List(D)
The issue is obviously that several Leafs() start out having the same weighting so there are several legitimate arrangements of  nodes in ascending order- this changes the way the tree is constructed.

title: 5.1 Is it possible for flatten function to return List[Int] instead of List[Any] using parametrization?
post_text:
There is no way to do it. Your parameter is a List[Any]. How would you know in advance what is the type T of elements that are contained in it, in order to ask for a result of type List[T]? E.g. what prevents me from writing
val list : List[Int] = flatten(List("whoops"))

Also, the pattern
case (elem: T) :: xs =>
is problematic. You are asking from the JVM to dynamically (at run-time) see what if the type of elem matches the type parameter of flatten, and act accordingly. But type parameters are not present at runtime in the JVM (look up type erasure). There is no way to know dynamically what T was.

title: Difference between ::: (concatenation) and ++ (append)?
post_text:
You can use ++ with any Iterable, even if it is not a list, but the (static) result type will only be Iterable. 
Whereas ::: is defined between Lists, and always returns a List.

title: Scala/SBT incompatibility causes strange NoSuchMethodException at runtime
post_text:
This seems to be a minimal worksheet that causes the error:

object notfun {
  def test (xs: List[Object] ): List[Object] = xs match {
    case Nil => Nil
    case x :: _ => x::Nil
  }
 
  test(List("a"))
}

It compiles fine, but when executing test(List("a")), you might get (depending on the version of Scala and SBT you are using):

java.lang.NoSuchMethodError: scala.collection.immutable.$colon$colon.hd$1()Ljava/lang/Object;
    at #worksheet#.test(notfun.sc9139384316132215921.tmp:3)
    at #worksheet#.#worksheet#(notfun.sc9139384316132215921.tmp:6)

There are a number of references on the Internet. See e.g. https://groups.google.com/forum/#!msg/scala-ide-dev/h-kUTfxUfLM/dGTr0hVInSgJ.

The root cause seems to be an SBT build that's incompatible with the Scala version you are using. The code is obviously correct, but somehow the pattern matching on lists steps on the incompatibility.

I am encountering the problem with the Scala plugin 0.41.2 for IDEA (version 13.1.4 for Linux).

But other students using Eclipse have reported the same problem.

title: Lecture 5.8: open-ended exercise
post_text:
You don't need to worry about whether ys is Nil; you only need to use structural induction on xs. If you watch lecture 5.6 and follow the example proving (xs ++ ys) ++ zs == xs ++ (ys ++ zs), you can see this in action. Even though that example contains three lists, we only need to do induction on xs to prove the theorem.

The reason this works is that our rewrite rules, such as "Nil ++ ys -> ys" and "(x :: xs) ++ ys -> x :: (xs ++ ys)", hold for all ys by the definition of concat.

title: What should convert return for a single leaf?

I think that the hint refers to "subtree" as the complete path from the root to a leaf excluding all other leaves. Eg: (ABCDEFGH) -> (A) in the assignment details.

Because it doesn't make sense to have a tree of a single leaf (even though it's "correct" in terms of code), it would be like having a language of just one letter.

Having said that I'm still working on that function myself. I found a solution to the problem but it's way inefficient so I'm still working to improve that.

Hi,
I am using IntelliJ as my IDE, and am keen to be able to use it as a scratchpad to follow along with Prof. Odersky's lectures. I have been able to import and execute the assignments, no problem (except solving the assignments was v. tricky), so the software is installed properly and working.

Following along with the IntelliJ tutorial and Lecture 2.5, I create a new sbt/scala project called scratchpad, and create a new package called Week3. I then use the menu to create a new class, Rational, and start to fill it out as described in Lecture 2.5.

But in the Lecture, Prof. Odersky uses Eclipse, and his worksheet has an additional object definition above the class definition, which he then uses as a scratchpad. How do I obtain the same functionality in IntelliJ? Do I write out the same object definition shown in the video, and use the same approach as Eclipse?

I tried to watch the Intellij tutorial, but as a non-expert user it was hard to decipher.

Can anyone please help with a step-by-step description of how I can use IntelliJ to follow Prof. Odersky's lectures?

Please use Lecture 2.5 as an example. Thanks in advance.

title: Using IntelliJ as Scratchpad to follow Prof. Odersky Lectures
post_text:
Yes, just create a worksheet and type in the object definition. To create a worksheet right click in the project tree where you want to create it and select 'New > Scala Worksheet' and give it a name

or with the focus in the project tree move the cursor where you want the worksheet, press Alt-Insert, start typing "worksheet" (the 'w' should be enough), press enter and give it a name.


You may run into issues though, IntelliJ IDEA's Scala plugin (version 0.41.2) currently has some bug(s) which may prevent some worksheets from executing properly, as mentioned in https://class.coursera.org/progfun-005/forum/thread?thread_id=663 .

title: Using IntelliJ as Scratchpad to follow Prof. Odersky Lectures
post_text:
I was just using the last project I had open on my desktop (week 3 objsets, the path was src/main/scala/objsets/<worksheet-etc>), yours under src/main/scala/Week3 is fine.

The *.sc are worksheets (really a kind of REPL [what you call a scratchpad], well a saved history [it's a plain text file] for the IDE's REPL). Worksheets are for trying things out and seeing intermediate feedback (i.e. throw away experiments), Scala classes are for source code you want to be part of the program (i.e. possibly packaged as a jar/war file eventually)

Hi,

and not:
def quickEncode(tree: CodeTree, text: List[Char]): List[Bit]?

When would you use the first option and when would you use the second option

title: Week 3 assignment

title: a question about method signature syntax
post_text:
You would use the first option when you think you may want to partially apply quickEncode on a given CodeTree:
quickEncode(tree) _
creates a new "specialized" function that encodes a List[Char] according to tree.

title: a question about method signature syntax
post_text:
Having this definition
def quickEncode(tree: CodeTree)(text: List[Char]): List[Bit]

you might use quickEncode as a partially applied function with a specific code tree. As an example, using a specific code tree 'myTree' you can retrieve a new encoding function like this:
def quickEncodeWithMyTree = quickEncode(myTree)

This might then be applied to various lists of characters, using the same code tree:
quickEncodeWithMyTree(myText1)
quickEncodeWithMyTree(myText2)

However, this cannot be done with this signature:
def quickEncode(tree: CodeTree, text: List[Char]): List[Bit]

Have a look at the Lecture 2.2 - Currying (14:58) for more details.

title: What should convert return for a single leaf?
post_text:
I used the mergeCodeTables function as a helper in Convert in a way that is very related to the hint given in the assignment.

The way my mergeCodeTables worked determined what to do once I hit a leaf in Convert.

My mergeCodeTables uses an accumulator and it works as follows: "If I'm iterating across CodeTable a, then pre-prend a 0 to the accumulator. If I'm iterating across CodeTable b, then pre-pend a 1". That way, my mergeCodeTables is the one that is responsible for prepending 0s and 1s and I move one level up the hierarchy. 

If you think about it that way, what should a Leaf return so that mergeCodeTables can append either a 0 or 1 as appropriate, and the result is a single List(0) or List(1)?

title: Funtional Programming is Overrated
post_text:
Making your brain hurt to accomplish simple things reeks of make-work for overpaid professions. I don't like make-work and I don't like cults. An empirical study by Pankratius, Schmidt and Garretón found that Scala programs took more programming effort and were harder to debug. There aren't many empirical studies in these fields because it would finally prove that orange isn't the new pink. The computer industry has a lot of hype about what it "types".

"Functional programming has a major problem that is evident to every mainstream programmer who has expressed an interest in learning what the excitement is about: Functional programmers are a bunch of smug jerks." ~Larry O Brien

Alan Kay on Dijkstra
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9KivesLMncs

We can see a lot of inferiority complexes and envy coming from the Europeans who know that they are not nearly as innovative as Americans (try ditching all the cultural Marxism). Their snobbery is proportional to their irrelevance. I don't have to mention what a loser the French economy is because we all understand that the ghost of Rousseau fights on. http://papers.ssrn.com/sol3/papers.cfm?abstract_id=2132939

The straw men arguments against OOP have us believe languages like Java are good representatives. But all knowledgeable people know that OOP implementers focused on the class hierarchies instead of the decentralized communication.

Oh, let's not forget that buggy, command-line relic Linux:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rmsIZUuBoQs

Intellectually bankrupt fields go around creating a bunch trivial and meaningless derivatives of old ideas. Creating a bunch of equivalent context-free grammars doesn't really impress me. It does burden me with extra credentials and expenses to keep up with fashionable nonsense. I think the current imitation professionalism we find in computer science is the result of its practitioners being drawn from the pool of failed mathematicians and physicists. They will load you up on baroque nonsense if you let these brilliant make-work bureaucrats lead the way.

The arguments about nouns and verbs is really quite boring and unproductive. We keep inventing new languages because no one seems to understand that no language is perfect. Perfection never was the standard, so don't look for it. I would suggest you learn and  build new algorithms (few really important ones being developed past the 1970s) instead of wasting your time and effort reinventing the wheel and bulldozing for nickels.

Java:
for (int i=1; i<=25; i++)
    System.out.println(i*i);
}

Now lets try the "elegant" Clojure:

import java.util.ArrayList;
import java.util.List;

public class Take25 {

    public static void main(String[] args) {   
        for (Object o : take(25, squaresOf(integers()))) {
            System.out.println(o);
        }
    }
   
    public static List list) {
        return list.subList(0, n);
    }
   
    public static List squaresOf(List list) {
        List result = new ArrayList();
        for (Integer number : list) {
            result.add(number.intValue() * number.intValue());
        }
        return result;
    }
   
    public static List integers() {
        List result = new ArrayList();
        for (int i = 1; i <= Integer.MAX_VALUE; i++) {
            result.add(i);
        }
        return result;
    }
   
}

Exception in thread "main" java.lang.OutOfMemoryError...

"The productivity paradox has attracted a lot of attention because technology seems no longer to be able to create the kind of productivity gains that occurred until the early 1970s. Some, such as economist Robert J. Gordon, are now arguing that technology in general is subject to diminishing returns in its ability to increase economic growth."
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Productivity_paradox

https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLoX7a0UGDa6VaoHc_PyxL_6zAil3F_ETX

title: Funtional Programming is Overrated
post_text:
Posting an analysis on the on lack of merits of functional programming to experts means you probably want to have an educated discussion. Doing it on a beginners forum, suggests that you are having trouble with one of the assignments.

The nature of computing has changed drastically from the 1970's, and therefore so must the tools. Functional paradigms lend themselves well to massive distributed computing because passing immutable objects and thinking of steps of a map-reduce in terms of functional blocks makes it a lot easier to parallelize and build pipelines.

I am not suggesting that functional programming is the silver bullet but I do think that having an understanding of the principles will make someone better at coding.

title: 20/20 despite missing the point of quickEncode
post_text:
Not paying attention, I implemented `quickEncode` as:

  def quickEncode(tree: CodeTree)(text: List[Char]): List[Bit] = {
    val table = convert(tree)
    text match {
      case Nil => Nil
      case ch::rest => codeBits(table)(ch):::quickEncode(tree)(rest) 
    }
  }
This is obviously wrong, as it generates a new `table` for each character in `text`! However, I submitted this, and received 20/20 on the assignment. (I fixed my implementation to only convert(tree) once and resubmitted, for posterity.)

Perhaps a test could be added that ensures that `convert` is only called once in a call to quickEncode?

title: Funtional Programming is Overrated
post_text:
FP is not the solution to everything, it's an alternative to the more popular Imperative Programming (IP).
Sometimes I prefer FP, sometimes I don't. That's why I like to have the choice by using languages that mix a bit of both (like Scala but also Javascript for instance: its Underscore library popularized very useful functional helpers that are more elegant and readable than the IP equivalent, when understood correctly).

But be it FP or IP, you can always mess things up and make them overly complicated.

title: How to compile and test incrementally.
post_text:
my 2 cents

add the main method to the object if you want to run a method of an object, if not then create an object, instance the class, and run the method. : 

object whatever {
  def main(args:Array[String]): Unit = {
    val testHomework = new homework
    testHomework.anyMethod(x,y,z)
    objectMethod
  }
  objectMethod
}

class homework {
  ...
  anyMethod(x: [Any], y:[Any], z: [Any] ) ...
  ...
}
then just run the file.

http://blog.ajduke.in/2013/05/31/various-ways-to-run-scala-code/

title: Funtional Programming is Overrated
post_text:
It looks like someone woke upon the wrong side of the lambda this morning! :)

Honestly though, FP is just another tool in a developers toolbox. I do mainly Java at work, but I've been on something of a functional kick in my spare time in the last few months - I learned Haskell over the summer, and am picking up Scala and SML now. What I like about the FP paradigm is that it naturally lends itself to elegant recursive solutions.

What I've found is that when you use a language like Java that naturally lends itself to OO, you tend to think only in terms of object decomposition, and so it's easy to take something that has a simple recursive structure and turn it into objects that you deal with imperatively, and that hide that natural simple structure.

FP is just another way to think about a given problem. And generally, the more ways you have to tackle a problem, the better the final solution winds up looking.

title: Lecture 4.2: Succ class definition - method question
post_text:
If that is bigger than n, eventually the recursive calls to "-" will lead to one in which "this" is Zero and "that" is not Zero, which will throw the exception defined in Zero.-

As for your aside, this and n are not the same. n is the number that Succ(n) ("this") was built from. In terms of natural numbers, this = n + 1. But more accurately in the example we are discussing, Succ(n) is a Nat whose predecessor is n: Nat, and when a function is called on Succ(n) we refer to Succ(n) as "this" in the function body.

title: Assignment 4: 'Combine of some Leaf list' Test failure
post_text:
@Guilherme: ordering within the created Fork() isnt so important, the way its constructed will mean its almost balanced but there is no requirement that the left or right always be greater. Leaving attempted ordering out will make your life easier.-

Most people seem to have one of two difficulties

1- they try to solve the whole tree in one call.  As Pavel says above combine should only combine the two lowest weighted nodes, it shouldnt be recursive.  You will use combine in the until function to solve the whole tree.
2- they forget the important stipulation- combine must return the list in ascending order of weight (my first attempt neglected this and led to some weird trees)

title: Maintaining order in combine?
post_text:
I found that there are two approaches in maintaining ordering.

Method A: use sortWith:

Perform sorting to the whole list (e.g. with sortWith) every time we insert a new Fork element.

Method B: Sorting only the last element in case the list contains an odd number of elements; by relying on the fact that the list are originally inserted in ascending order. If the number of elements are even, then we do not need to perform sorting at all.

The list are guaranteed to be in ascending order by its weight. Consider for our example a list L containing 5 elements List(a, b, c, d, e), where the condition a < b < c < d < e holds.

Based on that property, it is then guaranteed that when we combine every two elements in L, the order will still hold e.g. a + b < c + d. However, we will need to reinsert e at the correct place e.g. by using sortWith. This condition applies to every list which contains an odd number of elements.

My question:

Do we really need to perform sorting here? If we really do then I feel like sorting the initial input (i.e. using makeOrderedLeafList) would not be of much use. Why would we need to sort it in the first place if we are going to sort it again due to inserting new elements?

It seems to me that this is the assumption made by the method :

I wanted to use this method to help me in my implementation of combine.

title: Combine(List[CodeTree]) = Combine(List[HuffmanTree]) ?
post_text:
Yes you can assume that the List contains only valid code trees.  There is no need to specially handle an empty list or any edge cases. The docco is clear on what to return for short lists.

Its especially important to conform to the second part of the requirements- combine assumes the input list is in ascending order but must assure that the return is also sorted in ascending order.

title: Maintaining order in combine?
post_text:
Combine assumes the input list is sorted so makeOrderedLeafList is required initially.  After that combine should keep it sorted.

However I suspect you are trying to do too much with combine:  it should be a one-pass function that takes the two lowest-weight nodes and combines them and inserts the result into the correct position in the list to ensure it remains sorted- there should be no recursion or iteration.  You will use combine() as an arguement to until() to process the entire list into a single tree.

title: mergeCodeTables with duplicate characters
post_text:
Guys please help me. I'm really stuck with mergeCodeTables.
Let's assume:
 - code table is List(('a', List(0)), ('b', List(1))) so it's code tree will be like Fork(Leaf('a',1), Leaf('b',2), List('a','b'), 3);
 - code table is List(('b', List(0)), ('a', List(1))) so it's code tree will be like Fork(Leaf('b',1), Leaf('a',2), List('b','a'), 3)

Is it really possible to merge this tables?

I'm stucking because for instance we have the same char in two code tables with the different bits. Is it possible?
If yes please someone give me a tip how to merge this two code tables.

My assumtion is too complicated: to convert code table to code tree, somehow merge code trees and then use convert().

title: mergeCodeTables with duplicate characters
post_text:
Hi Andrii,
I'm afraid you aren't seeing the "trick" that is intended here by whoever created this assignment. The good news, from the Assignment 4 FAQ, is that you don't have to use mergeCodeTables in convert.

I won't say too much to point you in the intended direction, since the assignment is intentionally vague about how to use mergeCodeTables and the course staff have not been explicit about it in the forums.

From the FAQ:

Do I really need to use mergeCodeTables in my implementation of convert?

Not really. The grader won't explicitly check for dependencies here. Using a certain approach to implementing mergeCodeTables will lead to a particularly elegant and succint version of convert, but that's not to say there cannot be elegant and succint implementations of convert that take a different approach.

title: sentenceAnagramsMemo without mutables?
post_text:
I implemented sentenceAnagramsMemo using a mutable map, which has the advantage that the map can be declared once in the outer function and accessed/modified by all recursive calls of the inner function.

I started trying a version with an immutable map (and no vars), but it seems that this is only possible if the code becomes significantly uglier. Every recursive call needs to have the updated memo, which is not a big deal. But each recursive call also needs to pack the memo into the return value as well, so its caller can pass the updated version in subsequent recursive calls.

This immediately made the code way less readable, especially within _for_ comprehensions. I eventually gave up. Is there, in general, a way to memoize functionally (i.e. immutable data structures and no vars) that doesn't complicate the code so harshly?

title: Huffman tree left and right branch definitions
post_text:
suspect your problem is similar to mine in this thread https://class.coursera.org/progfun-005/forum/thread?thread_id=775

The given algorithm doesn't necessarily recreate the tree in that order so the encodings are different although the weights  and character groups should be  the same.  There are a number of possible Huffman trees in the case (unlikely in a realistic example) that characters have equal weights.  Dont stress about it, it doesnt matter for the assignment.

title: mergeCodeTables with duplicate characters
post_text:
Its not possible to merge those code tables- nor should your algorithm ask to do so.

mergeCodeTables performs the same function for codeList's as makeCodeTree does for codeTree's: its not a simple concat.

title: Assignment 4 FAQ
post_text:
The whole mergeCodeTables question is interesting. I was able to implement convert with a simple two line pattern match helper function, but one step of the recursion was inefficient: the collecting the bits for the path down the tree. I knew it was inefficient but I can't sort out how to solve that problem without creating the list of bits in reverse.

title: Don't understand performance improvement
post_text:
The issue is that if you call your inner function with the same input, it will always return the same output.

As an example, I ran a test on the input sentence "beet beat bee beans" . Every time the inner function was called with input equal to List(('e', 3), ('n', 1), ('s', 1), ('t', 2)), I incremented a counter. The final value of this counter was 17. Each of these 17 times, the inner function did a bunch of computation then returned exactly the same value.

The idea behind memoizing is that, for example, in the course of computing the anagrams for "beet beat bee beans", if innerFunc(List(('e', 3), ('n', 1), ('s', 1), ('t', 2))) is called and evaluated, future calls with the exact same input should not require any additional computation, since we already know the answer.

title: sentenceAnagramsMemo without mutables?
post_text:
Memoizing almost by definition involves state mutation.
Functional programming almost by definition involves side-effect free programming (i.e. no state)

There is a way to overlap the two worlds through monads. You can think of map as returning the updated state across the collection you are mapping... to make such state work in a pure functional way you have to basically pass in your pre-cache into your memo function, return your updated cache out of the memo function and remember to pass your state around everywhere. If you were in Haskell, you'd pretty much have no choice but to do it this way. You may decide this is unwieldy and complicated.

Functional programming isn't a way to solve all problems. If you want state and side-effects, then I say that's exactly what vars are for!

title: sentenceAnagramsMemo without mutables?
post_text:
When I first started implementing an immutable version I got very messy code very quickly as I puzzled my way through the problem. Once I had a working solution, it was then possible to do some tidying and get back to more readable code.

As you said the recursive call needs to return a pair of the result and the improved cache, but Scala's pattern matching makes this pretty easy to de-construct readably. The other key was factoring the final generator out of the for loop and into a fold left, so that the result and cache pair could be built into an accumulator whilst keeping the code fairly simple.

To answer your question: I think this technique could be applied generally to similar solutions, but it is a matter of opinion if the complication to the code is too harsh. It is still nowhere near as concise as the non-cached version, but it offers a significant performance increase (14secs vs 5mins for List("scala", "is", "lots", "of", "fun") ), and maintains the immutability that then allows for e.g. easier parallel processing.

title: subtract Hint
post_text:
you can use foldLeft something like this:
val l1 = List(1,2,3,4)
val l2 = List(3,4)
l1.foldLeft(Nil)((acc, cur) => if (!l2.contains(cur)) cur::acc else acc)
The result of this will be elements of list l1 without elements of l2.
Its not hard to replace lists with maps [Char,Int] and adjust chars counters with update on accumulator map.

title: Case class definition
Lecture 5.5 mapFun
post_text:
The Scala compiler performs type inference in a local way. When you write 
mapFun2(xs, (_ == 3))
the compiler descends into the (_ == 3) part of the expression knowing only the constraints it saw in the level above, so the bound variable is unconstrained at this point.

The reason inference is so conservative, is that it unfortunately could not do any better: type inference in the presence of inheritance/method overloading is undecidable. If you are familiar with Haskell, you may know that the inferer of Haskell cannot infer all types in the presence of type classes either.

title: Lecture 4.2 - def Succ
post_text:
The actual implementation is the call to the constructor of Succ, i.e. exactly the call to new Succ(this). It says "allocate a new Succ object, and initialize its n field with this object". 

Your mentioning 1 + Succ makes me think you may have misunderstood something: These integers do not contain their usual "integer value" anywhere; rather, this values are represented by the number of nested Succ objects you have. For example 3 would be represented as new Succ(new Succ (new Succ( Zero ))).

Does it make it any clearer?

title: Assignment 5 FAQ
post_text:
This is a FAQ copied from a previous version of this course (003 to be exact), some information could be out-of-date. It is authored by Pavel Lepin

Do I need to watch week 5 / week 6 lectures for this assignment?

Yes. The assignment covers all of the material up to and including week 6.

Should I avoid recursion, explicit or implicit, in my solutions for this assignment?

The answer is definitely no for implicit, and not necessarily for explicit. Many of the functions we have to implement can be made more elegant through the use of for-expressions and/or HOFs. But if you feel a straightforward explicitly recursive solution makes more sense, go ahead and give it a shot.

May I use mutable variables in this assignment? It seems natural in some parts of it.

No. The same policy holds as with the rest of the course. Grader will dock points for the use of mutable variables. Anything that can be implemented with mutable variables, can also be implemented without them, and usually without much, if any, overhead in terms of source code readability.

My for-expressions do not compile due to cryptic type errors.

First of all, the sequence type of the first generator expression determines the sequence type for the entire for-expression - it's easy to run afoul of this.

Secondly, if you're still stuck, consider desugaring your for-expression following Prof. Odersky's explanations in the lectures, and rewriting it as a series of vals (perhaps even giving those explicit types to help you figure out where does the problem lie). This should help you figure out in which part of your expression the type mismatch actually is. (This may take a while, but it's very useful to go through this process at least once.) When you're working with nested lists, the most likely cause is that you've missed one level of nesting somewhere, or vice versa, introduced an unnecessary level of nesting. If you're using multiple containers you may need to use toList or such to make your types agree.

Lastly, one relatively common problem is figuring out how does the parser treat the expression after the yield. Something like for { ... } yield x :: xs means (for { ... } yield x) :: xs, while you probably wanted to say for { ... } yield (x :: xs).

What should I do about words containing characters not in the alphabet specified by the assignment handout?

The alphabet is not exhaustive, unfortunately. The good news is, you don't really need to know the alphabet at all to solve the assignment. If you just assume any characters may appear in the input, you solution will be fine with the grader.

Is the list of occurrences supposed to be in some specific order?

Yes. The Occurrences type comes with an implied invariant of always being sorted by the character. Your solutions may rely on the fact that all inputs provided to them fulfill said invariant, and must in turn ensure that all outputs returned by them do so as well. This is explicitly mentioned both in the assignment handout and in the source code comments.

Does wordOccurrences have to make use of groupBy?

Yes. The use of groupBy here is required by the grader.

Is there an easy way to make a Word out of a Sentence?

Yes. Look up mkString in the documentation.

My dictionaryByOccurences breaks on words not in the dictionary. How do I fix it?

Using withDefaultValue - this was shown in the lectures discussing the Map[T, V] containers.

I'm totally lost on combinations. How do I do it?

One way (not necessarily the best one) to approach this problem would be to think about properties of combinations inductively. What are the combinations of an empty set? Given the list of combinations for some set A, how do you obtain a list of combinations for a set A with an extra element X included in it?

May my implementation of subtract assume that it's not going to be provided an y that is not a subset of x?

Yes.

Do I have to use the suggested functions for my implementation of subtract?

No. Doing so will be quite instructive, but the grader won't check for implementation details here, as long as your subtract implements the behavioural requirements.

What is the list of anagrams of an empty sentence?

It's a list consisting of empty sentence itself. (That is, an empty list.)

How do I filter out "incomplete" anagrams?

One way to ensure that would be to implement previous parts of the assignment in such a way that the list of anagrams for a word not in the dictionary would be empty.

Dictionary file seems to be missing some words I assumed would be there.

Yeah. Do not assume a common word will be in it. When in doubt, check it.

How about mutability in the challenge assignment?

You should not submit this part of your code, especially if you do this with mutable containers. Note that while doing this with mutable containers is the most straightforward way to do this, it's not strictly necessary, as Scala already has the fundamental "caching" mechanism implemented in form of lazy vals. Given those, we can do the rest without mutable data structures. Also note that in pure world lazy evaluation strategy is equivalent to call-by-name to the factor of computational complexity - that is, it's an optimization that preserves expression semantics.

title: Over recursive
Over recursive
post_text:
I don't know C#, but I know that it's similar to Java. So from Java point of view the List is interface and it can be both ArrayList and LinkedList. In case the LinkedList is passed to the function, getting the last element from the list using list.get(length - 1) is not a constant time operation and would traverse the whole list to find the last element, so it's O(n) operation.
And since the last(ys) is a last call in a function in the Scala code you provided, this will be optimized by compiler and there will be no stack overflow.
From this point of view last() recursive function call is not that different from Java's LinkedList.get(length-1). No need to worry.

title: Over recursive
post_text:
For me, there are several reasons to use immutable data structures, immutable values instead of mutable variables, and especially to prevent null values.

I've listed them in descending order of priority:
1. Concurrency: it's safe to share immutable objects.
2. Maintainability (1): Because values never change, I never have to worry whether they have changed.
3. Maintainability (2): immutable objects that never contain nulls describe what you can expect. This is a huge improvement over the Java Beans object pattern.
4. Garbage collection optimization: immutable objects can only refer to older objects, so the GC never has to do old-to-young generation scans

I'll happily take (tail) recursion to avoid variables, and I tend only to compromise on that when readbility suffers.
Ignoring ingrained habits, this happens quite infrequently. It's far more easy to avoid both variables and recursion, by using functions like map, filter, fold, etc.

title: Over recursive
post_text:
Peter - you're comparing apples and oranges... or rather singly linked lists and vector/arrays

 Scala also has immutable vectors/arrays - try comparing with those.
Or I think .NET also has a LinkedList class (albeit possibly doubly linked).

 A singly linked list in any implementation requires you to traverse all the links to get to the last element. If you need to get last, then don't use List. Unless you're developing on a strictly academic exercise :)
