title: Over recursive
post_text:
Linked lists are often used when teaching functional programming to beginners because their structure mimics the simplest type of recursive function, namely "a List of Ints is either Nil or it is an Int followed by a List of Ints". Lists are not optimized for random access, and should probably not be used in an application if that's going to change your asymptotic runtime for the worse.

In a first-year Java class, one might learn how to compute the sum of an array of ints. However, in practice, if you were writing an application where you repeatedly modified an array of ints and recomputed its sum, you would switch to a data structure that retains a running sum and updates this sum whenever the array is modified. The fact that a simple array isn't the most efficient solution in every application doesn't make it a poor teaching tool.

I agree with you, though, that making copies of large data structures is a bad idea. I have cringed more than a few times when learning FP at how much more space-efficient a simple solution with mutable data structures can be. I don't have a good answer for you there, but maybe someone with more practical FP experience can offer some insight (or maybe not, which would be a real bummer).

title: Over recursive
post_text:
@Peter: I'm able to reproduce your above failure.  The JVM was using a little over 300MB when it crashed.  You need to run with more memory.  Scala uses the JVM, so you're dependent on the amount of memory the JVM is allowed to use, which by default may not be enough.  Try giving more memory to Scala:

scala -J-Xmx1g

Running like that, I don't get OOM.  This is with Scala 2.10.4

> the scala code was executed in the scala command line, I executed it many times and it gave
> the same result each time, so it's an implementation problem and not a JIT issue.

In the JVM, methods may have to be called hundreds or thousands of times before they are compiled as opposed to interpreted.  (I don't know enough about the CLR to compare.)  Doing something a dozen times is not enough to cause it to be compiled, so in that case you're running interpreted code, not native code.  This is a problem with microbenchmarks.  See, for example, http://stackoverflow.com/questions/504103/how-do-i-write-a-correct-micro-benchmark-in-java

> If we have to use different classes depending on which order we intend to traverse a collection
> of data (which might be determined at runtime) then scala isn't delivering the promise of allowing
> us to write what we want, rather than writing how to do what we want.

I disagree.  In any language, you have to think about how your data structure will be used and choose accordingly.  This is why Java offers ArrayList, LinkedList, Deque, and other list and list-like options.  If you need random access to a long list, don't use a linked list.

One disadvantage of an immutable linked list is that accessing or changing a single element at the end is expensive in terms of memory and CPU.  If you're doing that a lot, you wouldn't use an immutable linked list, just as you didn't in C#.  There's nothing in Scala stopping you from using the Java standard library collections or Scala mutable collections if they are a better fit for what you are doing.  But once you start using them in a multi-threaded fashion, you're back to using locks or synchronization.

I think the point of the recursive algorithms is that they're trying to teach the different way of thinking.  This doesn't mean that everything you do in functional programming has to be recursive (or tail-recursive).  But the only way to learn to think that way is to do it, over and over, until it starts to feel normal.

title: Lecture 7.7 encode function
post_text:
Key point 1 is that the for loop yields an empty list when one of the generators does not generate anything.

The most restrictive generator here is in line *1. Thus, if no prefix of the number argument encodes a valid word, the for loop yields an empty list. Due to the if statement, this happens when the number is not empty.

Key point 2 is that the if clause returns the empty result, which the for loop uses as rest to build a solution with. Without it, the for loop also terminates, but it will always yield an empty list.

     assert(pack(data) === List(List("a", "a", "a"), List("b"), List("c", "c"), List("a")))
  }

"generators vary faster" -- this is not about speed of execution, but the order in which they are queried.
In your case, for smallRange = 1..2 and largeRange = 1..4
the first for would result in
a b
- -
1 1
1 2
1 3
1 4
2 1
2 2
2 3
2 4

while the second in
a b
- -
1 1
2 1
1 2
2 2
1 3
2 3
1 4
2 4

title: Lecture 6.5 - understanding flatMap with for
post_text:
Hi,

I don't get this:
def flatMap[T, U](xs: List[T], f: T => Iterable[U]): List[U] =
  for (x <- xs; y <- f(x)) yield y

title: Lecture 6.5 - understanding flatMap with for
post_text:
Ok, I got it. The explanation came later in the lecture.

Generators are combined using a flatMap inernally, this means each y will be concatinated with the next y. So the the Iterables are concatinated to each other and not appended to a List of Iterables. Latter would be the case if map() was internally used for concatinating generators instead.

title: When should I use "toList" or "toList()"?
post_text:
toList is defined as: 

    def toList: List[A] = to[List]

so you should invoke it without the parentheses. For scala calling scala, you typically want to invoke a method the way it's defined. For scala calling java, the scala compiler provides a bit of sugar that allows you to drop the parentheses when invoking no-arg methods. For example, because String.toLowerCase is a Java method defined as: 

    public String toLowerCase() {
        return toLowerCase(Locale.getDefault());
    }

You can invoke it either as: 

"example".toLowerCase()
// or
"example".toLowerCase

Both are the same. But when a scala method is defined without the parens, don't try to include them when invoking it.

title: combinations
post_text:
I had a lot of trouble with this one initially, partly because I kept trying to use a recursive loop with an iterator, and kept trying to reconstruct the input with the various counts modified down to nothing. What really helped me was this comment from the FAQ:

I'm totally lost on combinations. How do I do it?
One way (not necessarily the best one) to approach this problem would be to think about properties of combinations inductively. What are the combinations of an empty set? Given the list of combinations for some set A, how do you obtain a list of combinations for a set A with an extra element X included in it?

Thinking about that led me down the right path for the final implementation. I also started with a var that I modified to make it easier to think about, then replaced that with an in-place implementation to get rid of the var. My final solution ended up being about 7 lines, and I couldn't really see a way to make it much more compact.

title: sentenceAnagramsMemo without mutables?
post_text:
The algo that I use is the following:
  • for the given sentence figure out the occurrence list and the combinations
  • Next using foldLeft figure out all the sentences (using a recursive sub routine called anagrams for a single occurrence) for each subset and add them to the list to return
  • anagrams for a single occurrence does the following
  1. Figure out words which match the occurrence, if found proceed further else return Nil
  2. If words are found, then figure out remaining occurrences using subtract, similarly figure out the remaining combinations using subtract (I pass along the original combinations list)
  3. Recursively call the top level function to get all sentences for the remaining occurrence.
Is this what you guys use as well? I tried to Memo this function and it works well using Mutable variables, the moment I make it functional (via exactly how you have described above by passing Tuples), it takes much longer time. I suspect that the map concat is taking longer time.

title: I dislike being required to implement inefficient solutions
post_text:
Why is the code table not a Map[Char, List[Bit]]?  The assignment says "for efficiency" I should use a code table, but if I'm not mistaken, the complexity is the same for the code table solution than the straight up CodeTree solution.

The CodeTree solution is a tree, but not a binary tree; it is one of the "degenerate" cases, where each node has one Leaf and one Fork subnode.  Therefore the depth of the tree is equal to the number of characters encoded in it.  So to lookup the average character requires O(N) traversals.

The allegedly more efficient Code Table solution is a linked list, also requiring O(N) traversals.

Could I not just implement quickEncode in terms of normal Encode and handin, claiming that my solution is as efficient as the intended one?  What really irks me about this is that the Map[] based solution actually WOULD be more efficient - but I have the feeling if I change the solution to actually be more efficient (ie use maps) the grader won't be able to interface with my solution correctly.

title: is xs.length O(1) ? how it is implemented if SCALA is not mutable ?
post_text:
It is O(n) because of list recursive structure. 
From http://stackoverflow.com/questions/8197655/why-doesnt-the-scala-list-have-a-size-field:
"The "disadvantage" of O(n) complexity is not as big as you might think. Martin Odersky mentioned in a talk that (if I remember correctly) 90% of all lists created in all programs in any computer language have a size of 4 or less. (This was in the context of immutability and efficiency)

Therefore, O(n) access time for size is not such a big overhead for most lists created, and, as others have mentioned here, memory savings more than compensates for this."

title: Which is more efficient/readable: isEmpty or pattern match
post_text:
No efficiency to be gained. The readability not improved in this example by pattern matching (if at all), but it is improved a lot if you use fields that are only used in one of the subclasses. Imagine something like 
abstract class Foo
case class Bar(i1 : Int, i2 : Int, i3 : Int, tail : Foo) extends Foo
case object Baz extends Foo

def sum( foo : Foo ) : Int = foo match {
  case Baz => 0
  case Bar(i1,i2,i3,tail) => i1 + i2 + i3 + sum(tail)
}

The respective OO version would contain type tests and casts and multiple field retrievals.

title: When should I use "toList" or "toList()"?
post_text:
The convention is that you include the parentheses when the function has side-effects. The reasoning is that, when it does have side-effects, you want to show explicitly that you are calling a function which may affect something. When there are no side-effects, there is in principle no need to make the syntax any different than a field retrieval; in fact, you want to hide if what you are calling is implemented as a val or def. So you write 

list.length
but
println()

title: Explanation of until
post_text:
This is a common pattern. First function is used to test whether the recursive function should finish or continue, and second function is used to transform the object in some way and pass it on recursively. These functions are in the first parentheses. Second parentheses are for the object itself.

function f(p1, p2)(p3):
apply p1(p3) to check termination
apply p2(p3) and pass the result to f (in other words, call f(p1, p2)(result))

One could also define until with just one argument, p3, and hardcode the p1 and p2 in its body. However, by putting p1 and p2 in the parameters you can provide the until function with any functions p1 and p2 that satisfy the type parameters, which makes it more flexible.

title: 4.2 another way to define + operation on the Succ class
post_text:
Yes, that will work, this will decrease and that will increase every iteration until this hits 0.
There are even more ways of writing the + and - defs, when I did the exercise I ended up with the following in the abstract class.
def + (that: Nat): Nat = if (that.isZero) this else successor + that.predecessor
def - (that: Nat): Nat = if (that.isZero) this else predecessor - that.predecessor

post_text: You need to make sure the type of 'singleton' (should be a function from list to boolean) matches the type of the first parameter of 'until'. What type is your first parameter in until? i.e. what do you have for xxx in until(xxx, yyy)(zzz) ?

title: createCodeTree extracting the singleton
post_text: You're over thinking it! Remember List.head and tail from the early lectures :)

title: createCodeTree extracting the singleton
post_text:
I am not sure what exactly are you trying to do, since signature of until ideally should be a code tree and not a list of code tree. You already have a list of code tree that you are going to pass to until, why would you like to pull the head of that list again after smashing it to one entity in until. If you read the documentation in the skeleton provided you will see this comment for until as

In such an invocation, `until` should call the two functions until the list of
code trees contains only one single tree, and then return that singleton list.

You are going to recursively apply merge on the list of code tree till you are left with just a code tree, that you would return. Does that clear things up, or did I add to confusion?

title: createCodeTree extracting the singleton
post_text: Soham -- I considered both and decided to have mine return a list rather than a single element. Your reasoning makes sense to me but I went with a more general / extensible 'until'. Even though the 'until' in this specific use case will be used to recursively merge until you are left with one element, a general 'until' may recursively perform a function 'f' on a list until the list satisfies a condition 'cond', in this case the condition is that the list be size 1.

title: is xs.length O(1) ? how it is implemented if SCALA is not mutable ?
post_text:
Different data structures for different jobs. That's linked list for you. Calculating size of or accessing the end of a list is alway O(n), mutable or immutable (barring memoization as demonstrated by Emmanouil).

Also, just to point out, Scala itself allows mutable objects and it's possible for Scala immutable types to use mutability during method implementation; there's nothing stopping the library implementation of immutable.List.size() from using a mutable counter and iterating through the lists until the end...

...I wrote the previous sentence without really knowing how size() is implemented, but as best I can tell, immutable.List.size() DOES use a mutable object! I could be wrong but I believe it inherits an implementation of size() from the following location: https://github.com/scala/scala/blob/2.11.x/src/library/scala/collection/TraversableOnce.scala#L103

The reason I say I could be wrong is that I navigated to TraversableOnce from List strictly through github's web interface, and I want to leave open the possibility that List inherits a different implementation of size() from somewhere else. Still, no reason why it has to use strictly immutable objects in implementation as long as it provides immutable collections to the user.

title: Handling encoding of characters not in code tree
post_text: I think you missed the point of the Huffman algorithm. It minimizes the size of a list of characters (a text file is an example) for compression. So the only characters that need to be encoded are characters that occur within the list of characters found in your text file.

title: sentenceAnagramsMemo without mutables?
post_text:
I've implemented the memo-solution with no mutable variables. I'm not sure it is the best way, but I'll describe it.
My approach was to start from the smallest occurrences, finding words and sentences for them and then build up to the bigger occurrences and then up to the uppermost occurrence. This can be compared with building the tree starting with leaf nodes and then building up to the root.
Also I decided not to return the tuple of a sentence and a memo map from the function (List[Sentence], Memo), but only the memo map, which anyway includes the information about sentences for this particular occurrence.
The solution worked faster, but unfortunately it hit the memory limit on bigger sentence (like  List("scala", "is", "lots", "of", "fun")). Then I decided to use the map only for smaller occurrences, and use the usual recursive algorythm for bigger ones. So it was already a two-step solution: memo-precomputation -> find-anagrams-recursively. By this approach it took me 24 sec to make anagrams for List("scala", "is", "lots", "of", "fun").

title: No idea how to start writing the times() function
post_text:
Here are a few thoughts about deciding whether to use built-in methods or to write most everything from scratch.

Perhaps it depends on where you are in your journey, but perhaps not, if you are able to manage this course at all. For me, with programming experience that surely lacks some fundamentals, but which happens to have made me familiar with operations like sortBy and foldList, I think my learning is more efficient if I look at library functions such as are on the "Scala Cheat Sheet" or found by a little Googling. Here are my reasons, including and supplementing those already given, I wouldn't feel bad about it.

1. I need to learn Scala methods if I want to use Scala effectively.
2. To follow and absorb the lectures and do these assignments there is already PLENTY to do and think about and struggle over (for me, anyway). If I can properly use a library function, I feel a gain in knowledge, no loss, and no feeling of missed opportunity. (And it makes it more likely I can submit in a timely manner! As well as to get back and take in all that is done in the lectures.)
3. If used as intended, library functions are going to be optimized better than anything I would write; and likely implemented in ways entirely different than I would do.
4. Surely it is sound FP thinking to be appropriately exploiting the available higher-order functions, such as map, which is what I happened to use in my "times" function.
5. Working with standard built-ins seems to advance my ability to use the language more than putting together equivalent code from primitive elements. For example, foldLeft is well suited for the "encode" function: the (worthwhile) work one must then do is find precisely an appropriate function of type (List[Bit], Char) => List[Bit] to put into the foldLeft. 
6. For my submissions, the use of map, foldLeft, sortBy did not elicit any complaints from the grader.

From my perspective, proper use of established technology is a good thing, and aids learning, even for a novice; in fact, it is what I want to learn. Reinventing wheels, not so much. When you really need to build a wheel for the learning benefit it brings—this is usually pretty clear, and occurs often enough in this course's lecture examples and questions—just dig in.

title: I dislike being required to implement inefficient solutions
post_text:
[CodeTree] ... each node has one Leaf and one Fork subnode

Only in nodes adjacent to leaves. Most of the nodes should have Forks, i.e. subtrees under them - see the picture on the assignment page. The depth should be close to log2(Number of characters).

Map[] based solution actually WOULD be more efficient

For encoding - yes. Once this map is built - it would be faster to encode a string into bits.

For decoding you would still need to recreate CodeTree from your map of char->bits and that might be not a trivial (or even inambiguous?) task, probably more complex than this assignment. With CodeTree we can do both operations using the same structure...

Also, space-wise, I feel like it might be significant only if you pack bits into real bits instead of using lists/arrays of integers... Running numbers on a toy example of 8 characters I get 168 bytes for map char->bits of integers (4 bytes per integer) vs 120 bytes for CodeTree, assuming that weights are removed from CodeTree (since they are not needed for encoding/decoding) and the root node is empty (since characters are not used there).

Update: Just saw what quickEncode is in the assignment. My comment still stands - quickEncode would not help with efficient decoding much.

title: sentenceAnagrams help
post_text:
Let me share with you some hints that helped me to pass this assignment - unit tests do not cover these:

  1. Make sure that your sentenceOccurrences() return empty list if empty sentence is given
  2. Make sure that your dictionaryByOccurrences() returns empty list if specific occurrence does not exist in map. This was covered in the lectures
  3. Make sure that your subtract() method is sorted (the actual hint from code comment). This was also covered in the lectures

Another tip: use interactive shell as much as you can and experiment. Experiment a lot. Print intermediate results to check if your algorithm works as expected. Here's how you can do it:

  1. in sbt start console by typing console
  2. load source files (assuming you have started sbt in top level directory forcomp)
     :load src/main/scala/forcomp/package.scala
 :load src/main/scala/forcomp/Anagrams.scala
  3. there may be some errors saying illegal start of definition or eof expected but '}' found. but they are not critical and you can skip them
  4. import Anagrams object methods (the methods you are supposed to implement) by typing import Anagrams._
  5. Voila! you can now implement your functions interactively and test them
  6. Note: if you redefine any of the methods, make sure that you define again all the methods that use it.

With regards to sentenceAnagrams() I'm not sure that my solution is most optimized, but it passes grading system. Here are few tips (hope that I do not reveal to much):

  1. Recall N-Queens algorightm - you need a helper method. What does it mean helper(k - 1) in terms of words and sentences?
  2. my helper method contains one for expression with three generators, one of them calls helper recursively
  3. think about stop condition - when do you know, that the sentence you produced is an anagram of original sentence?
  4. My entire solution takes 8 lines of code.

I hope that these tips will help some of you as much as other posts were so much help to me during the entire course. Good luck.

title: Two ways to implement mergeCodeTables()
post_text:
I found that there are two possible ways to implement 

mergeCodeTables() but only one of them can pass the grader.

Given the signature 

def mergeCodeTables(a: CodeTable, b: CodeTable)

One way is to add 1 to the front of every bit sequence of the longer CodeTable and add 0 to the shorter one. For example, if a.length < b.length, then call 

a.map( A=>(A._1, 0 :: A._2))
which implicitly means the left sub-tree of the original CodeTree is shorter than the right one. 

Another way is the opposite, namely, add 0 to the front of every bit sequence of the longer CodeTable but add 1 to the shorter, which implicitly means the right subtree of the original CodeTree is smaller than the left one.

I found that the second way of implementation can pass the grader but the first one cannot. However, the figure in the assignment instruction indicates that in a huffman tree, the left subtree is not larger than the right one, which contradicts with the second way of implementation. 

What's wrong here, did I understand correctly? Hope I have explained it clearly.

title: I have a question regarding lecture 4.2
post_text:
Zero.successor == Zero.successor returns false, because it creates a new, different '1' for each time you use new, unless you override equals.

To get the value you could add a method value that returns 0 for Zero and 1 + predecessor.value for Succ.

title: combine : Cannot insert the new created Fork back into the list
post_text:
Remember: there is Leaf.weight and Fork.weight but no CodeTree.weight. Since your List is a List[CodeTree], you cannot use .weight on its elements directly.

I see two options (both have their downsides):

a. Do some more pattern matching on the head.

b. Use the weight(tree: CodeTree): Int function.

title: ++ versus #:::
post_text:
When solving the Bloxorz assignment, I was stumped for some time because my program seemed to enter an infinite loop on trying to solve the InfiniteLevel. Initially I couldn't find anything wrong with my code, thinking I had used Streams in all the right ways.

Turns out that at some point I used ++ to concatenate two streams, which apparently doesn't (always) result in a lazily evaluated stream. This caused my solver to map the entire solution space before returning the shortest solution, which is fine for the finite levels, but doesn't terminate on the InfiniteLevel.

When I changed ++ to #::: (or append) everything started to work as expected.

My question is: why does this happen? Can someone explain the difference between these two ways of concatenating Streams?

title: How to ensure tail recursion?
post_text:
In the lectures, Prof. Odersky shows an example of map implemented like this:

case x::xs => f(x) :: xs.map(xs)

and he notes that the real implementation in scala is more complex in order to be tail recursive where this implementation is not.

Q: Is it possible to have the compiler detect functions that are intended to be tail recursive, but are not?  In other words, I'd like to annotate the definition of a function telling the compiler to generate an error if the actual function I write does not actually produce the tail-recursion optimization.

Such a warning would be incredibly useful for someone learning to write efficient functional code.

title: sentenceAnagrams help
size of objects?
post_text:
Two options:

A. You could use a regular class instead of a case class:
package sos2

class SOS (x: Int, y: Int){
  val d = x * x + y * y
}
Of course, you will have to do without the benefits of case classes then.

B. Declare the case class with the value you want to keep and compute its value before construction, for example using an extra apply method:
package sos2

case class SOS (d: Int)

object SOS{
  def apply(x: Int, y:Int): SOS = SOS(x * x + y * y)
}

title: How to ensure tail recursion?
post_text:
Put @tailrec before the def of a function, this should give an error (because it adds 1 to the result of the recursive call):
import annotation.tailrec
object test {
  @tailrec def length[T](xs: List[T]): Int = xs match {
	  case Nil => 0
	  case head :: tail => 1 + length(tail)
  }
}

trait Expr2 {

title: ++ versus #:::
post_text: The signatures of these functions are different. ++ takes an argument by value, so this value has to be computed at the place of the call. #:: takes an argument by name, so this argument can be computed later. Together with lazy evaluation this produces the desired effect - the evaluation starts only when it is required.

title: subtract Hint
post_text:
Yes, this will be pretty useful when you will try to find the possible anagrams for the sentence. Imagine that with this function you are subtracting one occurrence (word) from a larger one (sentence). As you subtract the word occurrence from the sentence occurrence you have the remaining possible words occurrences. The algorithm is pretty clever.
I had to make another method to check if the word occurrence is indeed fully contained in the sentence occurrence because this is the condition stated for the method subtract.

title: Two ways to implement mergeCodeTables()
post_text:
The left subtree to be smaller than the right one is not a strict necessity. If you look at the tree in the homework, then notice that the right branch which is a valid tree in itself; its right branch EFGH 4, has a smaller weight than left branch BCD 5.

What is necessity that the leaf with higher weight appears at a shallower depth, than that of leaf with lower weight. Hope this helps.

Hi Eduardo,

Thanks for contacting us about a problem with the videos for your course! Do these steps help?

1. Check that you’re using a supported browser. Coursera supports the most recent versions of Google Chrome (recommended), Firefox, Safari, and Internet Explorer. You may need to update your browser:http://browsehappy.com/.

If you’re already using a supported browser, clear your browser cookies and cache:https://kb.iu.edu/d/ahic.

2. Change your video player using the Settings menu (gear icon) in the bottom right of the video player. Coursera offers an HTML and a Flash video player.

3.Test your Internet connection on another video streaming site, such as YouTube:https://www.youtube.com/. If you can’t play any videos, you may be experiencing a connection problem.

4. Download the videos and view them offline. You can download videos by clicking the icons to the right of the video title on the video index page.

Please let me know if you’re still having trouble after trying the steps above. Happy learning!

Coursera Community Operations

title: FAQ?
post_text:
In the previous session of the course someone made a nice FAQ in the forums. I'm not sure if you can still access it if you're not already registered, but in any case here is the link: https://class.coursera.org/progfun-004/forum/thread?thread\_id=1222.

Regarding your question about from: the idea is that it generates a stream of paths, where (depending on what the initial stream contains) the first element is the empty path, the next few elements are all the possible paths of length 1 that can be reached from the starting position, the next elements after that are all the possible paths of length 2 that can be reached from the starting position, et cetera.

Once you have that stream, your Bloxorz solver can just walk through the stream until you find a path that leads to the goal. Because the paths in the stream are ordered by length, the first solution you find is also the shortest.

I'm not an expert on type errors- they are very frustrating!   Can only suggest using a worksheet or the sbt console to try out each command and see what the types are.  I suspect (without proof) that the compiler isnt always accurate in pointing out where the problem is within the expression. I would try changing the return type of the function temporarily to see if that allows it to compile.

List[List[Product]]] is a list of lists of Product. From googling "Product" seems to be a supertype of List so maybe your combinations function isnt returning what its supposed to-maybe an Option is finding its way in there..

Finally you might improve efficiency if you put the test ahead of the subSolution- it seems like wasted effort to solve the subSolution if your first word isnt even in the dictionary.

title: lecture 7.3 at 9" performance difference
post_text:
In lecture 7.3 at 9", an exercise is given on the difference in performance in two ways to express the infinite stream of multiples of a given number.
 
I coded this in a worksheet, see below.

In the video the map example is expected to generate results faster.
However, my test code gives opposite results.

You can cut and paste the code below in a worksheet. I get 158 ms for the map implementation and 29 ms for the filter solution.

Kind regards, Hugo

def from(n: Int): Stream[Int] = n #:: from(n + 1)

val xs = from(1) map (_ * 3) val ys = from(1) filter (_ % 3 == 0) val n = 10000 val t1: Long = System.currentTimeMillis xs.take(n).toList val t2: Long = System.currentTimeMillis println("map solution: " + (t2 - t1).toString) val tb1: Long = System.currentTimeMillis ys.take(n).toList val tb2: Long = System.currentTimeMillis println("filter solution: " + (tb2 - tb1).toString)

title: lecture 7.3 at 9" performance difference
post_text:
In lecture 7.3 at 9", an exercise is given on the difference in performance in two ways to express the infinite stream of multiples of a given number.
 
I coded this in a worksheet, see below.

In the video the map example is expected to generate results faster.
However, my test code gives opposite results.

You can cut and paste the code below in a worksheet. I get 158 ms for the map implementation and 29 ms for the filter solution.

Kind regards, Hugo

def from(n: Int): Stream[Int] = n #:: from(n + 1)
val xs = from(1) map (_ * 3)
val ys = from(1) filter (_ % 3 == 0)

val n = 10000


val t1: Long = System.currentTimeMillis

xs.take(n).toList
val t2: Long = System.currentTimeMillis
println("map solution: " + (t2 - t1).toString)

val tb1: Long = System.currentTimeMillis

ys.take(n).toList
val tb2: Long = System.currentTimeMillis
println("filter solution: " + (tb2 - tb1).toString)

title: Feedback and Thank You
post_text:
Just finished the week 7 assignment. Most of the assignments are really neat. But the last one is really great.

In a retrospective, I had a lot of fun doing this course. However, there is a thing or two you might want to consider:

What did I considered as remarkably good and helped me a lot?

- Blending the video of your desk over the slides. While it does not appear to be that important it makes following your explanations much easier if one can follow your actual workflow. In most other courses here on Coursera slide-annotations just pop up all over the place, requiring me to pause and seek back and forth to check what actually just changed and why. Do you use a special software / equipment to achieve this?

- Assignments where one has to accomplish a larger task that is broken into several parts.

- The output of your assignment checking tool is great. Apparently, I often tend to forget checking special conditions like "Nil"-inputs. ;-)


What was not so good?

- The audio of some videos is very noisy. Through my laptop's speakers it was sometimes almost impossible to understand you. Playing around with the equalizer of VLC helped a little bit. (Hence, maybe you could try to denoise it?)

- I was unable to import your projects into IntelliJ (which I normally use for writing Code). The example steps from the video did not work. However, I did not bother because downloading ScalaIDE (which I, after doing the assignments in this environment, consider as totally buggy) was the easier solution.
Platform: IntelliJ 13, Oracle Java 8, LinuxMint 17

- The signature track instructions should be revised (see my other post)
https://class.coursera.org/progfun-005/forum/thread?thread_id=667


Anyway, this course has helped me to understand the potential of Scala. I have begun working on a larger project in Scala and what I have learned here allowed me leave the OO-Mindset, that I have acquired throughout the past 15 years, behind. I will definitely design some functions different (i.e. more functional) because of the things I learned in this course.

~tel

title: Best way to write "add to head of list if"
"from" not lazy
post_text:
Thanks to Robbert's post I think I understand how from should behave.  However I can't get it to evaluate lazily.  It tries to build the whole solution space (and eventually fails with StackOverflowError), even if I only ask for one element.  For example, when I invoke it like this:
from(List((startBlock, Nil)).toStream, Set(startBlock)).take(1)
(and all the other solution generating code commented out).  And this is without updating explored -- I haven't figured out how to do that yet.  (At least, not correctly, I don't think.)

Are there any techniques for investigating what causes a Stream to be realised unexpectedly?  Everything Martin did in the videos "just worked"!

title: Best way to write "add to head of list if"
post_text:
Personally, I don't think there's anything wrong with the first version... it's very clear and fairly concise. Having to repeat a variable name isn't really "code repetition."

Here's an alternate to the second way:

List(headElem).filter(_ => cond) ::: restOfList

To be honest I still prefer the first way. Maybe someone else knows a way cooler way, but it seems fine to me as is.

title: "from" not lazy
post_text:
Never mind.  I had tried the ++ and ++: operators to concat streams in from, because that's all I could find in the scala api docs for Streams.  These return concatenated streams, but also force an evaluation of the rhs, even if it isn't needed yet.  This triggered a cascade of recursive calls to from and eventually StackOverflowError.

I just needed to use #::: instead.

title: Feedback and Thank You
post_text:
Your setup is near identical to mine. I had some trouble getting IntelliJ running with Scala initially; I updated scala version and reverted Java version to 7. My understanding is that current versions of scala don't work great on Java 8; that's supposed to change with Scala 2.12.

I never had problems loading, running, and submitting projects once everything was set up.

If you want to keep Java 8 as your default Java, you can create a script java7_idea.sh that sets your IDEA_JDK to your Java7 home dir (/usr/lib/jvm/java-7-oracle on my machine) before calling idea.sh and plop that on your path (assuming idea.sh is also on your path).

title: Type Error with List[(Char, Int)] is not List[(Occurences)]. why compiler give me an error?
post_text:
Since
type Occurrences = List[(Char, Int)]
then
List[Occurrences]  = List[List[(Char, Int)]]

Imagine Occurences as a stack of scrabble tiles you are going to make a single word out of.   if you want to make a sentence you need several such stacks in a certain order- this is List[Occurences].

title: Lecture 6.7 encode method missing some filter?
post_text: Remember, there can be zero or more words that match a given digit-string - and the for loop is considering all of those options in separate iterations. Having a for loop with a variable ranging over an empty sequence will essentially skip that part of the loop in the same way that a traditional for loop such as for(i=0; i<0; i++) will not execute anything.

title: How to import trait GameDef into scala worksheet?
post_text:
GameDef is a trait, so you have to create an object based on it first if you want to use it in a worksheet. For example:

package common

import streams.Bloxorz
import streams.GameDef

object test {

  // Create a game
  val game = new GameDef {
    val startPos = Pos(1,1)
    val goal = Pos(5,5)
    val terrain = ((p: Pos) => true)
  }       
  // Now do stuff with it.
  game.Pos(2, 2).x

  // You can also use one of the predefined levels, such as this one
  Bloxorz.InfiniteLevel.startPos
}

title: Assignment 6 FAQ
post_text:
This is a FAQ copied from a previous version of this course (003 to be exact), some information could be out-of-date. It is authored by Pavel Lepin

Any ideas on testing my solutions?

You could try using a few levels from the original flash game and see whether your algo manages to find a correct solution.

Which one is x, and which one is y as far as Pos is concerned?

If you're accesing a vector of vectors representing the terrain, you should index by x first, and by y second.

What do the two positions supplied to Block constructor represent?

The positions of two blocks comprising the playing piece. If the playing piece is standing upright, both are the same, otherwise the two positions are adjacent.

May I assume coordinates supplied to terrainFunction will not be out-of-bounds?

No. You should explicitly check for coordinates being within bounds. Both ways.

What does terrainFunction really mean?

Whether you can place a block (vertically) without ending the game at given coordinates.

Is neighborsWithHistory supposed to produce an infinite stream of positions?

No, don't overthink it. You only need to generate immediate neighbors. The rest will be handled by functions implemented later in the assignment.

How is my from supposed to handle infinite terrain?

Naturally. The tail of a stream will not be evaluated unless needed. Since solution only takes the first path to goal, the entire infinite solution space will not be explored (as long as there's some solution in it). There's an important caveat here: the behavior of ++ is unintuitive, as it will, in fact, force partial evaluation of its second operand. Just use #::: instead, which is the equivalent of ++, but behaves sensibly for lazy streams, never touching its second operand.

Running Bloxxorz causes stack overflow.

See the answer to the previous question.

Can't we just determine explored from initial in from?

initial may represent a partially explored space, so no.

I'm having a hard time debugging and/or dealing with type errors in from.

Try decomposing your logic through the use of vals, perhaps giving your expessions explicit types.

My solution blows up when graded - what should solution return when no solution is possible?

An empty List, as the comments suggest.

Lastly, just hang on in there. You're very close to completing this class, which is no small feat, and if you worked through the lectures and previous assignments, you should be up to this last climb.

title: lecture 7.3 at 9" performance difference

As always with microbenchmarks, the JIT may also be skewing results in favor of the second call.

title: Lecture 6.4 - why does changing the List[book] to Set[Book] change the result?
post_text: The result of the for-comprehension will be of the same type as the original collection it is called on (there are some exceptions but let's not get into that). This means that if you start with a List you will and up with a List (which may contain duplicates), and if you start with a Set you will end up with a Set (which contains no duplicates, by construction).

title: lecture 7.3 at 9" performance difference
post_text:
amazing! You where right. When I change the order, the results are indeed that the first call takes more time than the second call. So this is apparently not the right way to measure the performance. 
Thanks for the reply
Kind regards, Hugo

title: The assigment checker of week 7 accepts reversed solutions
post_text:
Problem: There is a typo or other mistake on the page (e.g., factual error, information omitted)

Problem ID: pages-mistake

URL: https://class.coursera.org/progfun-005


Browser: Chrome 38
OS: Windows 7


Additional details:
After submitting a solution to this assignment i found that i sent an incorrect solution producing a reversed list of moves. Nevertheless the assignment checker graded the solution as correct.

Possibly related, in the unit test given with the assignment,(file BloxorzSuite.scala) the 'solve' function in SolutionChecker does not verify that all intermediate positions are valid. As a result a reversed solution is always correct

possible fix in BloxorzSuite.scala:

    def solve(ls: List[Move]): Block = {
      val blocks = ls.foldLeft(List(startBlock)) {
        case (blocks, Left) => blocks.head.left :: blocks
        case (blocks, Right) => blocks.head.right :: blocks
        case (blocks, Up) => blocks.head.up :: blocks
        case (blocks, Down) => blocks.head.down :: blocks
      }
      if (blocks forall { _.isLegal }) blocks.head else startBlock

title: Bug in grading system
post_text:
Grading system accepts reversed solutions.

If you carefully read comments, than you should have seen that:
   * Note: the `head` element of the returned list should represent
   * the first move that the player should perform from the starting
   * position.

I forgot to reverse history, and grading system accepted my solution 20/20

I had modified BloxorzSuite as follows to catch this sitiuation:

    val ILLEGAL = Block(Pos(-1, -1), Pos(-1, -1))

    def solve(ls: List[Move]): Block =
      ls.foldLeft(startBlock) {
        case (block, move) => move match {
          case Left => if (block.left.isLegal) block.left else ILLEGAL
          case Right => if (block.right.isLegal) block.right else ILLEGAL
          case Up => if (block.up.isLegal) block.up else ILLEGAL
          case Down => if (block.down.isLegal) block.down else ILLEGAL
        }
      }

title: What type the element of  for-yield generated Seq is determinated by ?
post_text:
Getting from dictionaryByOccurrences gives you a list of words. Travesing it like you did
words <- dictionaryByOccurrences.getOrElse(item, Nil)
means that in each iteration, "words" will represent one word from that list.
This means that in each iteration, "words" is already a Word. Traversing it in your third generator (word <- words) means that "word" will be a Char in each iteration (because you're iterating over a Word, which is basically a String).

This is why you're getting the error - your return value is defined as a List[Word], not a List[Char].

def printInFor[T](s: T): T = {
	  println(s.toString)
	  s
	}                                         //> printInFor: [T](s: T)T

  for {
  	a <- Set('a','b','c','d') map printInFor
  	b <- Set(1,2,3,4)
  } yield (a.toString + b)                        //> a
                                                  //| b
                                                  //| c
                                                  //| d
                                                  //| res0: scala.collection.immutable.Set[String] = Set(c3, c4, 
                                                  //| b2, b3, d4, d3, b4, c2, b1, a4, c1, d2, a3, a1, d1, a2)
}

title: printing intermediate values from a for loop

title: IndexedSeq from for..yield
post_text:
You are traversing over a Range. The compiler would like to return a Range, but it cannot (since you are yielding something that are not Range indexes), so it falls back to the closest compatible supertype, i.e. IndexedSeq. The default implementation of IndexedSeq is a Vector, so there you have it.

You can always get a List by calling .toList at the end.

title: question from Prof. Oderskys book - Chapter 18
post_text:
If I understand you correctly, the lines in question are

def afterDelay(delay: Int)(block: => Unit) {
    val item = WorkItem(currentTime + delay, () => block)

Note the second argument to the WorkItem Constructor is not block itself but an anonymous function, () => block.  That transforms the by-name parameter into a function for the WorkItem Constructor. Since the return of a function can't be by-name (by-name only makes sense for parameters), the body of this function evaluates the by-name block to return its Unit.

title: Lecture 7.1 exercise - assumptions missing?
post_text:
Hi,
I think there is something missing in the exercise at the end of lecture 7.1.
As far as I understand the IntSet is aimed as an implementation of a BST, but this assumption is neither stated nor enforced in the implementation. And to prove the correctness for the union operation I think we have to use some assumption of this kind (e.g. for NonEmpty(z,l,r) where (x<z) then (r contains x = false)). Without this assumption we can do:

abstract class IntSet {

     def incl(x: Int): IntSet

     def contains(x: Int): Boolean

     def union(other: IntSet): IntSet

}

object Empty extends IntSet {

def contains(x: Int): Boolean = false

def incl(x: Int): IntSet = NonEmpty(x, Empty, Empty)

def union(other: IntSet) = other

}

case class NonEmpty(elem: Int, left: IntSet, right: IntSet) extends IntSet {

  def contains(x: Int): Boolean =

    if (x < elem) left contains x

    else if (x > elem) right contains x

    else true

    

  def incl(x: Int): IntSet =

    if (x < elem) NonEmpty(elem, left incl x, right)

    else if (x > elem) NonEmpty(elem, left, right incl x)

    else this

    

    def union(other: IntSet): IntSet = (left union (right union (other))) incl elem

}

val wrongL = new NonEmpty(5,Empty,Empty)  //> wrongL  : week7.intsets.NonEmpty = NonEmpty(5,week7.intsets$Empty$@368102c8,

                                                  //| week7.intsets$Empty$@368102c8)

val wrongR = new NonEmpty(3,Empty,Empty)  //> wrongR  : week7.intsets.NonEmpty = NonEmpty(3,week7.intsets$Empty$@368102c8,

                                                  //| week7.intsets$Empty$@368102c8)

val wrongS = new NonEmpty(4,wrongL,wrongR)//> wrongS  : week7.intsets.NonEmpty = NonEmpty(4,NonEmpty(5,week7.intsets$Empty

                                                  //| $@368102c8,week7.intsets$Empty$@368102c8),NonEmpty(3,week7.intsets$Empty$@36

                                                  //| 8102c8,week7.intsets$Empty$@368102c8))

  wrongS contains 5                         //> res0: Boolean = false

(wrongS union Empty) contains 5           //> res1: Boolean = true


And the reason for this result is obviously that wrongS is not a correct BST.

On the other hand I think that proofs in the lecture might actually work without this assumption.

What do you think? Am I missing something here?

title: question from Prof. Oderskys book - Chapter 18
post_text:
That's it

Ok ,so block in afterDelay is a parameter, passed by name, which returns a value of Unit (i.e. nothing).

This is then used to create an anonymous function which takes no parameters (i.e. the () bit and executes block to return Unit. (the f(x) bit in x=> f(x), only without the x).

Think I get it now. Thanks for taking the time to answer.

title: Lecture 7.5- from():does 'more'get evaluated each time a value is retrieved from the stream?

In the water pouring problem (Lecture 7.5)  we have code sort of like

from(paths ..) = if paths.isEmpty Stream.empty else {
  val more = for(..) yield val
  paths #:: from(more ..)
}

If not why not?

title: Can Scala do some memcopy jobs like C/C++?
post_text:
StringBuilder is one option to work with large strings.

But if you would've used memcpy in C/C++ a byte array might be closer to what you're looking for.

Billions of lines is gigabytes of memory, if possible you might want to use a Stream instead of loading the entire file into memory.

title: Lecture 7.5- from():does 'more'get evaluated each time a value is retrieved from the stream?
post_text:
As I understand it, the for expression gets transformed into a series of flatMap, withFilter and map operations depending on which apply. This is explained in the lectures of week 6, lecture 6.5 iirc.

This means every call to from(...) is evaluated at most once, and as late as possible, due to the lazy nature of streams.

title: Lecture 7.5- from():does 'more'get evaluated each time a value is retrieved from the stream?
post_text:
@Randall: of course the value is defined for each time the function is called: its (new) value is used every single time. This is because each value defines all paths with one hop more.

Reading your question again, I think you overlooked something: to get all initial moves (let us assume there are 4), you do a take(1) on the result, and you get a Set with 4 instances.

This is different from the Bloxorz assignment, where a take(4) on the pathsFromStart will yield 4 of the shortest paths.

title: sentenceOccurrences(dictionary) return java.lang.StackOverflowError
post_text: I am not sure why you would want to run sentenceOccurrences against an entire dictionary.  The aim of that method is to give the occurrences for a single sentence. The javadoc comment says, "Converts a sentence into its character occurrence list. "

title: sentenceOccurrences(dictionary) return java.lang.StackOverflowError
post_text: Although both a sentence and dictionary are list of words, sentenceOccurrences is meant to work with a much smaller list of words than an entire dictionary.  My implementation took a while [edit: I optimized it down to less than a second] to return but didn't crash, most likely because I used functions that were tail recursive.  You shouldn't need to test sentenceOccurrences with sentences that long.

title: A simple for-expression doesn't always translate to a map()
post_text:
Problem: There is a typo or other mistake on the page (e.g., factual error, information omitted)

Problem ID: pages-mistake

URL: https://class.coursera.org/progfun-005/wiki/AssignmentFeedback


Browser: Chrome 38
OS: Windows 7


Additional details:
In following lecture 6.5's "Translation of For (1)" slide, I was trying to translate the following for-expression to a map (where cts is a Map[Char, String]):
    for ((c, s) <- cts) yield (c, s.length)

The direct translation would be
    cts map (( (c, s) ) => (c, s.length))

But this gives the errors "not a legal formal parameter", "not found: value c", "not found: value s"

I had to go with this less-desirable form:
    cts map (p => (p._1, p._2.length))

Apparently the problem is that a for-expression can use pattern matching, but the arguments to the map function cannot.

title: sentenceAnagrams end-recursion condition
post_text:
I had problems with missing results, it turns out my subtraction method was the culprit. The procedure I used to figure this out was:

- for the smallest case ie. one word, stub in a dictionary of "real words" as well as the recursive result of making an anagram that yields one word. if you can return the pairs of found words and your one word, the logic of your sentence anagrams should be ok

- then try to remove the stubs and use "live" data. I used the real dictionary of words with the stubbed recursive result and it worked fine, so I knew I had to look at the arguments of the recursive call. Writing more tests for the arguments of the recursive call yielded my bug.

Hope this helps.

title: subtract Hint
post_text:
if you have performance problems in sentenceAnagrams it's very likely subtract() is implemented incorrectly. With regards to the original request the instructions tell you almost step by step what to do.

a) you want to work on maps
b) you want  to use foldLeft (and accumulate on what?)
c) if you need to remove an element use map - key
d) if you want to update an element use map updated (key, newValue)

You can write this in one line (or more depending on how you format your code)

Remember to sort when you convert back to List

List(1, 2) ::: List(3, 4)
different from 
List(1, 2).:::(List(3, 4))
? title: Lecture 5.1: Why is infix different from standard?
post_text: Operators ending with : are by convention methods of their right hand operand. This is exactly to make some collection methods work. For example in the :: case (you want cons to be a method of the following list, not the preceding object) or the +: operator for sequences.

title: Why does my solution work?
post_text:
Difficult to tell without looking at the actual implementation, but notice that, if you followed the solution outlined in the assignment:

Occurrence for "seat" -> List(('a', 1), ('e', 1), ('s', 1), ('t', 1))
Occurrence for "eat" -> List(('a', 1), ('e', 1), ('t', 1))

As the occurrence is used as the key to retrieve words from the dictionary with the same occurrence, "eat" would never be retrieved as a possible anagram for "seat".

title: Bloxorz Solution Visualizer
Why does my solution work?
post_text:
My guess is that your for comprehension is gracefully handling it. If you have something like the following, on recursive calls to innerFunc where no anagrams could be made, there is no contribution to the yielded list.

def innerFunc(...) {
...
for {
...
subSolution <- innerFunc(reducedArgument)
...
} yield ...

My guess is that if you call your function on List(('s', 1)) and trace its evaluation, you'll find that it goes through the for comprehension but doesn't yield anything. So if the caller iterates over the returned subSolutions, of which there are none, it will likewise not yield any solutions that need List(('s', 1)) to be the reduced argument.

Sorry if that isn't clear; I'm just guessing what your solution looks like based on the lecture.

Vector(level.split("\s*
").map(str => Vector(str: _*)): _*)

title: sentenceAnagrams end-recursion condition
post_text: You're welcome! Happy to help.

title: Type Ascription
post_text:
I don't like when they use exotic language features in the assignments and don't explain them to us. In the assignment for week 7 they used this:

Vector(level.split("\n").map(str => Vector(str: _*)): _*)

The _* is a compiler hint to treat a single sequence parameter as multiple decomposed parameters to a varargs function. A String f.e. is treated by the compiler as a sequence of Char objects. And an Array[Vector[Char]] is treated as a sequence of Vector[Char] objects. This makes a big difference to the called Vector.apply() method.

Taken from the Scala Documentation:

Ascriptions

Type ascription is often confused with type annotation, as the syntax in Scala is identical. The following are examples of ascription:

  • Nil: List[String]
  • Set(values: _*)
  • "Daniel": AnyRef

Ascription is basically just an up-cast performed at compile-time for the sake of the type checker. Its use is not common, but it does happen on occasion. The most often seen case of ascription is invoking a varargs method with a single Seq parameter. This is done by ascribing the _* type (as in the second example above).

title: Assignment done, and now?
post_text:
What's next? The logical next step is to join the Principles of Reactive Programming course as it's more or less the follow-up course to this (either join the old course now and just work through the material or wait for the next official run which is expected in spring 2015).
Also, you might want to develop some small projects from scratch to strengthen your confidence in your Scala skills outside of those guided "fill in the blank spaces"-assignments.

About exploiting the course for your career: this course is so well-known among the Scala community that wherever you apply for a Scala job, people will know it and know what to expect from someone who did this course. However: if you're planning to go that route, I'd even more suggest doing the reactive programming course too.
Whether you add the course to your CV or just add Scala to your list of skills is up to you (I'd choose the latter).

title: wordOccurrences call for map
post_text:
I tried to implemented wordOccurrences using
.... .map ( (c:Char,s:Sentence) => (c,s.length()) ) ....

This made various (type inference?) errors, so I ended up replacing it with a solution hinted to in here the forum, which uses:

 ... .map({ case (c,s) => (c,s.length()) }) ...



I have only two problems with this:

  1. why doesn't my original solution work? 
  2. why does the correct solution work? Specifically, shouldn't the parameter to map be a function deceleration? 
Thanks!

title: wordOccurrences call for map
post_text: The map function works by calling a function with a single parameter (not two as you show).  In addition, the parameter type of the tuple being passed is (Char, String) not (Char, Sentence).  You can then use ._1  and ._2 to reference the tuple elements.  The second works because it creates an implicit match function where the case separates the tuple elements for you.

title: Bloxorz Solution Visualizer
post_text: Pretty neat.  Bear in mind that this solver expects the solution move list to be ordered with the first move first and the last move last so you may need to reverse your solution List if you, like me, ordered it the other way around.

title: Type Ascription
post_text: There's a mention of ascription starting at the 17:18 mark of Lecture 6.6

title: wordOccurrences call for map
post_text: Keep in mind that a parameter of a pair type (A,B) is not the same as two parameters of type A and B. So in the first case you pass to .map a function which takes 2 arguments instead of one (which happens to be of type (Char, Sequence)).

title: Assignment done, and now?
post_text:
Luca, yes, now they can't verify the assignments were solved by yourself. It's kinda awkward verification where you need to take a photo of your face before each homework submit. You must also provide o webcam photo of your ID when you register for Signature Track. Coursera claims that Your photo identification document will be deleted after successful verification of your profile information. But they still may keep (and improve further each time) your biometric information that is used for photo verification. Coursera saves and verifies also your typing pattern. On the other hand as an U.S. company they are obligated to provide any stored information to the government. In the worst case the NSA can track you down by this data on other websites or even on airports, rail stations and street surveillance cameras.

If you still want a verified certificate from Coursera, add a future session of this course to your watch list. Maybe in 1-2 month a new session will start and you can then submit your assignments again with a paid Signature Track. AFAIK they don't change the assignments on new sessions.

title: Why it does not fail? sentenceAnagrams potential endless resursion
post_text:
When it comes to the sentenceAnagrams, I did a substraction within the for-comprehension.

something like this:

...
for {
  someOccurrence <- ...
  someWord <-   ...
  partialsentence <- a_iterator_helper_function(substract(previous occurrence, someOccurrence))
}
...
My question is that:
it is possible that `someOccurrence` is `List()`, and then `substract(previous occurrence, someOccurrence)` is doing `substract(previous occurrence, List())`.

And my `substraction` for that will return the exact `previous occurrence`.
So the `a_iterator_helper_function` will be called exactly again with the same input.
So I suppose tests should fail due to infinitely looping.
But I got passed with the tests.

I don't know why I don't need a checking `! someOccurrence.isEmpty`.

title: sentenceAnagrams of an empty list = the key to solution?
post_text:
The test provided in forcomp.zip turns out to be the most confusing part of the assignment, which also implied a key to the solution:

test("sentence anagrams: []") {
  val sentence = List()
  assert(sentenceAnagrams(sentence) === List(Nil))
}

Why anagrams of an empty sentence is a List(Nil) and not just List()?

A good hint which could have saved me (and probably others) a lot of time would be a reminder that:

  def computeList(a: Int):List[Int] = List()
  for {
    a <- List(1, 2, 3)
    b <- computeList(a)
  } yield
     (a, b)

Will not yield anything, because inner loop is over the empty list (which totally makes sense).

Another confusing (unexpected) part was that I tried to use Nil as a different return code from List():

  def computeListOfLists(a: Int):List[List[Int]] = a match {
    case 1 => List(List(888))
    case 2 => List() // blank solution
    case 3 => Nil // no solution
  }
  for {
    a <- List(1, 2, 3)
    b <- computeListOfLists(a)
    if b != Nil
  } yield
     a :: b

Yields List(List(1, 888)) and not List(List(1, 888), List(2)).

The real reason is that b cannot be iterated on an empty list. Why Nil == List()? In the end I realized that this works:

  def computeListOfLists(a: Int):List[List[Int]] = a match {
    case 1 => List(List(888))
    case 2 => List(Nil) // same as List(List())
    case 3 => Nil
  }
  for {
    a <- List(1, 2, 3)
    b <- computeListOfLists(a)
  } yield
     a :: b

Yields List(List(1, 888), List(2)) as expected.

Would you please consider adding a hint / reminder about this in the assignment description for future students?

title: wordOccurrences and groupBy
post_text:
My initial implementation of wordOccurrences used map function and did not use groupBy. After initial submission, I've rewrote it using groupBy to make the grading system happy.

I wrote 2 versions using group by:

  1. One involved reversing the map produced by groupBy which resulted in 2 nested loops (similar to the example shown in the Lecture 6.7 video about the phone numbers).
  2. Another was using groupBy + map combination similar to the example in assignment description. However that seems weird because it produces intermediate result which is getting transformed & discarded:
    Map(
0 -> List(0, 0),
1 -> List(1, 1),
2 -> List(2)
)

Both of these seem clumsy. My original solution used just a single map (one could argue there is another hidden inside of distinct or toSet depending what I use).

Is this expected, or there is a way to implement it using groupBy in a cleaner way?

title: Lecture 7.4 Why does sqrtStream store guesses in a lazy val?
post_text:
Because guesses refers to itself, which can only be done with either def (which evaluates the definition every time), or lazy val (which evaluates it only once).

You can try the code in the IDE; remove the lazy, and you'll get a syntax error.

title: Why it does not fail? sentenceAnagrams potential endless resursion
post_text:
Actually, someWord is call by a function whose parameter is someOccurrence, i.e., someWord = func(someOccurrence).

When someOccurrence is empty, someWord <- List(). It makes the for loop skip this iteration.

So we do not need to check if someOccurrence.isEmpty.

title: SBT Import failed in Intellij IDEA
post_text:
When you get these errors, the best way to resolve it is to remove the existing content root from the Intelli J Project Structure and recreate the your content root.

So the step by step directions that I followed include.

1. Unzip the module.
2. Remove the eclipse specific files, like .classpath and .project and .settings
3. Import the project into Intellij, using Import Project and choose the existing structure as SBT.
4.  Use Auto-Import setting as On.
5. The project will get imported, but the Source Roots will not be setup propertly.
6. To fix, simply remove the existing sourceroot and add the source root back.

In the end, It will look like

title: Assignment 6. Why so much Lists? Why not Sets?
post_text:
For the occurrence, I think that a Set could not be used because Sets do not guarantee the order of elements and we need the letters ordered. Set does not care with the position of its elements, while Lists do. Run this in the worksheet:

val s1 = Set(('a', 1), ('b', 2), ('c', 3), ('d', 4))
                                                  //> s1  : scala.collection.immutable.Set[(Char, Int)] = Set((a,1), (b,2), (c,3), 
                                                  //| (d,4))
val s2 = Set(('d', 4), ('a', 1), ('b', 2), ('c', 3))
                                                  //> s2  : scala.collection.immutable.Set[(Char, Int)] = Set((d,4), (a,1), (b,2),
                                                  //|  (c,3))
s1 == s2                                  //> res0: Boolean = true
val l1 = List(('a', 1), ('b', 2), ('c', 3), ('d', 4))
                                                  //> l1  : List[(Char, Int)] = List((a,1), (b,2), (c,3), (d,4))
val l2 = List(('d', 4), ('a', 1), ('b', 2), ('c', 3))
                                                  //> l2  : List[(Char, Int)] = List((d,4), (a,1), (b,2), (c,3))
l1 == l2                                  //> res1: Boolean = false

Of course you probably can come up with a solution using Set but you have to have these critical differences in mind.

title: Comment on Lecture 7.2 and 7.3
post_text:
As I was following the lectures I came across the following example, which I'm going to present in form of a question:
What is the difference between: 
val ex01 = streamRange(1000, 100000) filter isPrime
and 
lazy val ex01 = streamRange(1000, 100000) filter isPrime
if the only extra line is: 
(ex01 take 3).toList
The answer is that the first one needs to compute the first value, while the second one doesn't (as the line is executed).

Just thought about sharing these differences.

Best,

title: How do i invoke this function
post_text:
Your use case sounds weird, but here:

  def businessFunction = {
    (new ((Int => Int, Int, Int) => Int) {
      def apply(f: Int => Int, x: Int, y: Int): Int = {
        if (x > y) 0
        else f(x) + apply(f, x + 1, y)
      }
    })(x => x, 1, 2)
  }

  def businessFunctionX(g: Int => Int)(a: Int, b: Int) = {
    (new ((Int => Int, Int, Int) => Int) {
      def apply(f: Int => Int, x: Int, y: Int): Int = {
        if (x > y) 0
        else f(x) + apply(f, x + 1, y)
      }
    })(g, a, b)
  }

title: val or def
post_text:
A def is like a direct definition of a Function. Remember, in one of the earlier weeks of the course, we saw that we needed an apply method to mix functions and objects. The argument list and body of a def are translatable into a Function type's apply method.

When you're not inside a class, the following are equivalent:

def myFunc(x: Int): Int = // do stuff
myFunc(5)

val myVal = new Function1[Int,Int] {
  def apply(x: Int) = // do stuff
}
myVal(5)

myVal and myFunc both represent exactly one value - a Function1[Int,Int] instance. In other words, when you do myVal(5), you are actually getting an object before the application:

myVal(5) --> Function1$(5) --> Function1$.apply(5)

 

 

 

Also note, def inside a class defines a method on that class. Which means that function doesn't have to exist on its own as an object and thus no Function instance is made.

title: val or def
post_text:
vals have a single simple type, e.g. String and are a reference to an object in memory.

defs represent methods and have a more complex type, e.g. String -> Int. Methods are generally stored in the symbol table for look-up at compile-time but don't necessarily have an object in memory.

If we ever store a reference to a method, we store a Function instance. So val f: String -> Int is actually storing a Function1[String, Int] object.

title: sentenceAnagrams of an empty list = the key to solution?
post_text:
Every sentence has itself as anagram. Even if the sentence is empty: there is exactly one way to order 0 elements.

While this may seem counterintuitive, it does ensure that there always is an empty solution to extend. In fact, the N-queens example in the lectures uses this to terminate recursion for valid solutions. For invalud solutions, the for comprehension recurses into nothing.

title: Bloxorz advanced features
post_text:
This was a good assignment, thanks.  Perhaps it was the way it was based around a concrete example of a problem.  Anyway, I enjoyed it so much that I decided to do the ‘obvious’ thing and extend it to incorporate the more advanced rules of Bloxorz, i.e. squares representing:

  • fragile terrain on which you cannot have a standing block
  • teleports that split the block into two single blocks, and you use toggle between them (until they come back together)
  • switches to create/destroy/toggle bridges
  • switches that need a ‘heavy’ standing block on them to operate them.

If anyone is interested in this, and wants some pointers (without giving everything away, and certainly without helping you with the basic assignment!) here are a few notes on how I did it.  If you are interested, but want to do it all yourself, then look away now!

  • Solving.  I thought about this first, because it influences the other changes.  The main change is that when calculating paths, not only do you have to pass around a list of tuples of (block, list of moves that got you to that block), you also have to pass around the updated terrain at that point (since the terrain can now change).  I introduced a new Terrain class (see below), and then the solving generates passes around Stream[(Block, List[Move], Terrain)].  Also explored is now Set[(Block, Terrain)] (e.g. two explored ‘positions’ are different if they have the same Block, but different Terrains).
  • ‘Block’ class.  Still defined as b1 and b2 positions.  But if a ‘Block’ is split then the positions needn’t be adjacent (or on top of each other).  I decided b1 would represent the active half of a split block (which means relaxing the requirement that b1 is lexicographically less than b2).  Various updates to up/down/left/right.  A new ‘toggle’ returning the toggling of split block (swap over b1 and b2).  If the block is split then ‘neighbours’ also returns a move of toggling the block.  ‘isLegal’ needs to take into account fragile terrain (see below). 
  • ‘Terrain’ class.  Previously the terrain was just a function of type Pos => Boolean, whether a position was in the terrain or not.  I first defined a new Square class to represent the squares of the terrain, with case sub-classes In, Out, Start, Goal, Fragile, Split, HeavySwitch, SoftSwitch.  The last three case classes were parameterized with the new positions resulting from a split, or a List(Pos) to represent a bridge and whether the switch created, destroyed or toggled it.  The base terrain is then a function of type Pos => Square.  I defined a new ‘Terrain’ class to represent the dynamically changing terrain.  Objects of this class can be passed around when solving the problem (as mentioned above).  I implemented the class with a Map[Pos, Boolean] which is a representation of the positions that have been overridden from the base terrain to be in or out.  Various methods on this class.  inTerrain: Pos => Boolean looks to see if there is an override in the map, else looks at the base terrain.  update: (Pos, Boolean) => Terrain adds or updates an overridden position in the map with whether it is in or out.  updateBridge update all the list of positions for a given bridge when its switch is hit.  Finally ‘move’ moves a block on this terrain, which inspects the postion(s) it has moved to, and returns a possibly new block (e.g. it might have been split), and a possibly new terrain (e.g. bridges changed).
  • When implementing ‘move’ you discover some complexities if non-standing blocks cover two special squares.  Some can be handled, but some lead to ill-defined behaviour.  E.g. a block could activate two switches, so you need to apply the updates to the terrain for one then the other, but if both switches act on the same bridge the order you apply the updates in could make a difference to the resulting terrain.  Or what do you do if a block spans two teleports?  I just assumed levels wouldn’t be defined like that.
  • Parsing.  Change terrainFunction to return a function of type Pos => Square.  You can incorporate a new symbol in the text representation of a level for ‘fragile’ squares.  But I separately defined any other special squares as val specials: Map[Pos, Square]. 

For example, here is a level with a switch that toggles a bridge allowing you to get to the goal, and its solution (excuse the poor formatting):

object LevelSoftSwitch extends Level {
  val level = """ooSoo--oT""".stripMargin
  override val specials = Map(Pos(0,0) -> SoftSwitch(List(Pos(0,5), Pos(0,6)), Create))
}
List(Left, Right, Right, Right, Right, Right)
Here is a level with some fragile terrain to be negotiated,
and its solution:
object LevelFragile extends Level {
  val level = """SooxooT
                |-ooooo-""".stripMargin
}
List(Right, Down, Right, Right, Up, Right)
Here is a level with a teleport, and its solution:
object LevelSplit2 extends Level {
  val level = """ooSoo
                |----o
                |----T""".stripMargin
  override val specials = Map(Pos(0,0) -> Split(Pos(0,1), Pos(0,3)))
}

List(Left, Toggle, Right, Down, Toggle, Right, Right, Right, Down)

title: styleCheck message: Covariant equals without overriding equals(java.lang.Object)
post_text:
The parameter shouldn't be java Object. Use scala Any instead.

//Pos equals
override def equals(that: Any): Boolean = that match {
  case other: Pos => this.x == other.x && this.y == other.y
  case _ => false
}

Similar for Block equals

title: Unit tests using InfiniteSuite
post_text:
This might be useful to anyone who, like me, is trying to create unit tests like those given in BloxorzSuite, but for the infinite terrain.

The trick is that with InfiniteTerrain, the start and goal positions cannot be inferred from the level matrix, so you must provide them explicitly in each Level instance you define.

@RunWith(classOf[JUnitRunner])
class InfiniteSuite extends FunSuite {
  trait SolutionChecker extends GameDef with Solver with InfiniteTerrain {

    /**
     * This method applies a list of moves `ls` to the block at position
     * `startPos`. This can be used to verify if a certain list of moves
     * is a valid solution, i.e. leads to the goal.
     */
    def solve(ls: List[Move]): Block =
      ls.foldLeft(startBlock) { case (block, move) => move match {
        case Left => block.left
        case Right => block.right
        case Up => block.up
        case Down => block.down
      }
    }
  }

  trait Level1 extends SolutionChecker {
      /* Infinite terrain with same start and goal positions as level 1*/

    val startPos: Pos = Pos(1,1)
    val goal: Pos = Pos(4,7)

    /* The optimal solution is 1 move shorter than in the restricted terrain case */
    val optsolution = List(Right, Right, Right, Right, Down, Down)
  }  

  /* Note: If you want to re-run the tests in BloxorzSuite, some of them need to be adjusted to allow for the extra degrees of freedom on the infinite grid. */

  test("Put your tests here") { }
}

title: neighborsWithHistory test
post_text:
Hello, I am trying to implement all tests, and the assignment detail, under neighborsWithHistory :

As mentioned above, the history is ordered so that the most recent move is the head of the list. If you consider Level 1 as defined in Bloxorz.scala, then

neighborsWithHistory(Block(Pos(1,1),Pos(1,1)), List(Left,Up))
results in a stream with the following elements (given as a set):

Set(
  (Block(Pos(1,2),Pos(1,3)), List(Right,Left,Up)),
  (Block(Pos(2,1),Pos(3,1)), List(Down,Left,Up))
)
However, running this on the Level 1 would not make sense, as from Block(Pos(1,2),Pos(1,3) it is not possible to move up. anyone else implement this test?

title: For Those Wanting to Immediately Jump Into Principles of Reactive Programming
post_text: I would also like to know this :)

title: neighborsWithHistory test
post_text:
In
neighborsWithHistory(Block(Pos(1,1),Pos(1,1)), List(Left,Up))
you say "give me the neighbors of a standing block on (1,1) and that block has made the following moves so far (it's his history): Left, Up (or in the order of execution - up, left).

The result seems correct to me - you can go right, in which case "Right" is appended to the history (on the left side), or you can go down, in which case "Down" is appended to the history.

title: Understanding Block moves with diagrams
post_text:
Back in the file GameDef.scala, a block is a 2 x 1 x 1 cuboid. We represent it as a case class which contains two fields, the 2D position of both the cubes which make up the block.

A Block is therefore a case class Block(b1: Pos, b2: Pos), and can move in four different directions, each time yielding a new block. To this effect, the methods left, right, up and down are provided.

A Block is two cubes. A Block is standing if one of its cubes is on top of the other.

With this understanding can anyone draw a diagram showing left, right, up and down moves?

def left = if (isStanding)         dy(-2, -1)
               else if (b1.x == b2.x)  dy(-1, -2)
               else                    dy(-1, -1)

    /** The block obtained by moving right */
    def right = if (isStanding)        dy(1, 2)
                else if (b1.x == b2.x) dy(2, 1)
                else                   dy(1, 1)

etc.

Thanks in advance.

sqrtStream(4).take(3).toList
